text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
kidney stone
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ transferred from ___ Ed to ___ ED with L UVJ sonte 
9mm in size.  He had some moderate ___ pain this morning with 
nausea an no vomiting.  CT ___ moderate hydroureteronephrosis.  
Pain now no longer present, no more nause.  No fever.  WBC: 13; 
Creat 1.3
 
Past Medical History:
HTN, DM, prostatitis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
Gen: NAD
Abd: soft, NT, ND
no CVAt
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted from the ED to Dr. ___ 
service for pain control, IV fluids and observation.  On HD#2 
his pain was no longer present and he was without nausea. He 
received IV fluids for elevated creatinine.  He has been without 
fever or leukocytosis.  A KUB confirmed the presence of the 
stone.  He is discharged to home with plan to follow up with Dr. 
___ management of his distal ureteral stone.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime).  
3. Acetaminophen 650 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six 
(6) hours as needed for pain.  
4. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain not controlled with tylenol.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Metformin 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO qAM.  
6. Metformin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO qPM.  
7. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day: 
take this medication if you are taking percocet.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Kideny stone (Left UVJ)

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks. 
-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequecy over the next month.
-You may have already passed your kidney stone, or it may still 
be in the process of passing.  You may experience some pain 
associated with spasm of your ureter.  This is normal.  Take 
tylenol as directed and take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.   
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.   
Max daily Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain 
medication may contain Tylenol (acetaminophen)
-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself 
hydrated and facilitate passage of stone fragments.
-You may shower and bathe normally. 
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
-Resume all of your home medications excet for your Lisinopril.  
Please do not take your lisinopril until you have seen your 
primary care doctor to check your kidney function.
-Call Dr. ___ for ___ AND if you have any 
questions. 
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Back/chest pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cardiac catheterization
Promus Drug eluting stent placed to Left Circumflex artery
 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o gentleman with type 1 DM, dyslipidemia, presented with 
back pain radiating to chest. Patient stated feeling unwell 
yesterday afternoon with ? diffuse myalgia. Last night at around 
9 ___ he started having back pain radiating to his chest. He has 
had similar pain in the last ___ years but not as severe as last 
night. He felt nauseous, diaphoretic and short of breath. He 
came to ___ ED.
.  
In the ED, initial vitals were T 96.1  HR 58  BP 133/77  RR 18  
100% in RA. He recieved ASA 325 mg, Plavix 300 mg, heparin 
bolus/gtt, integrillin bolus/gtt. He also recieved nitro SL x 3, 
morphine/dilaudid, zofran 4 mg IV x1. He was eventually started 
on nitro gtt. Given his chest pain has not resolved and he had 
concerning ECG changes he was taken to cardiac catheterization.  
He recieved 2.5x23 promus to occluded proximal ___. He had 
angiosesal in right groin. 
.
On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, 
TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the 
time of surgery, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or 
red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies 
exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of 
systems were negative.  
.  
Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of paroxysmal 
nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope 
or presyncope.
.  

 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: + Diabetes, + Dyslipidemia, - 
Hypertension  
2. CARDIAC HISTORY:  
N/A 
3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 
- Type 1 DM approx ___ years
- Concussion some ___ years ago after a mechanical fall, short
episode of LOC.
- ? Seizures, but patient think they were hypoglycemic episodes
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or 
sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory.  

 
Physical Exam:
VS: T=... BP=134/76 HR=86 RR=... O2 sat=... 
GENERAL: Pleasant gentleman in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect 
appropriate.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no 
pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  
NECK: Supple with JVP of 6 cm.  
CARDIAC: RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 
or S4.  
LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits.  
SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.  
PULSES:  
Right: DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: DP 2+ ___ 2+  

 
Pertinent Results:
Labs on Admission:

___ 11:00PM BLOOD WBC-9.5 RBC-4.80 Hgb-14.5 Hct-40.9 MCV-85 
MCH-30.2 MCHC-35.4* RDW-12.9 Plt ___
___ 11:00PM BLOOD ___ PTT-24.1 ___
___ 11:00PM BLOOD Glucose-173* UreaN-16 Creat-1.1 Na-139 
K-3.7 Cl-102 HCO3-25 AnGap-16
___ 11:00PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-104
___ 11:00PM BLOOD CK-MB-3
___ 05:00AM BLOOD Cholest-200*
___ 11:00PM BLOOD %HbA1c-7.1*
___ 05:00AM BLOOD Triglyc-35 HDL-71 CHOL/HD-2.8 LDLcalc-122
On discharge:

___ 04:34AM BLOOD WBC-11.5* RBC-4.52* Hgb-13.6* Hct-38.9* 
MCV-86 MCH-30.1 MCHC-35.0 RDW-13.4 Plt ___
___ 05:47AM BLOOD Glucose-50* UreaN-14 Creat-1.1 Na-143 
K-4.3 Cl-107 HCO3-26 AnGap-14
___ 05:47AM BLOOD Calcium-9.3 Phos-4.4 Mg-2.1
___ 05:00AM BLOOD Triglyc-35 HDL-71 CHOL/HD-2.8 LDLcalc-___ORONARIES: STEMI s/p drug eluting stent (Promus) to ___. 
Pt was CP free after intervention, no complications. CK peak was 
3869 with MBI of 6.2 and Trop of 3.39. Started on Metoprolol, 
Lisinopril, Aspirin and Plavix. His Atorvastatin was increased 
to 80 mg. LDL 122, goal will be < 80. Hgb A1C 7.1. His groin was 
stable with no significant ecchymosis, bruit or hematoma. 
Angioseal device was used. Pt understands that he needs to take 
Plavix every day for one year without missing any doses. He 
should not stop taking Plavix unless Dr. ___ him 
to. He received discharge activity instructions and will follow 
up with Dr. ___ a repeat ECHO and stress test. 
Cardiac rehabilitation was suggested to him and Dr. ___ 
will refer. 
.
# Regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction: TTE with 
inferior/lateral wall hypokinesis with EF 45%. No symptoms of 
congestive heart failure during hospital stay. Filling pressures 
in the cath lab were normal. Daily weights were discussed with 
pt prior to dischage, started on Lisinopril and Metoprolol 
Succinate at discharge. 
.
# RHYTHM: Currently in NSR. No history of rhythm abnormalities. 
Few episodes of NSVT seen on telemetry. 
.
# TYPE 1 DM: Patient has an insulin pump. A1C 7.1. Currently 
followed by endocrinologist at ___ but requesting new 
endocrinologist at ___. Appt made after discharge.
# Continuing care: Pt has requested that his care be changed to 
___. He will f/u with Dr. ___ cardiology, Dr. 
___ primary care and Dr. ___ for endocrinology. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Insulin pump with humalog
Atorvastatin 20 mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily): Take every day for one year. Do not stop taking unless 
Dr. ___ you to. .
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*11*
3. Atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: 1.5 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hrs PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*45 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
ST Elevation myocardial infarction
Diabetes Mellitus Type 1
Dyslipidemia

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You had a heart attack and a cardiac catheterization showed a 
blockage in your left circumflex artery. You received a drug 
eluting stent (Promus) in your left circumflex. No lifting more 
than 10 pounds for one week, no pools or bathing for one week. 
You may shower and cover the cath site with a band-aid. You were 
started on the following new medicines:
1. Plavix: a platelet inhibitor that prevents the stent from 
clotting off and causing another heart attack. Don't miss any 
doses or stop taking Plavix for one year unless Dr. ___ 
___ you to. 
2. Aspirin: a platelet inhibitor that works with the Plavix to 
prevent the stent from clotting off. 
3. Lisinopril: a blood pressure medicine that helps your heart 
recover from the heart attack
4. Metoprolol: a medicine that slows your heart rate and helps 
your heart recover from the heart attack. 
5. Increase your Atorvastatin to 80 mg. This help with 
inflammation and will lower your bad cholesterol further.
.
You should follow the activity instructions given to you by the 
physical therapist. Dr. ___ will refer you to cardiac 
rehabilitation after he sees you in one month. Please call Dr. 
___ you have a reoccurance of your back pain, trouble 
breathing, sweating, nausea, fevers, bleeding or swelling at the 
cathterization site or any other concerning symptoms. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI:
___ w/h/o PBC presents s/p colonoscopy this AM.  She noted
significant LUQ and shoulder pain after her colonoscopy and a CT
scan was performed showing a small amount of perisplenic fluid 
so
she was directed to the ER.  She currently complains of pain in
her LUQ and shoulder.  +nausea, no vomiting.  No f/c/ns.  No
lightheadedness/dizziness. No hematochezia/melena.

 
Past Medical History:
PBC, Hypothyroid, GERD, COPD, HL

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
 
Temp: 98.1 HR: 65 BP: 133/69 Resp: 18 O(2)Sat: 97
 
Constitutional: Comfortable
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic
Oropharynx within normal limits
Chest: Clear to auscultation
Cardiovascular: Regular Rate and Rhythm, Normal first and
second heart sounds
Abdominal: LUQ tenderness, no rebound no guarding
GU/Flank: No costovertebral angle tenderness
Extr/Back: No cyanosis, clubbing or edema
Skin: No rash, Warm and dry
Neuro: Speech fluent

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:31AM BLOOD WBC-13.0* RBC-4.80 Hgb-13.8 Hct-40.1 
MCV-83 MCH-28.7 MCHC-34.5 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 04:40PM BLOOD WBC-14.0* RBC-4.64 Hgb-13.3 Hct-39.1 
MCV-84 MCH-28.7 MCHC-34.0 RDW-12.8 Plt ___
___ 05:00PM BLOOD Neuts-86.2* Lymphs-11.1* Monos-2.2 
Eos-0.2 Baso-0.4

K-3.9 Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-17
___ 05:00PM BLOOD ALT-42* AST-37 AlkPhos-317* TotBili-0.8
___ 06:31AM BLOOD Calcium-9.8 Phos-2.8 Mg-2.0

___:  cat scan of abdomen and pelvis:

IMPRESSION: 
1. Unchanged quantity of blood along the spleen and tracking 
into the pelvis. 
Distribution of hemoperitoneum is highly suspicious for splenic

quadrant and shoulder pain after a colonoscopy.  A cat scan of 
the abdomen was done which showed a small amount of perisplenic 
fluid and there was concern for a splenic injury. The patient 
was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, and underwent serial 
abdominal examination.  There was close monitoring of her 
hematocrit which remained stable. She underwent a repeat cat 
scan which showed an unchanged quantity of blood along the 
spleen tracking into the pelvis. The distribution of the 
hemoperitoneum was highly suspicious for splenic injury though 
no splenic laceration was clearly identified, and there was  no 
evidence of active extravasation. The patient's vital signs 
remained stable and serial hematocrits unchanged.  A regular 
diet was resumed on HD #3. The patient reported upon mild left 
upper quadrant pain which was present upon admission.  There was 
no intensity of the pain and no association with meals.  She was 
discharged home on HD #4 with stable vital signs and a white 
blood cell count of 11. She was admitted and cared for by the 
acute care surgery service. She was instructed to complete a 1 
week course of antibiotics.  An appointment for follow-up was

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Allergies/ADRs on File
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
MSSA Bacteremia, endocarditis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with alcohol use disorder not 
previously followed by medical care who presented to ___ 
___ with subacute abdominal pain and shortness of 
breath, found to have mitral valve endocarditis and MSSA 
bacteremia. History obtained from chart review and family as 
patient is intubated and sedated. Patient had been in his usual 
state of health one week prior to presentation. Over the past 
week, he developed worsening nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain 
and shortness of breath. He also noted left sided visual changes 
on presentation. He had been riding a 4 ___ a week prior to
arrival and was noted to have several cuts and scrapes. He also 
frequently gets cuts at work.

On arrival to the OSH, patient was found to be hypothermic to 85 
degrees and became progressively hypotensive requiring pressor 
support. On arrival, labs were notable for a lactate of 11, 
creatinine 4.6, BNP >70,000, CK 47,000, troponin 0.23 (--> 
0.30), platelets 14 with negative tox screen. He was tachypneic 
with respiratory rates ___ and mottled from head to toe. He was 
subsequently intubated in the ICU.

He had a CXR performed that demonstrated bilateral infiltrates 
and a blood gas of 7.12/38/143, subsequently started on bicarb 
gtt. He was given 6 L IVF found to be anuric with K 6.4, for 
which patient was started on dialysis ___. He underwent two 
sessions of iHD. Patient had TTE performed which demonstrated
large vegetation on anterior mitral valve leaflet measuring 
2.56cm in length with mild MR, bicuspid aortic valve with mild 
AS, preserved EF without WMA; RVSP 40. He was given vancomycin 
and cefepime. Preliminary blood cultures demonstrated MSSA 
bacteremia and patient was subsequently narrowed to cefazolin. 
He was given stress dose IV steroids. CTA chest/abdomen did not
demonstrate PE or septic emboli. Head CT did not show any acute
abnormality.

He was maintained on Vasopressin, Norepinephrine, Fentanyl, and 
___ transferred to ___ for TEE and surgical evaluation.

Vitals upon transfer T 37.8 HR 109 RR 28 BP 112/57 (73) SpO2 83% 
CMB 500/60% peep 10 Labs prior to transfer notable for pH 
___ lactate 13. gtts on transfer propofol 40mcg/hr, 
norepinephrine 64mcg/min, vasopressin 0.04 units/min, bicarb 
200cc/hr, fentanyl.

On arrival to the CCU, patient is intubated. Propofol was 
discontinued upon arrival due to hypotension and fentanyl was 
discontinued as well. Patient was not responsive despite lack of 
sedation.
 
Past Medical History:
- EtOH use disorder
- Back pain s/p back surgery (no hardware implanted per family)
- Heart murmur since childhood

and  hemidiaphragm are not well seen.  There is airspace disease 
at both lung bases with air bronchograms suspicious for

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man w/___ alcohol use disorder not previously 
followed by medical care, who presented to ___ 
___ with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and shortness of 
breath, found to have mitral valve endocarditis and MSSA 
bacteremia. He was found to be in septic shock with hypotension 
requiring pressor support. He developed respiratory distress and 
was intubated at the OSH. He developed acute renal failure 
requiring hemodialysis. Blood cultures grew MSSA. He was 
initially started on vancomycin and cefepime and subsequently 
narrowed to cefazolin based on culture sensitivities. TTE was 
obtained which showed 2.5cm mitral valve vegetation with 
resultant mild MR, bicuspid aortic valve with mild AS. Patient 
was transferred to ___ for consideration of TEE and cardiac 
surgery evaluation. Upon arrival to ___, patient required 
escalating doses of pressor support. Labs showed increasing 
acidemia with rising lactic acidosis. Cardiac surgery evaluated 
the patient and determined him to not be a surgical candidate. 
Infectious disease was consulted for recommendations on 
antibiotic therapy and nephrology was consulted in preparation 
for CRRT. Antibiotics were broadened to vancomcin, gentamicin, 
and nafcillin. Despite maximum dose of vasopressors, patient's 
blood pressures continued to decline. Family was notified of his 
critical condition and arrived to the bedside. Telemetry showed 
asystole at ___. Exam showed pupils were fixed and dilated. No 
heart or lung sounds were auscultated for ___. No carotid pulse 
was palpated for ___. He did not withdrawal to painful stimuli.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was initially taken to an outside hospital. He was 
intubated for agitation and underwent CT of head and face. A 
nondisplaced maxillary fracture was noted but no other acute 
injuries. He was transfered to ___ for further care, and 
admitted to the ___ given his ventilator-dependance on 
transfer. Plastic surgery was consulted and sutured the 
laceration on his lip. On HD 1 he was weaned off the vent and 
extubated. He remained neurologically intact and reported only 
mild left sided facial pain. His ___ tooth did become loose 
after extubation and was kept in saline pending dental 
evaluation. As his tertiary survey revealed no new injuries and 
he was otherwise well, tolerating diet, voiding, and 
hemodynamically stable, he was discharged home on HD 1. He will 
follow up with his dentist on day of discharge and with ACS in 
clinic as needed. He will also follow up in clinic with plastic 
surgery.

for the pain. Please take this only as directed. You can also 
take tylenol or motrin for pain, but only as directed on the 
bottle.

1. No evidence of acute intracranial process.
2. Right maxillary sinus opacification with no definite
fracture visualized. The density is lower than what would be
expected for acute hemorrhage; however, maxillofacial CT is
recommended.
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was initially taken to an outside hospital. He was
intubated for agitation and underwent CT of head and face. A
nondisplaced maxillary fracture was noted but no other acute
injuries. He was transfered to ___ for further care, and
admitted to the ___ given his ventilator-dependance on
transfer. Plastic surgery was consulted and sutured the
laceration on his lip. On HD 1 he was weaned off the vent and
extubated. He remained neurologically intact and reported only
mild left sided facial pain. His ___ tooth did become loose
after extubation and was kept in saline pending dental
evaluation. As his tertiary survey revealed no new injuries and
he was otherwise well, tolerating diet, voiding, and
hemodynamically stable, he was discharged home on HD 1. He will
follow up with his dentist on day of discharge and with ACS in
clinic as needed. He will also follow up in clinic with plastic
surgery.
Medications on Admission:
none
Discharge Medications:
1. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q4 Disp #*30 Tablet
Refills:*0
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
maxillary fracture
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service for
management of your injuries after an assault. You were found to
have a small fracture to your maxilla and a laceration to your
lip. You were seen by plastic surgery in the emergency
department and the laceration was repaired.
Please make an appointment to see your dentist in the next day.
You will have a small amount of narcotic pain medication to take
for the pain. Please take this only as directed. You can also
take tylenol or motrin for pain, but only as directed on the
bottle.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year old Man with no significant past medical 
history, sent to the ED by PCP ___ 1 month of fevers, migratory 
joint pain, and palpitations. EKG concerning for first or second 
degree heart block. Most likely diagnosis is Lyme given recent 
travel to ___ and ___. Seriologies sent for lyme, 
babesia, blood smears pending. Recently tested negative for HIV, 
gonorrhea, syphilis, chlamydia. Started on IV Ceftriaxone 2g 
daily on ___, received 2 doses. Telemetry showed few episodes 
of Mobitz Type 1 heart block. After 2 days of treatment was 
afebrile, decreased joint pain, and no palpitations. Repeat EKG 
showed first degree heart block. Lyme serologies did not come 
back due to what days they are tested in the lab. Symptoms 
resolving and can be discharged on oral antibiotics for 2 weeks 
of total treatment (end date: ___. Patient has follow up 
appointment with PCP ___ to follow up lab results.

d1= ___, end date = ___

Home

DISSEMINATED LYME DISEASE
FIRST DEGREE HEART BLOCK

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were at ___. 
You were admitted to the hospital because you had fevers for a 
month, joint pain, and new onset palpitations. An EKG showed 
that you had a first degree heart block. The most likely cause 
for all your symptoms was disseminated lyme disease. You were 
tested for lyme disease and other tick borne illnesses, but the 
results did not come back. You were treated empirically for Lyme 
disease with IV antibiotics. Your joint pain, fever, and 
palpitations resolved. Your EKG remained stable and was not 
concerning. You were discharged on oral antibiotics. 

Please follow up with your primary health care provider tomorrow 
to get your lab results.

Sincerely, 

Your medical team at ___

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Allergies/ADRs on File
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Cardiac Arrest
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Femoral a-line
Formal CVL
intuabtion

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old male with reported history of alcohol abuse found 
down at 7AM this morning. Per report he was not feeling well 
since the night prior but was unclear as to the cause of this. 
He was found by his family at 0700 to be unresponsive. The 
family called EMS and they found the patient to be in 
PEA/Asystole. Resusitation was started in the field and 
continued at ___. He recieved several rounds of 
epi, bicarb and calcium. ROSC was obtained after 39 minutes at 
OSH. A crash femoral CVL was placed and a head CT was obtained. 
Patient was placed on epi drip. CT scan reportedly with severe 
edema and troponin of 15. Cooling initiated and patient 
transferred to ___. On arrival to ___ the patient was 
reported to have no movement or response to pain though not on 
sedatives/paralytics, and reported to have unilateral fixed and 
dilated pupil. He was placed on levophed and epi, with 
improvement in his blood pressure. Per report from the ED all 
lines and interventions were done without sedation. No family 
member per the ED resident was with the patient. On repeat scan 
in the ED he was noted to have uncle herniation and diffuse 
swelling of the drain with lost of the grey white matter. 
Neurosurgey was consulted who said no neurosurgical 
intervention. 

On arrival to the MICU,  the patient is non-responsive with 
painful stimuli. His SBP was in the ___ with a thready pulse. 

Review of systems:  
Unable to obtain due to patient being unresponsive 

 
Past Medical History:
Unable to obtain due to patient being unresponsive 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Unable to obtain due to patient being unresponsive 

 
Physical Exam:
Admission Exam:
Vitals: T:32.8 C (activly being cooled)  BP:72/40  P:86  
Intubated on Assit Contol ventilation with rate of 22, sats of 
100% on 50% FiO2.   
General- Intubated and unresponsive not on sedation  
HEENT- Edemadous boggy scleara, left eye blown and fixed, right 
eye 6mm and non-responsive, Sclera anicteric, MMM  
Neck- supple, unable to further assess 
Lungs- Difuse ronchi bilaterally   
CV- RRR, no murmurs, or gallops  
Abdomen- soft, unable to assess tenderness, +BS, no rebound 
tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
GU- foley  
Ext- warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema  
Neuro- non-responsive.   left eye blown and fixed, right eye 6mm 
and non-responsive

Death Exam:
No pulse, no respirations, no heart sounds. Pupils fixed and 
non-reactive. 
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
___ 01:23PM BLOOD WBC-19.0* RBC-4.06* Hgb-12.2* Hct-38.4* 
MCV-95 MCH-30.2 MCHC-31.9 RDW-14.0 Plt ___
___ 01:23PM BLOOD ___ PTT-40.4* ___
___ 01:23PM BLOOD Glucose-564* UreaN-36* Creat-2.6* Na-136 
K-3.3 Cl-100 HCO3-12* AnGap-27*
___ 05:45PM BLOOD ALT-693* AST-1169* LD(LDH)-___* 
CK(CPK)-6553* AlkPhos-191* TotBili-0.9
___ 01:23PM BLOOD cTropnT-3.48*
___ 05:45PM BLOOD CK-MB-365* MB Indx-5.6 cTropnT-6.42*
___ 01:23PM BLOOD Albumin-3.1* Calcium-8.5 Phos-7.5* 
Mg-2.8*
___ 01:16PM BLOOD Type-ART pO2-102 pCO2-56* pH-6.89* 
calTCO2-12* Base XS--24
___ 06:04PM BLOOD Type-ART ___ Tidal V-500 PEEP-5 
FiO2-60 pO2-76* pCO2-42 pH-6.94* calTCO2-10* Base XS--24 
Intubat-INTUBATED
___ 01:16PM BLOOD Lactate-12.6*
___ 06:04PM BLOOD Lactate-11.5*

Imaging:
Head CT:
There is diffuse cerebral edema with loss of gray-white 
differentiation.  
There is effacement of the sulci. There is effacement of the 
lateral 
ventricles, basal cisterns and downward tonsillar herniation. 
There is 
increased density in the basilar cisterns likely related to 
diffuse cerebral edema. 
There is a possible fracture of the left medial orbital wall.  
There is 
opacification of the bilateral ethmoid air cells and mucosal 
thickening of the bilateral sphenoid sinuses and right maxillary 
sinus.  The frontal sinuses and mastoid air cells are clear. 
IMPRESSION: 
Diffuse cerebral edema with loss of gray-white differentiation 
and uncal and downward tonsillar herniation. 

CXR: 
Portable AP chest radiograph. The ETT now terminates 3.2 cm 
above the carina. Lung volumes are very low with low with 
bibasilar atelectasis.  
There is no pneumothorax. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with asystole -> PEA arrest with ROSC p/w cerebral edema and 
herniation.

#Cardiac Arrest/Brain Herniation: The patient was found down in 
the field and resusicated and had return of circulation after 39 
minutues from the time of EMS arrival on the scene. He was 
unresponsive and was placed on blood pressure support. His 
troponin was elevated, indicating a likely cardiac source for 
his arrest. He had a head CT that was notable for severe 
cerebral edema at the outside hospital. He was transfered to 
___ for further care. Here he required increased blood 
pressure support and was ultimatly on maximum dose of 3 
medications to raise blood pressure. He was unresponsive to 
painful stimuli. He was noted to have a left pupil that was 
fixed and dialated. He underwent repeat Head CT that was notable 
for severe cerebral edema with efacement of the grey/white 
matter and both tonsilar and uncal herniation. Neurosurgery was 
consulted who did not believe that any surgical or medical 
intervention would be successful in return of any type brain 
function. Given these findings multiple family meetings were had 
to explain the prognosis and that he would not improve. 
Following the family discussions the family decided to make the 
patient CMO and the pressors were stopped and he was extubated. 
The patient quickly passed and was pronounced dead at 2240. The 
family was informed and autopsy was declined. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Unable to obtain due to patient being unresponsive 

 
Discharge Medications:
Expired
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Expired s/p cardiac arrest.

 
Discharge Condition:
Expired

 
Discharge Instructions:
Admitted s/p arrest. Found to have cerebral edema and 
herniation. INitally on max support, but following prognosis 
discussion with the family made CMO and passed away with the 
family at his side. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Intubated on Assit Contol ventilation with rate of 22, sats of
100% on 50% FiO2.

eye 6mm and non-responsive, Sclera anicteric, MMM
Neck- supple, unable to further assess

tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly

edema

and non-responsive

non-reactive.

Imaging:
Head CT:
There is diffuse cerebral edema with loss of gray-white
differentiation.
There is effacement of the sulci. There is effacement of the
lateral
ventricles, basal cisterns and downward tonsillar herniation.
There is
increased density in the basilar cisterns likely related to
diffuse cerebral edema.
There is a possible fracture of the left medial orbital wall.
There is
opacification of the bilateral ethmoid air cells and mucosal
thickening of the bilateral sphenoid sinuses and right maxillary
sinus. The frontal sinuses and mastoid air cells are clear.
IMPRESSION:
Diffuse cerebral edema with loss of gray-white differentiation
and uncal and downward tonsillar herniation.
CXR:
Portable AP chest radiograph. The ETT now terminates 3.2 cm
above the carina. Lung volumes are very low with low with
bibasilar atelectasis.
There is no pneumothorax.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with asystole -> PEA arrest with ROSC p/w cerebral edema and
herniation.
#Cardiac Arrest/Brain Herniation: The patient was found down in
the field and resusicated and had return of circulation after 39
minutues from the time of EMS arrival on the scene. He was
unresponsive and was placed on blood pressure support. His
troponin was elevated, indicating a likely cardiac source for
his arrest. He had a head CT that was notable for severe
cerebral edema at the outside hospital. He was transfered to
___ for further care. Here he required increased blood
pressure support and was ultimatly on maximum dose of 3
medications to raise blood pressure. He was unresponsive to
painful stimuli. He was noted to have a left pupil that was
fixed and dialated. He underwent repeat Head CT that was notable
for severe cerebral edema with efacement of the grey/white
matter and both tonsilar and uncal herniation. Neurosurgery was
consulted who did not believe that any surgical or medical
intervention would be successful in return of any type brain
function. Given these findings multiple family meetings were had
to explain the prognosis and that he would not improve.
Following the family discussions the family decided to make the
patient CMO and the pressors were stopped and he was extubated.
The patient quickly passed and was pronounced dead at 2240. The
family was informed and autopsy was declined.
Medications on Admission:
Unable to obtain due to patient being unresponsive
Discharge Medications:
Expired
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
Discharge Diagnosis:
Expired s/p cardiac arrest.
Discharge Condition:
Expired
Discharge Instructions:
Admitted s/p arrest. Found to have cerebral edema and
herniation. INitally on max support, but following prognosis
discussion with the family made CMO and passed away with the
family at his side.
Followup Instructions:
___

as needed for constipation.

Capsule PO DAILY (Daily) for 2 days: Please take as directed for

Disp:*6 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

a day).  
11. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO TID (3 times 
a day) as needed for pain.

Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
small traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage
left periorbital swelling
c4-c7 mal-alignment

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the acute care surgery service on ___ 
for injuries sustained from a fall down a flight of stairs. Your 
CT scan showed C4-C7 malalignment. You also had facial swelling 
and bruising, as well as a small subarachnoid hemorrhage. You 
are improving daily and should continue to do so. You are being 
transferred to rehab for continuous support and therapy.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day,  Please also follow-up with your primary care physician.

* If you develop any increased pain, numbness or tingling or any 
other symptoms that concern you please call your doctor or 
return to the Emergency Room.

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Calcium Channel Blocking Agent Diltiazem Analogues
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Stroke
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yr F w/ hx of ESRD on HD, HTN, DMII, and prior stroke in 
___ w/ residual mild aphasia who was transferred from OSH due 
to new onset R sided weakness and profound aphasia concerning 
for stroke. Exam is consistent with a L MCA syndrome w/ pt seen
to have severe expressive aphasia, L gaze preference, and R 
sided weakness. NIHSS at OSH was 22, tPA was given at OSH at 
___ on ___. NIHSS on ___ was 18. Etiology could potentially 
cardioembolic, given recurrent stroke and proximal vasculature
appearing clear on affected side. Her 24 hour head CT showed 
large L MCA
infarct, with no hemorrhage. Based on the CTA would not have 
expected the entire territory to infarct, as she had what 
appeared to be relatively good distal reconstitution. She has a 
fetal PCA on the L and appeared to be supplying her MCA from 
there. Her infarct is quite large now, affecting both the 
cortical motor areas and subcortical fibers and would expect 
that she remain hemiplegic on the R. She exam developed into a 
global aphasia and hemiplegia on the R. Goals of care were 
discussed with family, and she was made comfort measures only. 
She passed away ___ at 7:07am. 

#ESRD - she received HD while she was here, renal was consulted 
for management. Per family request, this was discontinued when 
goals were shifted to comfort measures only.

#yeast in peritoneal fluid - yeast grew in peritoneal fluid 
culture from ___. She was started on fluconazole, ID was 
consulted. This was discontinued after she was made CMO

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
2. coenzyme Q10 100 mg oral DAILY 
3. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO DAILY 
4. Furosemide 40 mg PO DAILY 
5. glimepiride 1 mg oral BID 
6. HydrALAZINE 50 mg PO BID 
7. Labetalol 600 mg PO BID 
8. NIFEdipine (Extended Release) 60 mg PO BID 
9. Sodium Bicarbonate 650 mg PO DAILY 
10. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 
11. CloNIDine 0.1 mg PO DAILY 
12. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY

Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Stroke
 
Discharge Condition:
Passed away
 
Discharge Instructions:
N/A

Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
r elbow pain 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
radial head replacement 

 
History of Present Illness:
HPI: ___ male with history of cocaine use presents with the above
fracture s/p mechanical fall.  Patient states that on ___ he was
riding a bike through an intersection when he was struck by an
oncoming car.  He was initially evaluated at OSH and found to
have a right radial head and neck fracture as well as nasal bone
fracture.  Patient was discharged home in splint and told to
follow-up as an outpatient but he had continued pain and
presented to ___ today where he had repeat imaging done
that was read as consistent with ___ fracture.  He 
was
evaluated by orthopedics who referred him to ___ for
orthopedics evaluation.
 
Past Medical History:
Substance abuse - cocaine  
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
___
 
Physical Exam:
General: comfortable
MSK RUE: in splint. Motor/Sensory intact to median, ulnar, 
radial distributions. 2+ radial pulse. Soft compartments. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Hospitalization Summary (ED Admit)
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have radial head fracture and was admitted to the orthopedic 
surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on 
___ for radial head replacement, which the patient tolerated 
well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked 
with ___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. 
The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
NWB in the RUE extremity, and will be discharged on aspirin for 
DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ 
routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient 
regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course 
including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, 
and all questions were answered. The patient was also given 
written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and 
the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness 
for discharge.

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild 
RX *acetaminophen [8 HOUR PAIN RELIEVER] 650 mg 1 tablet(s) by 
mouth every 8 hours Disp #*100 Tablet Refills:*1 
2.  Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY vte prophylaxis 
RX *aspirin 325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every day Disp #*28 
Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
This is a new medication to prevent constipation. please hold 
for loose stools. 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 2 capsule(s) by mouth twice per day 
Disp #*80 Capsule Refills:*0

Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow

at discharge.

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

Chief Complaint:
Pelvic bleeding, altered mental status
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None.

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ woman with hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, osteoporosis, dementia, "slow" leukemia, 
possible prolapsed uterus who was sent from nursing home with 
report of vaginal bleeding for two days because employees found 
blood on pad of her bed. The volume and source of the blood are 
both uncertain. In addition, the patient experienced some nausea 
and vomiting. The patient's mental status is poor at baseline, 
but she is usually more conversant and now more withdrawn.
.
In the ED, initial VS were T 97.3F 70 82/44 14 96% RA.  She 
underwent gynecological evaluation. Gyn could not definitively 
rule out uterine prolapse, but who felt that patient more than 
likely had urethral prolapse. No vaginal bleeding (or any 
bleeding) on exam - can only tolerate one finger digital exam, 
but no blood on diaper or glove. Suspect bleeding was from 
irritation of urethral prolapse. Endometrial stripe 3mm on 
ultrasound (normal). No acute gyn issue.
.
Overall, no GYN intervention was needed, and given her 
leukocytosis and hypotension, admission to medicine was 
recommended. Labs were notable for floridly positive UA, Cr 1.7, 
WBC of 27K (1 band, 32% PMNs, rest Lymphs), HCT of 30, platelets 
of 88K, Lactate was 1.1. While in the ED, pt. received CFTX 1g 
IV, 2L NS, with which BP improved to 98/51. PIV x2 was reported 
at time of transfer. 
 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
"Slow" leukemia
Possible prolapsed uterus
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory

boutonierre deformity of most distal phalanges.

.

IMPRESSION:

2. Suboptimally evaluated adnexa due to positioning.
.
___ CXR: IMPRESSION: No evidence of pneumonia.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ woman with hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, osteoporosis, dementia, "slow" leukemia, 
possible prolapsed uterus, who is presenting with altered mental 
status, some possible pelvic bleeding, and a urinalysis 
suggestive of urinary tract infection.
.
# Urinary tract infection:  Patient's urinalysis positive for 
bacteria, nitrites, and had > 200 WBCs. UTI leading to sepsis 
may be responsible for hypotension on arrival to Emergency 
Department, as well as altered mental status (although patient 
may well be at baseline). Urine and blood cultures showed no 
growth. Patient was afebrile durign hospitalization. High WBCs 
complicated by patient's leukemia, though the patient did not 
have bandemia. The patient was started on ciprofloxacin, for 
which she should complete a seven-day course.
.
# Possible GI bleed/uterine or urethral prolapse/anemia: The 
source of blood on patient's bed pads is unclear. ___ have been 
secondary to urethral or uterus prolapse, though in either case, 
Gynecology felt there was no need for intervention. ___ also be 
rectal bleed, though stool guaiacs were negative. Patient may 
also be losing blood via vomiting. Anemia further complicated by 
patient's blood dyscrasia. Patient's hematocrit was stable. The 
source of blood was likely uterine or urethral.
.
# Dementia: Continued donepezil therapy.
.
# Hypertension: Held home anti-hypertensives in setting of 
episode of hypotension upon arrival at ___ ED. Patient was 
normotensive during hospitalization.
.
# Osteoporosis: Continued weekly alendronate.
.
# Hyperlipidemia: Continued home Crestor. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Crestor 10mg daily
Alendronate 70mg Qwed
Donepezil 10mg daily
Fe 325mg daily
HCTZ 12.5mg daily
Lisinopril 20mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. rosuvastatin 5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
2. alendronate 70 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QWED (every 
___.  
3. donepezil 5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime). 
 
4. ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q24H 
(every 24 hours) for 5 days.
Disp:*5 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. ferrous sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO once a day.  
6. hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO 
once a day.  
7. lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Urinary tract infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,
.
It was a pleasure participating in your care at ___ 
___ ___.
.
You were admitted to the hospital because you had a urinary 
tract infection. The infection may have made you confused as 
well. You have been treated with antibiotics, which you will 
continue to take once you go home. Please complete the entire 
course of antibiotic medication (ciprofloxacin) even if you feel 
better.
.
You also had some bleeding, perhaps from your prolapsed uterus 
or prolapsed urethra. We followed your blood counts to make sure 
you were not losing blood quickly. Your blood counts remained 
stable, so we do not think you have an active bleed.
.
Please START ciprofloxacin.
Otherwise, keep taking your medications as you have been taking 
them.
.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
syncope
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
N/A
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ PMHx anxiety, depression, and prior 
history of ?tumor of the jaw who presents with a syncopal 
episode.

He reports that yesterday evening, he was talking to his 
girlfriend on the phone when she had sudden LOC without any 
preceding symptoms or warning.  The next thing he remembers was 
waking up being surrounded by EMS staff, his girlfriend and his 
son.  Per EMS report, the patient was found initially 
unresponsive and responded to 4 mg of Narcan leading to 
suspicion of possible overdose.  Upon arousal, the patient had 
immediate return to his mental baseline.  He denies any drug use 
or alcohol use and states that he had been in his USOH leading 
up to this syncopal episode.  He does report feeling very upset 
while talking to his girlfriend given recently finding out from 
his dentist that he may need to have all of his teeth of his 
lower jaw removed due to concern of significant dental 
abscess/recurrent tumor (all of his upper teeth were removed in 
his teens because of tumor growth). 

He reports that he had a similar episode ___ years ago where he 
had sudden LOC without prodrome and again awoke following Narcan 
administration.

He reports that his ___ son recently had a pacemaker placed for 
some sort of arrhythmia after a syncopal episode.  He does not 
know what his son's actual medical history is, but states that 
he himself has no known prior cardiac history.  

Upon arrival in the ED, initial VS 98, ___, 18, 97% on 
RA.  Initial labs showed wnl chemistries, negative serum and 
urine tox screens, WBC 11.1, Hgb 15.0, Plt 199, troponins x 2 
were negative.  CXR showed RLL PNA. ECHO showed low normal LVEF 
of 50% but was otherwise unremarkable.  While in the ED, he 
developed substernal chest pain for which Cardiology was 
consulted.  His EKG showed TWI in the precordial leads and 
borderline LVH.  His chest pain was felt to be atypical and was 
reproducible on exam with palpation.  Inaptient admission for 
further monitoring on telemetry was recommended.

Upon arrival to the floor, the patient denies any current chest 
pain and otherwise feels well.  He states feeling rather anxious 
and frustrated by the recent news from his dentist that he may 
have to have all of his lower dental teeth removed.  No other 
acute medical complaints.  He denies any fevers/cough/ns, but 
states feeling dyspneic earlier.  
 
Review of Systems:  
(+) per HPI  
(-) fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision changes, 
rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, 
chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria.  
 

 
Past Medical History:
anxiety/depression
?tumor of upper jaw
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
___ son with PPM following syncopal episode.  Also states that 
heart disease of some sort runs in the family.
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals-  98.5 144 / ___ 96 RA 
GENERAL: well-appearing middle-aged male in NAD
HEENT: MMM, NCAT, EOMI, anicteric sclera
CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate, no murmurs/rubs/gallops.  
No JVD.
LUNGS: CTAB, no w/r/r, unlabored respirations
ABDOMEN:  Normal bowels sounds, non distended, non-tender to 
deep palpation in all four quadrants. + bowel sounds
EXTREMITIES: wwp, no edema of BLE
SKIN: multiple tattoos 
NEUROLOGIC: AOx3, grossly nonofocal, wnl gait
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:40PM   cTropnT-<0.01
___ 10:40PM   ASA-NEG ETHANOL-NEG ACETMNPHN-NEG 
bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG
___ 10:40PM   WBC-11.1* RBC-5.37 HGB-15.0 HCT-46.0 MCV-86 
MCH-27.9 MCHC-32.6 RDW-14.0 RDWSD-43.8
___ 10:40PM   NEUTS-75.0* LYMPHS-15.3* MONOS-7.9 EOS-0.4* 
BASOS-0.5 IM ___ AbsNeut-8.31* AbsLymp-1.70 AbsMono-0.87* 
AbsEos-0.04 AbsBaso-0.06
___ 10:40PM   PLT COUNT-199

Imaging/Studies:  
___ CXR
Right lower lobe consolidation, potentially infection or 
aspiration.

___ ECHO
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is 
seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure 
is ___ mmHg. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The 
left ventricular cavity is mildly dilated. Regional left 
ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is low normal (LVEF = 50%). Tissue Doppler 
imaging suggests a normal left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and 
no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery 
systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no 
pericardial effusion.  

EKG:  
___ NSR with TWI in the precordial leads, borderline LVH

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ PMHx anxiety, depression, and prior 
history of ?tumor of the jaw who presents with a syncopal 
episode.

# Syncope.  No associated prodrome concerning for possible 
cardiogenic etiology of his syncopal episode.  He has a 
concerning family history of possible arrhythmia.  His EKG is 
overall unremarkable and there is no concern for acute ischemia 
at this time.  His ECHO shows no significant structural heart 
disease.  He does have some atypical chest pain which was 
reproducible on exam, therefore c/w MSK, so per Cardiology, OK 
to defer stress testing at this time.  His syncopal episode was 
initially felt to be related to overdose; however, the patient 
denies any increased ingestion of his klonopin or home meds.  
Serum/urine tox are also both negative. Orthostatics normal. No 
events on telemetry for 24 hours. Per Cardiology recommendations 
patient will be discharged with ___ of Hearts" monitoring 
system and will follow-up in Cardiology fellows clinic with Dr. 
___. 

# Atypical chest pain.  Likely MSK given reproducible in exam.  
Per cards, no need for stress testing at this time.  EKG and 
cardiac biomarkers without obvious evidence of acute ischemia. 
Resolved on discharge. 

# PNA.  RLL opacity seen on CXR. No preceeding fevers, cough, 
dyspnea, sputum. No fevers or leukocytosis on discharge. 
Received 1 dose of levaquin in house but was not discharged on 
antibiotics. 

# Anxiety/depression.
-Can resume gabaepentin/klonipin but counseled on sedating 
nature of these medications. 

# ?dental abscess vs recurrent tumor.
- Continue outpatient work-up

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. Gabapentin 800 mg PO BID 
2. ClonazePAM 1 mg PO BID 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  ClonazePAM 1 mg PO BID  
2.  Gabapentin 800 mg PO BID  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Syncope 

 
Discharge Condition:
Good Condition
Fully Ambulatory
Fully Oriented and Alert

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___ you were admitted to the hospital with syncope 
(fainting). We were unable to identify a definite reason why you 
fainted. We recommend eating and drinking well when you leave 
the hospital. In addition you will go to ___ ___ floor on 
the ___ of ___ to obtain information for a heart 
monitor called ___ of Hearts." Please avoid using more than 
the recommended amount of gabapentin or klonipin as these can be 
very sedating.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Dust & Pollen Filter Mask
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
l hip pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
L hip replacement

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o w/ progressive hip pain,who has elected to proceed with 
left hip replacement.
 
Past Medical History:
htn
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Well appearing in no acute distress
Afebrile with stable vital signs
Pain well-controlled

Respiratory: CTAB
Cardiovascular: RRR
Gastrointestinal: NT/ND
Genitourinary: Voiding independently

Neurologic: Intact with no focal deficits
Psychiatric: Pleasant, A&O x3

Musculoskeletal Lower Extremity:

 *   Incision healing well with staples
 *   Scant serosanguinous drainage
 *   Thigh full but soft
 *   No calf tenderness
 *   ___ strength ___
 *   SILT DP/SP/T/S/S
 *   Toes warm

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD#1 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.  

At time of discharge, patient was deemed stable for safe 
discharge to rehab. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior hip 
precautions.
 
Medications on Admission:
___, 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
DAILY (Daily) for 3 weeks.
Disp:*21 * Refills:*0*
2. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) for 3 weeks.
Disp:*21 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Aspirin, Buffered 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice 
a day for 3 weeks.
Disp:*42 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Valsartan 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  


 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___ 
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L THA

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool
softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.
6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at least 
four weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues to be 
non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be removed 
will be taken out by the visiting nurse or rehab facility two 
weeks after your surgery.
7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in four weeks.
8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).
9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for three weeks 
to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  After 
completing the lovenox, please take Aspirin 325mg  TWICE  daily 
for an additional three weeks.
10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four week 
checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each 
day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check 
wound regularly for
signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
Staples will be removed by the visiting nurse or rehab facility 
in two weeks.
11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
surgery.
12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity.  No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow 
up appointment.

Physical Therapy:
wbat lle
post hip precautions

Treatments Frequency:
dressing changes as needed daily
DSD
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history hypertension who 
presents with complaints of hypertension. Patient just moved 
here from ___ 2 days ago. He states that he took 
his blood pressure at home which was high (SBP 180s) and he had 
some mild dizziness, he ran out of labetalol which he typically 
takes when his BP is high and came to the ED as he doesn't have 
a PCP or cardiologist. Patient is prescribed 3 blood pressure 
medications about ___ years ago when he was admitted to a hospital 
for his ankle fracture, including Labetalol 200mg and captopril 
25mg, and one other which he does not know. Prior to that he was 
taking lisinopril. He typically only takes his labetalol when he 
doesn't feel well. Does not take his medications regularly.

baseline).

Borderline heart size. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history hypertension who 
presents with complaints of hypertension of SBP to 190 on home 
monitor.  
# Hypertension: Patient with history of hypertension dx one year 
ago, not adherent with medications due to cost. Although patient 
was prescribed Labetolol 200mg BID, Captopril 25mg BID and 
Nifedipine 60mg BID, he was not taking them except for when he 
felt sick. We did not restart his Acei due to bump in creatinine 
(unclear if chronic). At OSH ___ in ___) renal u/s was 
completed and negative for RAS. His BP on admission was 190/142 
and down trended to 140s-150/90s-110 the day of discharge. He 
felt a bit dizzy prior to admission and did not recur during 
admission. He was initially placed on labetolol 200mg BID, which 
was titrated up to 300mg BID and amlodipine 10mg daily. 
Hydralazine 10mg po TID was added with some effect and increased 
to 20mg TID. There was a large component of patient stressors 
(pending divorce/annulment of marriage) which may have been 
worsening patient's BP. On discharge, he was increased to 25 
Hydralazine TID and started on Atenolol 25 daily due to cost of 
medications (___ 4$). Patient vocalized that he would not be 
able to afford medications unless cheap, which is why the above 
regimen was chosen.  
-cont low sodium diet
-close f/u with new PCP, titrate up medications. 
-needs insurance, f/u with ___ clinic to get signed up.
-Consider starting ACEi if CR stable 

# ___ vs. CKD: Unknown baseline. Risk factors include 
hypertension. Creatinine was 1.4 on admission, increased to 1.6 
the night of admission and came back down to 1.4 on discharge. 
His UA was postive for protein at 30mg/dL (microalbuminemia).   
- f/u BMP, UA, Microalbumin within 2 weeks.   
- ACEi if Cr stable
 
# Code: Full Code  
# Communication: Patient  
# Emergency Contact: ___ (cousin) ___  

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Labetalol 200 mg PO BID
2. Captopril 25 mg PO BID 
3. Nifedipine 60mg PO BID
 
Discharge Medications:
1. HydrALAzine 20 mg PO Q8H 
RX *hydralazine 25 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Three times daily 
Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*4
2. Atenolol 50 mg PO DAILY 
RX *atenolol 50 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*4

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hypertension, essential

 
Discharge Condition:
AAOx3
Ambulating w/o assistance. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were at ___. 
You were admitted for high blood pressure. You were started on 
medications to help control your blood pressure. It is important 
that you continue taking these medications every day to help 
protect your body from further damage. Your kidneys were found 
to be damaged from the high blood pressure and will likely 
improve in function if your blood pressure stays in better 
control. It is very important to keep taking your medications to 
keep your blood pressure less than 140/90. Check your blood 
pressure every morning. If your blood pressure is repeatedly 
above 140/90, please call your primary care physician. If it is 
less than 100/60, hold a dose of medications and call your 
primary care physician. 
-Follow-up with your primary care physician ___ ___ weeks
-Get a follow-up blood test to check on your kidney function
-Take your medications regularly (Atenolol 50mg daily and 
Hydralazine 25mg three times daily - breakfast, lunch, dinner). 

Thank you and take care. 

Sincerely, 

Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

2. Captopril 25 mg PO BID
3. Nifedipine 60mg PO BID
Discharge Medications:
1. HydrALAzine 20 mg PO Q8H
RX *hydralazine 25 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Three times daily
Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*4
2. Atenolol 50 mg PO DAILY
RX *atenolol 50 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily Disp #*30 Tablet
Refills:*4
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hypertension, essential
Discharge Condition:
AAOx3
Ambulating w/o assistance.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were at ___.
You were admitted for high blood pressure. You were started on
medications to help control your blood pressure. It is important
that you continue taking these medications every day to help
protect your body from further damage. Your kidneys were found
to be damaged from the high blood pressure and will likely
improve in function if your blood pressure stays in better
control. It is very important to keep taking your medications to
keep your blood pressure less than 140/90. Check your blood
pressure every morning. If your blood pressure is repeatedly
above 140/90, please call your primary care physician. If it is
less than 100/60, hold a dose of medications and call your
primary care physician.
-Follow-up with your primary care physician ___ ___ weeks
-Get a follow-up blood test to check on your kidney function
-Take your medications regularly (Atenolol 50mg daily and
Hydralazine 25mg three times daily - breakfast, lunch, dinner).
Thank you and take care.
Sincerely,
Your ___ Team
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain/left shoulder pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ splenectomy 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old male who is currently incarcerated reports he was 
"wrestling with cellmate" and complained of abdominal/L shoulder 
pain.  He was evaluated at an outside hospital and found to have 
hemoperitoneum and a splenic laceration.  He was transferred to 
___ ED for further care.  He was hemodynamically stable on 
arrival with mild abdominal distention and diffusely tender 
abdomen.  Based on clinical exam, a grossly positive FAST 
examination in the ED and review of the images revealing the 
massive hemoperitoneum with a grade 3 splenic laceration at the 
hilum with evidence of extravasation, the patient was taken for 
an emergency splenectomy. Dr. ___ the ___ 
___ was notified of the patient's condition 
and plan of treatment.
 
Past Medical History:
hepatitis C (per patient-not in jail records)
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non contributory
 
Physical Exam:
afebrile, VSS
NAD
RRR, CTAB
abd: incision c/d/i, soft, NT/minimally distended, +BS
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:11AM BLOOD WBC-17.0* RBC-3.57* Hgb-10.8* Hct-30.3* 
MCV-85 MCH-30.2 MCHC-35.6* RDW-12.5 Plt ___
___ 09:11AM BLOOD ___ PTT-25.7 ___
___ 05:30AM BLOOD WBC-19.3* RBC-3.08* Hgb-9.4* Hct-27.4* 
MCV-89 MCH-30.5 MCHC-34.4 RDW-13.1 Plt ___
___ 05:30AM BLOOD Glucose-87 UreaN-12 Creat-0.6 Na-139 
K-3.8 Cl-101 ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was taken to the operating room for an emergency 
splenectomy.  He tolerated the procedure well, was transferred 
to the PACU and later to the floor.  He received Pneumovax, 
haemophilus B and menigococcus vaccines in the PACU.  He 
continued to do well and his hematocrit remained stable post 
operatively.  His pain was managed with a Dilaudid PCA which was 
transitioned to oral pain medications on post operative day 2 
(___).  He had urinary retention after removal of the foley 
catheter which necessitated replacement of the foley catheter.  
It was removed again on ___ and he was voiding normally.  His 
pain was well controlled with oral pain medications and he was 
ambulating and tolerating a regular diet.  He was determined to 
be stable for discharge on ___.  
He will follow up on ___ for staple removal and wound 
check with Dr. ___ in Trauma clinic.   A hepatitis C panel was 
still pending at time of discharge, results can be obtained at 
follow up appointment.  
 
Medications on Admission:
Celexa
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) for 2 weeks.  
3. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for pain for 1 weeks.  
4. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every 
eight (8) hours as needed for pain for 1 weeks.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
splenic laceration

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Keep the incision clean and dry.  You may shower, pat incision 
dry.  

Avoid heavy lifting >10lbs and strenuous activity for 6 weeks.  

A hepatitis C panel was checked during your hospitalization and 
the results were not back at the time of discharge.  Results can 
be obtained at your follow up appointment.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

You came to ___ because you were not feeling well and had a 
fever. You were found to have a pneumonia. Please see more 
details listed below about what happened while you were in the 
hospital and your instructions for what to do after leaving the 
hospital.

It was a pleasure participating in your care. We wish you the 
best! 

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

WHAT WAS DONE WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL:
- You were given antibiotics
- You had low blood counts as well, which is not typical for 
pneumonia. Therefore several tests were sent for other 
infections
- Most of the infection studies were normal, except for one test 
for mononucleosis (AKA mono). Other tests were sent to confirm 
this.
- You improved considerably and were ready to leave the hospital

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL:
- Please follow up with your primary care doctor 
- Please take all of your medications as prescribed (see below).
- Until your tests come back, you should avoid sexual contact 
including kissing and also avoid contact sports
- Seek medical attention if you have fever, worsening cough or 
other symptoms of concern.

History of Present Illness:
___ year old male with history of intermittent chronic watery 
diarrhea who presents with one week of worsening watery 
diarrhea, subjective fevers, LLQ pain. He has also had some 
intermittent nausea/emesis. He also reports joint pains 
particularly in knees, ankles, elbows and some mild low back 
pain. Reports some intentional weight loss over past year. 
Denies cough, SOB, CP, palpitations, rashes or skin lesions. 
Denies frank blood in BMs or black tarry BMs. Notes some blurry 
vision although states this occurs when he does not wear his 
glasses.  No recent travel or camping. No strange or new foods.

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
fall with headstrike

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo F no significant PMH who suffered a trip and fall
today.  She tripped on a curb, fell back and hit her head.  No
LOC. She was taken to OSH where head CT showed bifrontal
contusions and so she was transferred to ___ for further
evaluation.  She denies HA, numbness, weakness, nausea, 
vomiting,
diarrhea.

 
Past Medical History:
none

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
On Admission:
O: T:97.8  BP:150/75   HR:98   R:18    O2Sats98% RA
Gen: WD/WN, comfortable, NAD.
HEENT: ___ laceration near occiput.
Neck: Supple. No pain to palpation

Extrem: Warm and well-perfused.
Neuro:
Mental status: Awake and alert, cooperative with exam, normal
affect.
Orientation: Oriented to person and place, and year (not month
ititially, required reorientation)
Language: Speech fluent with good comprehension and repetition.
Naming intact. No dysarthria or paraphasic errors.

Cranial Nerves:
I: Not tested
II: Pupils equally round and reactive 3 to 2
mm bilaterally. Visual fields unable to test.
III, IV, VI: Extraocular movements intact bilaterally without
nystagmus.
V, VII: Facial strength and sensation intact and symmetric.
VIII: Hearing intact to voice.
IX, X: Palatal elevation symmetrical.
XI: Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius normal bilaterally.
XII: Tongue midline without fasciculations.

Motor: Normal bulk and tone bilaterally. No abnormal movements,
tremors. Strength full power ___ throughout. No pronator drift

Sensation: Intact to light touch bilaterally.

On Discharge:
A&Ox3
PERRL
EOMs intact
Motor: ___ throughout

 
Pertinent Results:
CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST ___ 
1.  Mild intrahepatic biliary duct dilation and pneumobilia is 
likely related to the prior cholecystectomy.  The distal common 
bile duct measures 8 mm. 
  
2.  Multiple bilateral renal hypodensities most likely represent 
hemorrhagic cysts; however, confirmation with renal ultrasound 
could be obtained if clinically indicated. 
  
3.  Normal-appearing appendix. 
  
4.  Pancolonic diverticulosis without evidence of acute 
diverticulitis. 
  
5.  Multilevel degenerative changes, most prominent in the lower 
lumbar spine. 
  
6.  Calcified pleural plaques, likely related to prior asbestos 
exposure. 

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST ___
1.  Small foci of subarachnoid hemorrhage in the right frontal 
lobe.  
Additional 4-mm hyperdensity concerning for additional site of 
acute 
intracranial hemorrhage along the right cerebellum.  
  
2.  Enlarged ventricles are of undetermined age and could 
represent 
hydrocephalus or ventriculomegaly.  
  
2.  Right occipital fracture does not extend into the foramen 
magnum or 
occipital condyle. 
  
3.  Small right posterior subgaleal hematoma. 

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST ___ 
1. Stable small right frontal subarachnoid hemorrhage without 
associated mass effect or shift of midline structures. No 
central herniation. 
  
2. Enlarged ventricles, as before, may represent age-related 
central atrophy or communicating hydrocephalus in the proper 
clinical setting. 
  
3. Stable 4 mm hemorrhagic contusion in the posterior aspect of 
the right 
cerebellar hemisphere, along the course of the right occipital 
fracture. Close attention on follow-up imaging is recommended. 
  
4. Stable small right occipital scalp subgaleal hematoma. 
  
5.  Fracture of the right lateral aspect of the occipital bone, 
which does not extend into the foramen magnum or occipital 
condyle. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o F s/p fall striking her head presents with head CT 
revealed bifrontal SAH and R occipital fracture. She was alert 
to self and place, reoriented and able to get the date after 
prompting with full strength and admitted to the neurosurgical 
service for close monitoring. On ___, patient was stable on 
exam. Repeat head CT showed stable hemorrhage. ___ was consulted 
and recommended rehab. On ___, patient was stable on examination 
and was discharged to rehab in stable condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
aspirin 81mg QD
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Bifrontal SAH/contusion
R occipital skull fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
 Take your pain medicine as prescribed.

¨     Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, 
straining, or excessive bending.

¨     Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.

¨     Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, or 
Ibuprofen etc. 

¨     If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), 
or Plavix (clopidogrel), or Aspirin prior to your injury, you 
may safely resume taking this in 1 week.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

 

¨     New onset of tremors or seizures.

¨     Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status. 

¨     Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.

¨     Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.

¨     New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function 
on one whole side of your body.

 

 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

¨ Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
¨ Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not
relieved by pain medication.
¨ New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function
on one whole side of your body.
