___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
shortness of breath
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with h/o pulm fibrosis who has felt SOB w/ exertion 
beginning about 2 weeks ago and worsening over the past week. 
Mr. ___ reports that he recently noticed that he occasionally 
becomes SOB with climbing 8 stairs, when he could previously 
climb the entire flight without difficulty. He has also noted 
SOB while walking on flat surfaces but denies any difficulty 
while at rest. The patient denies any CP, fatigue, edema, pnd, 
orthopnea, dizzyness, light headedness or pain with inspiration. 
Mrs. ___ wife noticed the difference in his breathing and 
encouraged him to visit his PCP. At the PCP's office, there was 
concern for CHF due to the SOB and he was started on 40mg PO 
Lasix. A CXR at that time was also performed which showed no 
evidence of CHF. He returned to his PCP today for follow up and 
was referred to the ED due to the persistent SOB.  
.  
In the ED, initial vs were: T98.3 HR 71 BP 142/49 RR 20 O2 100% 
on 2l, 88% on RA. CXR that was nl, BNP 373, CTA chest neg for 
PE, though it did show interval worsening of fibrosis since CT 
done ___. On 2L he is ___ and with exertion or removal of 
nasal cannula sats drop to the 80's.  
.  
On the floor, patient is breathing comfortably on 3L of O2. He 
has no complaints saying he feels fine.  
.  
Review of sytems:  
Reports weight loss since surgery and occasional mild non 
productive cough over the past 2 weeks. Denies fever, chills, 
night sweats, headache, rhinorrhea or congestion, nausea, 
vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent 
change in bowel or bladder habits.  

 
Past Medical History:
- back pain secondary to spinal stenosis: Recent surgery in ___  

- Pulmonary fibrosis, no medication  
- HTN  
- Hypercholesterolemia  
- Anxiety  
- MI during back surgery  
- PNA in ___  
- Hearing loss  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- Negative for lung disease  
- Mother died of MI 

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals:T:98.5 BP: 132/60 P:66 R:20 O2: 94 on 3l  
General: Very pleasant, alert, oriented, no acute distress.  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, PERRLA  
Neck: Supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD  
Lungs: Good aeration throughout, dry crackles heard in the L and 
R lung bases, no wheezes.  
CV: Distant heart sounds, regular rate and rhythm, no prominent 
murmurs appreciated; exam limited due to limited heart sounds.  
Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
GU: no foley  
Ext: Well perfused, feet a bit cold to touch, 2+ pulses, no 
clubbing, cyanosis or edema  
Neuro: Cranial nerves ___ intact, 5+ strength in upper and lowe 
extremieites bilaterally  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:50PM   PLT COUNT-262
___ 04:50PM   NEUTS-45.4* ___ MONOS-8.0 EOS-6.2* 
BASOS-0.5
___ 04:50PM   WBC-10.1 RBC-4.63 HGB-13.7* HCT-42.7 MCV-92 
MCH-29.5 MCHC-32.0 RDW-14.4
___ 04:50PM   proBNP-410
___ 04:50PM   UREA N-17 CREAT-1.3* SODIUM-139 POTASSIUM-4.0 
CHLORIDE-99
___ 11:09AM   CK-MB-NotDone cTropnT-<0.01 proBNP-373
___ 11:09AM   CK(CPK)-98
___ 11:13AM   LACTATE-3.0*
___ 12:31PM   LACTATE-2.7*

___ CTA:
1. No evidence of PE to the segmental level. 
  
2. Progression of diffuse subpleural and parenchymal 
interstitial lung 
disease. Review of prior exams between ___ and ___ 
demonstrates slow 
progression of lung disease with marked progression in the short 
interval 
between ___ and the current exam raising suspicion for 
superimposed 
component of volume overload. However, there are no additional 
specific 
findings supporting this or alternate diagnoses. 
  
3. Fatty liver. 

___ CXR: 
No evidence of congestive heart failure. No significant change 
from ___. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo man with a ___ year history of pulmonary 
fibrosis who presents with 2 weeks of progressive dyspnea on 
exertion.  
.  
# Dyspnea: Mr. ___ was admitted and placed on inhaled oxygen 
therapy. His clinical exam demonstrated dry crackles in 
bilateral lower lung fields L>R. He tolerated 3L of O2 well with 
adequate O2 saturations ranging from 92-94%. Both a CXR & CTA of 
the chest were without evidence of pulmonary edema or 
congestion, but the CTA did demonstrate progression of his known 
pulmonary fibrosis compared to prior CT in ___. Consequently, 
Mr. ___ presentation was thought to be due to progressive 
worsening of his ILD. However, a due to recent immobility ___ 
pain from a prior back surgery, he was ruled out for PE. He was 
also evaluated and ruled out for CHF exacerbation, with a BNP of 
373 and no clinical evidence of fluid overload, as well as 
infection with a normal WBC, CXR, and no evidence of 
consolidation or effusion on exam. After being monitoried 
overnight on telemetry without concerning morphology or clinical 
symptoms, Mr. ___ was discharge to home with 3L of continuous 
pulsed dose O2, and a plan to follow-up with his pulmonologist, 
Dr. ___ PFT's and further work-up.  
.  
# HTN: Mr. ___ maintained good blood pressure control on his 
home dose of Atenolol 100mg daily and Isosorbide mononitrate 
30mg daily throughout this admission.
.
# Hypercholesterolemia: Patient continued on home Lipitor 20mg 
PO daily.   
.
# Back pain: Patient had not active issues with his back pain, 
reporting that it was unchanged from baseline ___ pain. He 
continued to take his home Vicodin ___ tablets q6 prn.
.  
# History of MI: No active issues. Denies any CP at rest or w/ 
exertion. He continued his home Atenolol 100mg daily, Lipitor 
20mg daily, Imdur 30mg daily and Aspirin 81mg PO daily.  
.
# Anxiety  
- Continue Paxil 20mg PO daily  
.
# Insomnia: Patient continued on home Zolpidem 5mg QHS:prn  
.
Mr. ___ remained FULL CODE throughout this hospitalization.
 
Medications on Admission:
- Atenolol 100mg PO daily  
- Atarvostatin (lipitor) 20mg Po daily  
- Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg Po daily  
- Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (vicodin) ___ tablets q6 prn  
- Isosorbide Mononitrate (Imdur) 30mg PO daily  
- Paroxetine (Paxil) 20mg Po daily  
- Zolpidem 5mg PO qhs prn  
- Aspirin 81mg Po daily 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
2. Isosorbide Mononitrate 30 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain.  
4. Atorvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at 
bedtime).  
5. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. Paroxetine HCl 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO QHS (once 
a day (at bedtime)).  
7. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
8. Atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
9. Zolpidem 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) 
as needed for insomnia.  
10. Home oxygen to be given at 3 liters a minute

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: Pulmonary fibrosis
Secondary: Hypertension, Dyslipidemia, Spinal stenosis, Anxiety, 
Coronary artery disease, PVD, GERD

 
Discharge Condition:
Improved. Stable.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital due to shortness of breath. 
While you were here you were placed on inhaled oxygen therapy 
that improved your symptoms and you were discharged to home with 
oxygen. This increasing shortness of breath is likely due to 
your pulmonary fibrosis. Please continue to use this oxygen 
until you see your pulmonologist, Dr. ___.

Medications:
1. Oxygen - You were placed on 3 liters of oxygen in the 
hospital. Please continue to use oxygen at home to treat your 
shortness of breath when you are ambulating or if you feel short 
of breath at rest.
There were no other changes made to your medication regimen.

If you experience any acute shortness of breath, chest pain or 
chest pressure, dizziness or lightheadedness, please call your 
primary care physician or go to the emergency room. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Allergies/ADRs on File
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Headache, chills, fatigue
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with no significant PMH who 
presents with couple days of a headaches, shaking chills, 
fatigue and "heavy hot" eyes.  Patient reports that he was in 
___ 4 weeks ago visiting family and traveling to urban and 
rural areas.  He was in ___ for 4 weeks but took his malaria 
prophylaxis for only three weeks while he was there.  When he 
came back to US, he was feeling well.  However, couple of days 
ago he started having throbbing frontal headaches associated 
with shaking chills and feeling fatigued with relief of symptoms 
after taking motrin.  Additionally he reports that his eyes feel 
heavy and warm; however his vision is not affected at all.  He 
reports being very fatigued especially in the morning.  He has 
been sleeping and eating okay. He denies any confusion, blurry 
vision, neck stiffness, any photophobia.  He also denies any 
sick contacts.
.  
In the ED, initial VS:  T 99.1 (rectal 100.7) P ___ BP 145/109, 
RR Sat 98%RA. Malaria smear was sent which came back negative 
for plasmodium antigen.  CXR didn't show any cardiopulmonary 
process.  Patient was asked permission for LP due to concern for 
meningitis but he refused the LP.  He was given 2g Ceftriaxone 
IV and 1g Vancomycin IV. 
.  
ROS: Also denies history of headaches, night sweats, sore 
throat, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, abdominal pain, 
nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation. 
 
Past Medical History:
Inguinal Hernia s/p repair in his ___ 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother died of stroke at age ___.
 
Physical Exam:
VS:  T 99.1  P 110s-120s BP 140s/100s, RR Sat 98%RA.
Gen:  Appears somewhat fatigued but in NAD, lying in bed
HEENT:  NC/AT, sclera anicteric and conjunctivae non-injected, 
PERRLA, EOMI, visual fields intact to confrontation. No sinus 
tenderness. MMM.  Oropharynx clear without exudates or erythema.
Neck: Supple, no cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular 
lymphadenopathy..  Kernig and brudinski negative.  
Chest:   Clear to ausculatation bilaterally. No rales, rhonchi 
or wheezes.  
CV:  RRR, nl s1/s2, no murmurs. 
ABD:  Soft, NT/ND, 
Extremities: Warm and well perfused
Skin:  Anicteric without rash
Neuro: Alert, oriented x3, CN II-VII intact. ___ strenght in the 
upper and lower extremity.  Sensation intact to light touch 
throughout. Gait not tested.
.
Discharged Physical Exam:
VS: T 98.6  BP 140s/80s  HR 100s, 98%RA
Gen:  Appears well sitting in chair
HEENT: NC/AT, sclera anicteric and conjunctivae non-injected, 
PERRLA, EOMI, visual fields intact to confrontation. MMM.  
Oropharynx clear without exudates or erythema.
Neck: Supple, no cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular 
lymphadenopathy.
Chest:   Clear to ausculatation bilaterally. No rales, rhonchi 
or wheezes.  
CV:  RRR, nl s1/s2, no murmurs. 
ABD:  Soft, NT/ND,no CVA tenderness 
Extremities: Warm and well perfused
Skin:  Anicteric without rash
Neuro: Alert, oriented x3
 
Pertinent Results:
Admission Labs:
___ 08:30AM BLOOD WBC-6.2 RBC-5.24 Hgb-14.9 Hct-43.7 MCV-83 
MCH-28.4 MCHC-34.1 RDW-14.6 Plt ___
___ 08:30AM BLOOD Neuts-82.0* Lymphs-12.0* Monos-5.4 
Eos-0.4 Baso-0.2
___ 08:30AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-12 Creat-1.1 Na-142 
K-4.1 Cl-109* HCO3-26 AnGap-11
___ 08:30AM BLOOD ALT-22 AST-23 LD(LDH)-192 AlkPhos-61 
TotBili-0.5
.
Hospital Course Labs:
___ 05:25AM BLOOD WBC-8.0 RBC-5.01 Hgb-14.2 Hct-41.3 MCV-82 
MCH-28.3 MCHC-34.3 RDW-14.5 Plt ___
___ 08:30AM BLOOD Parst S-NEGATIVE
___ 05:25AM BLOOD Parst S-NEGATIVE
___ 07:45PM BLOOD ESR-8 Parst S-NEG
___ 09:45PM BLOOD IgM HAV-NEGATIVE
___ 09:45PM BLOOD HCV Ab-NEGATIVE
___ 09:45PM BLOOD HEPATITIS E ANTIBODY (IGG)-PND
___ 09:45PM BLOOD HEPATITIS E ANTIBODY (IGM)-PND
___ 05:25AM BLOOD TSH-0.031*
___ 05:30AM BLOOD T4-7.9
___ 08:30AM BLOOD CRP-15.1*
.
EBV IgG positve, IgM negative
CMV IgG Postive, IgM negative
Toxo IgG positive and IgM Negative
Malaria Smear negative x4.
Blood cultures: pending
Urine analysis negative.
.
EKG ___: Sinus Tachycardia
.
CXR ___: No acute cardiopulmonary disease
 
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT & PLAN:  ___ year old man with no significant PMH who 
presented with several days of low grade temperatures, 
headaches, shaking chills, and fatigue after a trip to ___ 
one month prior. 
.
#Febrile syndrome: Presentation seems most consistent with a 
viral syndrome.  Initial suspicion for meningitis in the ED and 
patient given ceftriaxone and vancomycin prior to arrival to the 
medical floor (pt refused LP).  Clinical suspicion for menigitis 
was very low by the time of the patient's admission to the 
floor, so antibiotics were discontinued.  Malaria was also 
entertained given prior traveling history and lack of 
prophylaxis, but smears were negative times four.  Pt did not 
receive any pretrip vaccinations.  Time line of presentation 
inconsistent with dengue.  Typhoid fever and yellow fever also 
thought to be less likely.  Full infection workup, including 
blood cultures, urine analysis, chest radiograph, liver function 
tests, and infectious labs - including viral hepatitis 
(A,C,D,E), EBv, toxo, CMV - were all negative.  With supportive 
care and fluid, the patient's fevers resolved and  symptoms 
significantly improved by hospital day three.  Patient was 
discharged home with PCP follow up.
.
#Tachycardia: On admission patient was tachycardic to the 120s 
which responded well to IV fluid boluses.  EKG consistent with 
sinus tachycardia.  Differential for tachycardia included fever, 
infectious process, anxiety, and hyperthyroidism.  TSH was sent 
which came back as 0.031 with T4 of 7.9 which suggested 
subcllinical hyperthyrodism for which patient will follow up 
with his PCP for further management.  On the day of discharge 
patient's heart rate had decreased to normal ranges of ___. 
.
Transition of care:
Pending Labs: Blood Cultures with no growth to date.
Patient will follow up with his PCP on ___ for evaluation 
of any remaining symptoms he may have as well as for management 
of his subclinical hyperthyrodism.
 
Medications on Admission:
Tylenol PRN headaches
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Viral Symdrome
2. Sub clinical Hyperthyrodism
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, it was a pleasure taking care of you during 
your admission at ___ from ___.  You were admitted 
because you were having headaches, shaking chills, fatigue, for 
two days.  Your symptoms were  most likely because of a viral 
syndomee.  We did many lab tests for different viruses as well 
as for malaria which all came back as normal.  You were afebrile 
for over 24 hours without medications and your symptoms 
significantly improved with conservative therapy with pain 
control.  Most of your symptoms should resolve fully between 
___ days.  You can take tylenol as needed for pain. You should 
avoid drinking alcohol while you are taking tylenol.  

In the hospital you also had thyroid test which suggested that 
you may have sub clinical hyperthyroidism. You should follow up 
with your PCP as scheduled below for further management. 

We have made NO changes to your medications.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

been sleeping and eating okay. He denies any confusion, blurry
vision, neck stiffness, any photophobia. He also denies any
sick contacts.
.

IV and 1g Vancomycin IV.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT & PLAN: ___ year old man with no significant PMH who
presented with several days of low grade temperatures,
headaches, shaking chills, and fatigue after a trip to ___
one month prior.
.
#Febrile syndrome: Presentation seems most consistent with a
viral syndrome. Initial suspicion for meningitis in the ED and
patient given ceftriaxone and vancomycin prior to arrival to the
medical floor (pt refused LP). Clinical suspicion for menigitis
was very low by the time of the patient's admission to the
floor, so antibiotics were discontinued. Malaria was also
entertained given prior traveling history and lack of
prophylaxis, but smears were negative times four. Pt did not
receive any pretrip vaccinations. Time line of presentation
inconsistent with dengue. Typhoid fever and yellow fever also
thought to be less likely. Full infection workup, including
blood cultures, urine analysis, chest radiograph, liver function
tests, and infectious labs - including viral hepatitis
(A,C,D,E), EBv, toxo, CMV - were all negative. With supportive
care and fluid, the patient's fevers resolved and symptoms
significantly improved by hospital day three. Patient was
discharged home with PCP follow up.
.
#Tachycardia: On admission patient was tachycardic to the 120s
which responded well to IV fluid boluses. EKG consistent with
sinus tachycardia. Differential for tachycardia included fever,
infectious process, anxiety, and hyperthyroidism. TSH was sent
which came back as 0.031 with T4 of 7.9 which suggested
subcllinical hyperthyrodism for which patient will follow up
with his PCP for further management. On the day of discharge
patient's heart rate had decreased to normal ranges of ___.
.

Pending Labs: Blood Cultures with no growth to date.
Patient will follow up with his PCP on ___ for evaluation
of any remaining symptoms he may have as well as for management
of his subclinical hyperthyrodism.

6 hours) as needed for pain.

Home

1. Viral Symdrome
2. Sub clinical Hyperthyrodism
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, it was a pleasure taking care of you during
your admission at ___ from ___. You were admitted
because you were having headaches, shaking chills, fatigue, for
two days. Your symptoms were most likely because of a viral
syndomee. We did many lab tests for different viruses as well
as for malaria which all came back as normal. You were afebrile
for over 24 hours without medications and your symptoms
significantly improved with conservative therapy with pain
control. Most of your symptoms should resolve fully between
___ days. You can take tylenol as needed for pain. You should
avoid drinking alcohol while you are taking tylenol.
In the hospital you also had thyroid test which suggested that
you may have sub clinical hyperthyroidism. You should follow up
with your PCP as scheduled below for further management.
We have made NO changes to your medications.
Followup Instructions:
___

pain she gets with angina. At this point she was send to the ED. 


#Chest Pain
   HPI as above. While in the ED all laboratory testing was 
negative and EKG was equivocal. At this point given the patient 
history of preexisting cardiac disease and typical symptoms 
cardiology felt it would be best to admit over the weekend for 
observation for ACS and stress testing ___. Over the weekend 
Ms. ___ continued to have intermitted episodes of typical 
chest pain with negative testing. Cardiology originally wanted a 
pharmacologic stress test presantine MIBI but patient refused IV

results should be taken in such context. Patient will likely 
need a discussion as an outpatient on need for more informative 
cardiac testing.

and need for p-MIBI to truly investigate perfusion and vessels.

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo G0 who presents with acute onset of bilateral lower 
quadrant abdominal pain. Patient reports that pain began at 8PM 
suddenly while she was taking a shower. It was intermittent in 
waves initially and stabbing ___ with radiation
straight back to her midline back at times radiating to the 
right flank.  She took 2 ibuprofen with no relief.  Given her 
history of ovarian torsion ___ years ago, she decided to come in 
to the ED. She endorses nausea, but no vomitting, diarrhea, 
abnormal discharge. She reports feeling chills initially with 
onset of
pain. She did not take her temperature. She denies dysuria and 
has been voiding normally. She has had normal bowel movements. 
She was asymptomatic before onset of pain today.
 
Past Medical History:
ObHx: G0

Gyn Hx:
- LMP: ___, q28 days x ___ days
- Last pap: ___ neg, no hx abnl
- Denies hx STDs
- Single. Last intercourse ___. Unprotected. Negative STIs
after encounter. Used plan B. Current contraception: NuvaRing; 
Past contraception: OCP
- Hx right ovarian torsion in the setting of 5.9cm ovary, no 
cyst
-> LSC detorsion

Med Hx: Iron deficiency anemia

Surg Hx: tonsillectomy, LSC (R) ovarian detorsion ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
denies hx of breast or female cancers

 
Physical Exam:
Exam on admission by Dr. ___:
98, 76, 118/82, 16, 100% RA
Gen:Lying supine and still in bed with wet washcloth over eyes.
2 friends are at the bedside
CV: RRR
lungs: CTAB
back: no CVAT but mild bilateral flank tenderness
abd: soft, diffuse TTP RLQ=LLQ > RUQ & epigastrium >
Periumbilical > LUQ, no rebound, (+) voluntary guarding, no
peritoneal signs, not tympanic to percussion
SVE: No CMT, no localization of pain, diffusely tender in the
lower abdomen during exam.  Small, mobile uterus. Neither ovary
palpable. Dark menstrual blood on glove. Moderate to heavy flow
note.  
Extr: NT, NE

 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-6.3 RBC-3.86* Hgb-12.1 Hct-36.9 MCV-95 MCH-31.3 
MCHC-32.8 RDW-13.4 Plt ___
___ WBC-11.0# RBC-4.16* Hgb-12.7 Hct-39.9 MCV-96# MCH-30.6 
MCHC-31.9 RDW-13.3 Plt ___
___  Neuts-75.4* ___ Monos-2.8 Eos-1.9 Baso-0.2
___ ESR-12
___ Glucose-93 UreaN-14 Creat-0.9 Na-138 K-4.0 Cl-104 
HCO3-23 AnGap-15
___ ALT-12 AST-21 AlkPhos-35 TotBili-0.1
___ HCG-LESS THAN 5
___ CRP-3.1
___ URINE Color-Yellow Appear-Clear Sp ___
___ URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR Glucose-NEG 
Ketone-TR Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.0 Leuks-NEG
___ URINE RBC-10* WBC-<1 Bacteri-FEW Yeast-NONE Epi-0

Pelvic u/s (___): 1. Normal arterial and venous waveforms 
and normal-sized ovaries bilaterally excluding torsion at the 
time of the study; however, intermittent torsion cannot be 
excluded. 2. Prominent left pelvic vessels may suggest pelvic 
congestion syndrome. 

CT abd/pelvis (___): No CT findings within the abdomen or 
pelvis to account for abdominal pain. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the GYN service for monitoring 
of her pain. She underwent serial abdominal exams for 
monitoring.  Ms. ___ had initially required narcotics for 
pain medication while in the ED but upon arriving to the floor 
had decreased need. Her work-up was unrevealing for a source of 
her abdominal pain with normal labs and imaging. Her abdominal 
exam was reassuring, without any distention or peritoneal signs 
throughout her entire hospitalization. She did however start her 
menses shortly after admission which was thought to contribute 
to her pain.  

On hospital day one she also had urinary retention and was 
straight catheterized for 600 cc of clear yellow urine. This was 
thought to be secondary to narcotic use. After that initial 
decompression she had no trouble voiding. 

By hospital day 2 she was able to control her pain with oral 
tylenol and motrin.  She no longer required narcotics.  She was 
ambulating, tolerating a regular diet and voiding spontaneously. 
 She was discharged home in good condition with follow-up. 
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
None
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Abdominal pain

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain.  No acute 
cause of your pain could be found and your symptoms improved.  
Please continue to monitor your pain and follow-up as an 
outpatient for further evaluation.  You may continue to take 
tylenol or motrin as needed for your pain. Do not exceed 4000 mg 
tylenol daily.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right ZMC fracture
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Open reduction internal fixation of right zygomatic maxillary 
complex fracture through multiple approaches.

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ male who sustained a right ZMC 
fracture status post motor vehicle crash on ___.  He is here 
today for repair of this fracture.
 
Past Medical History:
Previous history of a nail into right lobe requiring removal and 
suture repair.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Pre-procedure physical exam as documented in Anesthesia Record 
___:
General: ___ M mod distress
Mental/psych: A&Ox3, no issues with recent memory formation, no 
new itnerval headache.
Airway: as documented in detail in anesthesia record
Dental: poor dental health
Head/Neck Range of Motion: Free range of motion
Heart: S1S2 RR
Lungs: clear to auscultation
Extremities: Right anterior leg wound, 2 small ventral burns on 
left forearm

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had a repair of right sided facial fracture.  The 
patient tolerated the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received IV pain medication 
with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. His diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. He was also started on a bowel regimen 
to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were closely 
monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV unasyn, then 
switched to PO augmentin for discharge home. Patient was given 
Peridex to swish and spit after meals and at bedtime for 
cleansing of his oral incision site.  The patient's temperature 
was closely watched for signs of infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient had some right periorbital/facial 
swelling and ecchymosis.  He had a right sided facial splint 
intact.  His right upper cheek incision was clean and intact.
 
Medications on Admission:
Penicillin VK
percocet
 
Discharge Medications:
1. erythromycin 5 mg/gram (0.5 %) Ointment Sig: 0.5 inch strip 
Ophthalmic HS (at bedtime): Apply to right eye.
Disp:*1 tube* Refills:*2*
2. chlorhexidine gluconate 0.12 % Mouthwash Sig: Fifteen (15) ML 
Mucous membrane four times a day: swish and spit after meals and 
at bedtime.
Disp:*420 ML(s)* Refills:*2*
3. polyvinyl alcohol-povidon(PF) 1.4-0.6 % Dropperette Sig: ___ 
Drops Ophthalmic PRN (as needed) as needed for dry eyes: apply 
to right eye.
Disp:*1 bottle* Refills:*1*
4. amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO Q12H (every 12 hours).
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain: Max 12/day. Do not exceed 
4gms/4000mgs of tylenol per day.  
6. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right zygomatic maxillary complex fracture.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted on ___ for repair of a facial fracture. 
Please follow these discharge instructions:
.
Medications: 
* Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise. 
* You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that 
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do 
not take these meds with additional Tylenol. 
* Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
* Take your antibiotic as prescribed. 
* Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking the 
prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
. 
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
* Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
* A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s). 
* Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
* Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 
.
Activities:
* No strenuous activity 
* Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
* Unless directed by your physician, do not take any medicines 
such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or Ibuprofen etc
.
Comments:
* Please sleep on several pillows and try to keep your head 
elevated to help with drainage. 
* Please maintain SOFT diet until your follow up clinic visit 
and you can ask your surgeon whether you can advance your diet 
at that time.  
* Please continue your oral antibiotics for 7 days. 
* Please avoid laying on the right side of your face. 
* Keep your facial splint in place until your follow up 
appointment
* Sneeze with your mouth open 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

* Please maintain SOFT diet until your follow up clinic visit
and you can ask your surgeon whether you can advance your diet
at that time.
* Please continue your oral antibiotics for 7 days.
* Please avoid laying on the right side of your face.
* Keep your facial splint in place until your follow up
appointment
* Sneeze with your mouth open
Followup Instructions:
___

he was playing football with friends, when around ___ he was

his head, thrusting his neck and head forward.  He had no loss 
of
consciousness and no headache, but 10 minutes afterwards, he
noticed that he was seeing double.  The diplopia was one image
above the other image.  It is resolved when he turns his head to
the left, and worsened in a mid-line or right head-deviated
position.  The positioning of his eyes do not affect the
diplopia.  It improved over the next few hours such that the
images were becoming closer together, but did not resolve, so 
his

CT

work-up. There has been no headache, neck pain, field cut,
weakness, or numbness. No vomiting.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ right-handed man who presented to 
___ with vertical diplopia after being struck in 
the head while playing football.  A CT of the head was 
reportedly negative and the patient was transferred to the ___ 
for further evaluation and care. An MRI and Angiogram of the 
head and neck was performed to evaluate for vertebral artery 
dissection and other contributory abnormalities.  The study was 
unrevealing.  Mr ___ symptoms were therefore thought to 
be related to a post-concussive syndrome.

findings.

signs.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You presented to ___ with double vision after being 
struck in the head while playing football.  A CT of the head was 
negative and you were transferred to the ___ for further 
evaluation and care. An MRI and Angiogram of the head and neck 
was performed to evaluate for vertebral artery dissection and 
other contributory abnormalities.  The study showed no 
concerning changes.  Your symptoms are thought to be related to 
a post-concussive syndrome, and should improve with time.

* If it provides relief, you should wear an eye patch until your 
vision improves.

* Please coordinate and attend all follow-up apporintments as 
recommended.

* Please seek medical attention if you develop headache, neck 
pain, visual changes, nausea, vomiting, sleepiness, dizziness, 
trouble walking, weakness, numbness, tingling, chest discomfort, 
shortness of breath, or any other symptom you find concerning.

* Please avoid contact sports for at least two weeks and speak 
with one of your physicians before beginning these activities.

(every 8 hours).

Home With Service
 
Facility:
___

Very small foci of traumatic SAH 
Left maxilla: 
-Displaced, comminuted fx posterior wall
-minimally displaced fx anterior wall
-fx of inferior orbital wall
-minimally displaced fx of lateral orbital 
-hemmorrage and fat herniating into left maxillary sinus with no
sinus of entrapment of inferior rectus muscle

 
Discharge Condition:
Neurologically stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions

Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
You have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it as 
prescribed.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Laparoscopic appendectomy (___)

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ previously healthy with no past surgery is now
presented with migratory abdominal pain x 1 day. 
Patient reports that she started having periumbilical pain 
around
4 ___ yesterday, which then migrated to right lower quadrant.  
She
denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, change in bowel
movements, loss of appetite.  The last time she had a meal was
yesterday at 7 ___, which she tolerated.  She has been drinking
water throughout the day today.  

Upon arrival, she was hemodynamically stable, afebrile.  Her lab
was notable for leukocytosis, with a white blood count of 13.2. 
Left shift was noted with a PMN of 83%.  Otherwise her LFTs and
lipase are normal.  CT abdomen pelvis was performed, and
demonstrated dilated appendix to 8 mm, no apparent 
appendicolith,
consistent with acute uncomplicated appendicitis.
IV fluids was started in the ED.  Patient was given Zosyn. 
Patient declined ___ study. Surgery is consulted for surgical
management of acute appendicitis.  
 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
Physical exam:
Gen: NAD, AxOx3
Card: RRR, no m/r/g
Pulm: CTAB, no respiratory distress
Abd: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, normal bs.  
Wounds: c/d/i
Ext: No edema, warm well-perfused

 
Pertinent Results:
Per OMR
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on 
___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain.  
Admission abdominal CT revealed acute appendicitis, WBC was 
elevated at 13.2 and downtrended to 5k. The patient underwent 
laparoscopic appendectomy, which went well without complication 
(reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a 
brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the 
floor tolerating regular diet, on IV fluids, and tylenol and 
oxycodone for pain control.  The patient was hemodynamically 
stable.

When tolerating a diet, the patient was converted to oral pain 
medication with continued good effect. Diet was progressively 
advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. 
The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, 
the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with 
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth q8 Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Ibuprofen 400 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild 
RX *ibuprofen 400 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q8hr:PRN Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5-5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 0.5 (One half) tablet(s) by mouth q4hr:PRN 
Disp #*5 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation - First Line 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth bid:PRN Disp 
#*14 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute appendicitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___

___ were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy (removal of your appendix 
using small holes in your belly). ___ are recovering well and 
are now ready for discharge. Please follow the instructions 
below to continue your recovery:

Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
 
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until ___ have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel ___ could respond in an emergency.
o ___ may climb stairs. 
o  ___ may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
___ see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o ___ may start some light exercise when ___ feel comfortable.
o ___ will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when ___ 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW ___ MAY FEEL: 
o  ___ may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. ___ 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust ___.
o  ___ may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  ___ might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
___ might feel somewhat depressed.
o  ___ could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow ___ may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing ___ have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o ___ may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless ___ were told 
otherwise.
o ___ may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o ___ may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when ___ may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, ___ may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. ___ can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If ___ go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If ___ find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o ___ will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if ___ take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long ___ will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If ___ are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when ___ 
cough or when ___ are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If ___ experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines ___ were on before the operation just as 
___ did before, unless ___ have been told differently.
If ___ have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Upon arrival, she was hemodynamically stable, afebrile. Her lab
was notable for leukocytosis, with a white blood count of 13.2.
Left shift was noted with a PMN of 83%. Otherwise her LFTs and
lipase are normal. CT abdomen pelvis was performed, and
demonstrated dilated appendix to 8 mm, no apparent
appendicolith,
consistent with acute uncomplicated appendicitis.
IV fluids was started in the ED. Patient was given Zosyn.

management of acute appendicitis.

(reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a
brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the
floor tolerating regular diet, on IV fluids, and tylenol and
oxycodone for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically
stable.
When tolerating a diet, the patient was converted to oral pain
medication with continued good effect. Diet was progressively
advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability.
The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization,
the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively
participated in the plan of care. The patient received
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this
stay.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled. The patient was discharged home without services.

instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with
the discharge plan.

History of Present Illness:
___ who was BIBEMS to the ER intoxicated. By report, he was 
drinking whiskey, and his friends ___ get him to wake up 
while sleeping in his car, so they called EMS. 
.
In the ED, initial vs were: T 97 P 85 BP 102/88 R 12 O2 sat 98%. 
FSG 136. Nonfocal basic neuro exam, but patient was intubated 
for airway protection as he didn't react to nasal trumpet. 
Nasotracheal intubation was attempted but was unsuccessful, and 
then the pt vomited 1L of gastric contents. He was then 
intubated i the standard fashion. Propofol caused mild 
hypotension to 95. Initial ABG 7.28/47/128, so increased TV and 
rate in ED. Also got 1L NS. No signs of trauma but got head CT 
and C-spine CT just to be sure, which show no acute process. EKG 
without acute process. Has 2 PIVs for access. Arrived to the ICU 
with no sign-out and no holding orders.
.
He currently appears intubated and sedated, does not respond to 
verbal commands or withdraw from painful stimuli.
.

.

no acute fracture or subluxation, DJD at C5-6
.

no acute process, ETT in good position

Brief Hospital Course:
# Respiratory failure - Did not have evidence of gas exchange 
abnormality. Tubed for airway protection. After metabolized the 
ETOH he was alert and pulled his own ETT. He maintained his 
airway afterward and was on RA prior to leaving AMA.

# AG Acidosis - likely ___ alcohol, perhaps some lactate 
component. Was trending down in the morning. Left AMA before 
could assess further.

# EtOH abuse: received a banana bag and a social work consult. 
Not usually a heavy drinker but in the setting of his divorce 
has started drinking more heavily. counseled on stopping the 
ETOH.

# UGIB: Patient started vomiting and then had coffee ground 
emesis the afternoon after admission. Hct was stable at 38 and 
patient was also hemodynamically stable. Was started on IV PPI 
BID with plan to follow serial hematocrits, however, the patient 
wanted to leave AMA. He was competent to make his own medical 
decisions and understood the risks of leaving including more GI 
bleeding, hypotension from the bleeding and even death. He was 
given a prescription for omeprazole BID X 14 days to attempt to 
treat the GIB at home. He was advised to come back to the ED if 
he had any furhter bleeding.

# Communication: Patient
Fire___ ___, lives 5 mins away

# Code:  Full (presumed)

___ herbal supplements

Home

ETOH intoxication
upper gi bleed likely ___ ___ tear

AMA

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with acute alcohol intoxication. You had to 
have a breathing tube to protect your airway. You pulled the 
breathing tube out. You also had some bloody vomit. We would 
have liked you to stay in the hospital another night but you 
refused. You have left against medical advise.

___

# Respiratory failure - Did not have evidence of gas exchange
abnormality. Tubed for airway protection. After metabolized the
ETOH he was alert and pulled his own ETT. He maintained his
airway afterward and was on RA prior to leaving AMA.
# AG Acidosis - likely ___ alcohol, perhaps some lactate
component. Was trending down in the morning. Left AMA before
could assess further.
# EtOH abuse: received a banana bag and a social work consult.
Not usually a heavy drinker but in the setting of his divorce
has started drinking more heavily. counseled on stopping the
ETOH.
# UGIB: Patient started vomiting and then had coffee ground
emesis the afternoon after admission. Hct was stable at 38 and
patient was also hemodynamically stable. Was started on IV PPI
BID with plan to follow serial hematocrits, however, the patient
wanted to leave AMA. He was competent to make his own medical
decisions and understood the risks of leaving including more GI
bleeding, hypotension from the bleeding and even death. He was
given a prescription for omeprazole BID X 14 days to attempt to
treat the GIB at home. He was advised to come back to the ED if
he had any furhter bleeding.

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left leg redness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo male with history epilepsy and chronic mild LLE edema 
after a motorcycle accident ___ years ago who presents with 2 
days of LLE swelling and pain. He first noticed extreme fatigue 
while at work on ___, necessitating a nap. He had to leave 
work since he felt so unwell. On ___ morning, he began to 
have LLE throbbing pain around his ankle with mild associated 
swelling. He also noted a burning in his upper medial left 
thigh. He first noticed redness with further swelling and pain 
___ morning. This has never happened to him before. He was 
taking ibuprofen to try to reduce the swelling, but was not 
requiring anything for pain as long as he is not ambulating. He 
has not noticed any insect bites or skin breakdown. This has 
never happened to him before despite ___ years of chronic mild 
LLE edema. He denies athlete's foot, but notes running the day 
before his symptoms started. It was much worse so he went in to 
see his PCP. At his PCP's office he was given cefazolin and they 
drew borders around the erythema. In the ED, initial VS 101.6 89 
136/78 18 100% on RA. Exam notable for extensive erythema of LLE 
and fever. Labs notable for normal WBC. The pt underwent U/S w/o 
clot or fluid collection. The pt received one dose vancomycin. 
Vitals prior to transfer 98.1 64 118/82 99ra.
.
Currently, he feels that his leg is smaller in size with less 
erythema but still warm. He would like to leave the hospital 
tonight to see his son in a play.
.
ROS:
+Per HPI.
-Denies night sweats, headache, vision changes, rhinorrhea, 
congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, 
abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, 
melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria. All other ROS 
negative. 
 
Past Medical History:
-Facial fracture in ___ after syncope
-Epilepsy, CT brain w/ old encephalomalacia. Has had seizures in 
setting of low med levels.
-L>R peripheral edema from LLE compound fx in setting of 
motorcycle accident
-Hypercholesterolemia 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father died of PE at ___, Sister w/ melanoma.
 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission:
VS: 101.6 98.9 103/66 74 18 99% on RA 80.5kg 840/BR
GENERAL: Well-appearing man in NAD, comfortable, appropriate.
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclerae anicteric, MMM, OP clear.
NECK: Supple, no thyromegaly, no JVD, no carotid bruits.
HEART: RRR, no MRG, nl S1-S2.
LUNGS: CTA bilat, no r/rh/wh, good air movement
ABDOMEN: +BS, Soft/NT/ND, no masses or HSM, no rebound/guarding.
EXTREMITIES: LLE with large area of bright erythema, warm to 
palpation, 2+ non-pitting edema to the knee. Erythema and warmth 
tracks up towards groin, without inguinal lymphadenopathy. 2+ 
pulses bilaterally. Erythema within borders drawn at 2pm today. 
+erythematous punctate 1cm lesion on left foot, +cracked skin in 
between first two toes on right foot, no evidence of athlete's 
foot
NEURO: Awake, A&Ox3, CNs II-XII grossly intact, muscle strength 
___ throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout. 
.
At discharge:
VS: 100.7 ___ 97-100%RA
GENERAL: Well-appearing man in NAD, comfortable, appropriate.  
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclerae anicteric, MMM, OP clear.  
NECK: Supple, no thyromegaly, no JVD, no carotid bruits.  
HEART: RRR, no MRG, nl S1-S2.  
LUNGS: CTA bilat, no r/rh/wh, good air movement  
ABDOMEN: +BS, Soft/NT/ND, no masses or HSM, no rebound/guarding. 
 
EXTREMITIES: LLE with large area of bright erythema and warmth 
which has significantly improved with IV Vancomycin.  2+ pulses 
bilaterally. +cracked skin in between first two toes on right 
foot, no evidence of athlete's foot, no crepitus on exam 
NEURO: Awake, A&Ox3, CNs II-XII grossly intact, muscle strength 
___ throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout. 
 
Pertinent Results:
LABS:
CBC: 9.5/13.1/39.0/138 MCV 95
Chem 7: ___

MICROBIOLOGY:
___: No growth
___: No growth

STUDIES:
___ LLE U/S: No DVT in the left lower extremity. Soft tissue 
selling in the left leg, predominant in the left calf. No focal 
fluid collections. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with chronic venous stasis in LLE presents with fever 
and LLE erythema representing cellulitis with lymphangitic 
spread up left leg.

# Cellulitis: Chronic venous stasis of left leg plus appears to 
be a punctate lesion on left foot is a set up for cellulitis. 
Given extent and severity of infection, he was started on IV 
vancomycin which significantly improved his cellulitis and 
fever.  He was changed to po keflex and bactrim to cover for 
strep and staph species respectively on day 4.  He remained 
afebrile and his cellulitis continued to improve. He was 
discharged to complete 10 days of antibiotics with keflex and 
bactrim.  

# Epilepsy: Continued home Keppra.

# Glaucoma: Continued timolol and latanoprost.

# Hyperlipidemia: Continued on simvastatin and Aspirin

Follow up for PCP
1. Please evaluate for further need for antibiotics as he will 
complete his course of keflex and bactrim on the day of his 
appointment with you on ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
-simvastatin 20mg daily
-Keppra 1,000mg BID
-timolol 0.5% 1 drop ___ daily
-latanoprost 0.005% 1 drop ___
-hydrocortisone 0.2% cream BID affected areas
-ASA 81mg
-Multivitamin 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. simvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
2. levetiracetam 1,000 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day.  
3. timolol maleate 0.5 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic 
DAILY (Daily).  
4. latanoprost 0.005 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic HS (at 
bedtime).  
5. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
7. sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim 800-160 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day).
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
8. cephalexin 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:  Cellulitis
Secondary Diagnosis:  Chronic venous stasis of left lower 
extremity

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay here at 
___.

You were admitted for an infection of the superficial tissues of 
the left leg, known as cellulitis.  You were given IV vancomycin 
as an antibiotic and then transitioned to KEFLEX and BACTRIM by 
mouth.  You had high fevers during this time which prolonged IV 
therapy.  

The following changes were made to your medication regimen:
START Bactrim DS one tab twice a day for 7 more days (End date: 
___
START KEFLEX ___ mg by mouth four times a day for 7 more days 
(End date: ___
STOP hydrocortisone 0.2% cream

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the ED with symptomatic cholelithiasis 
and elevated liver function tests. Patient was evaluated by 
anaesthesia and taken to the operating room where she underwent 
a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. There were no adverse events in 
the operating room; please see the operative note for details. 
Pt was extubated, taken to the PACU until stable, then 
transferred to the ward for observation. 

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization; pain was managed with oral medication. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO. On POD1, the diet 
was advanced sequentially to a regular diet, which was well 
tolerated. Patient's intake and 
output were closely monitored.
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, of which there were none. 
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to 
get up and ambulate as early as possible. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient will received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you.

Diet: Resume your regular diet until your follow up appointment. 


Medication Instructions:
Resume your home medications.
You will be starting some new medications:
1. You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.
2. You should begin taking a chewable complete multivitamin with 
minerals. No gummy vitamins.
3. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.
4. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and 
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system.

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal 
exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right ___ digit amputation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
PROCEDURE ___
1. Right ___ digit shortening osteoplasty of the distal
    phalanx.
2. Open reduction, internal fixation, right ___ digit
    distal phalanx.
3. Debridement down to bone, 3 x 2 cm area.
4. Repair of the skin and soft tissues over 3 cm area.

 
History of Present Illness:
History of Present Illness: ___ is a healthy ___ year-old
male who presents as a transfer from ___ with a
right small finger complete distal tip amputation. The paient
reports that he was using a woodsplitter to help out a friend,
when the ___ slipped. He felt immediate pain in the right small
finger and noticed the tip was amputated. EMS was called and the
tip was located and immediately wrapped in a wet gauze and 
placed
on ice. The injury occured at approximately 10:30am. At the OSH,
the finger was injected with a local anesthetic and irrigated
with saline and betadine. It is unclear whether a full 
neurologic
exam was performed prior to the anesthetic. The patient was then
transferred to ___ for hand surgery consultation. On arrival 
he
denies any pain in the finger. he denies any numbness, tingling
or parasthesias. He denies trauma to any other region.

 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
General: AVSS, NAD, AAOx3
Resp: Regular rate, non-labored on RA
CV: RRR
GI: Abd soft, NTND
Neuro: No focal neurologic deficits
MSK: On focus examination of the right hand there is a complete
tip amputation of the small finger just distal to the DIP joint.
There is a portion of the fragmented distal phalanx which is
visible without soft tissue coverage. There is no active 
bleeding
at this time. Secondary to the block placed at OSH, sensory exam
could not be performed. He is able to flex and extend at the
MCP/PIP/DIP joints. Otherwise, he has full ROM without pain of
his shoulder, elbow, wrist and other 4 digits. 2+ distal pulse,
symmetric.
 
Pertinent Results:
Imaging: Imaging of the right hand was reviewed and significant
for a right small finger complete distal tip amputation just
distal to the DIP joint. The amputated portion is not seen on
imaging.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic hand surgery service 
on ___ s/p right ___ digit amputation repair. The patient 
tolerated the procedure well, without complication. He was kept 
overnight for monitoring of the repaired digit, to assure that 
there was no venous congestion. 
 
Neuro: The patient received Dilaudid IV with good effect and 
adequate pain control. The patient was transitioned to oral pain 
medications with continued adeqaute pain relief. 
 
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
 
GI/GU: The patient was given IV fluids until tolerating oral 
intake. His diet was advanced when appropriate, which was 
tolerated well. He was also started on a bowel regimen to 
encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were closely 
monitored. 
 
ID: The patient's temperature and incision was closely watched 
for signs of infection. He recieved a brief course of IV 
antibiotics during his hospital course. He remained afebrile.

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible. 
 
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, 
voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours Disp 
#*60 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 50 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
daily Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0
4. Cephalexin 250 mg PO Q6H Duration: 7 Days 
RX *cephalexin 250 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp 
#*28 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right small finger distal tip amputation s/p reattachment 
without revascularization.
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:
1. Keep your dressing on until follow-up.
2. Non weight bearing right arm. 

Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. DO NOT lift anything with your right arm. 

Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered. 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 

for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that 
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do 
not take these meds with additional Tylenol. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per ___, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 

Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 

Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness,swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Erythromycin Base / Bactrim / Amoxicillin / Minocycline / ___ 
FE ___
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EGD

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old female with a past medical history notable for 
pancreatitis presents with one day of right flank pain radiating 
to the right inguinal region. The patient reports that her pain 
began gradually yesterday and has progressively worsened. She 
reports this pain is very similar to her prior episode of 
pancreatitis that she had last year. She reports associated 
nausea and dry heaves but denies any vomiting. She denies any 
chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, dysuria, bowel changes. 
She has no other significant past medical history. She has had 
her appendix removed.  She has no history of alcohol abuse.

In the ED, initial vitals were  96.7 74 126/70 18 98% RA.  There 
was tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant, along 
with right CVA tenderness.  Labs showed lipase 431, lactate 1.3, 
BUN 11, hematocrit 38.  UA showed no blood, protein 30, ketones 
40.  She received 2 liters NS, morphine 5 mg IV x 2 and 
ondansetron 4 mg IV x 2.  
 
Currently, the patient has ___ right side pain as well as dry 
heaves.  
 
Review of systems:  
(+) Per HPI  
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats. Denies headache, sinus 
tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, shortness of 
breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies 
diarrhea, constipation. No recent change in bowel or bladder 
habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Ten point 
review of systems is otherwise negative. 
 
Past Medical History:
Bulimia
Previous episode of pancreatitis
GERD
Sciatica
Irritable bowel syndrome
Dysmenorrhea
Acne
Migraines 
Anxiety
ASCUS   
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Breast cancer runs in the family.  There is no autoimmune or GI 
issues that run in the family.

 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAM:
Vitals: T: 96.3 BP: 101/80 P: 84 R: 16 O2: 100% on RA
GEN: Alert, oriented to name, place and situation. Fatigued 
appearing and uncomfortable, no acute signs of distress.  
HEENT: NCAT, Pupils equal and reactive, sclerae anicteric, OP 
clear, MM dry.  
Neck: Supple, no JVD
Lymph nodes: No cervical, supraclavicular LAD.  
CV: S1S2, reg rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs or gallops.  
RESP: Good air movement bilaterally, no rhonchi or wheezing.  
ABD: Soft, tender at epigastric area and at right flank, 
non-distended, + bowel sounds.  
EXTR: No lower leg edema  
DERM: No active rash.  
Neuro: non-focal.  
PSYCH: Appropriate and calm.

DISCHARGE EXAM:
tolerating POs
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:

___ 03:40PM BLOOD WBC-5.4 RBC-4.21 Hgb-13.9 Hct-41.3 MCV-98 
MCH-33.0* MCHC-33.7 RDW-12.6 RDWSD-45.5 Plt ___
___ 03:40PM BLOOD Neuts-44.4 ___ Monos-7.1 Eos-2.1 
Baso-0.9 Im ___ AbsNeut-2.38 AbsLymp-2.43 AbsMono-0.38 
AbsEos-0.11 AbsBaso-0.05
___ 07:00AM BLOOD ___ PTT-26.8 ___
___ 03:40PM BLOOD UreaN-11 Creat-0.8 Na-140 K-4.0 Cl-104 
HCO3-25 AnGap-15
___ 03:40PM BLOOD ALT-22 AST-24 AlkPhos-41 Amylase-106* 
TotBili-0.6
___ 03:40PM BLOOD Lipase-212*
___ 08:00PM BLOOD Lipase-431*
___ 08:14PM BLOOD Lactate-1.3

IMAGING:

CT Abdomen/Pelvis (___):
1. No radiographic evidence of pancreatitis.
2. Focal fatty infiltration of the liver.

EGD (___):
Impression:
Normal mucosa in the stomach (biopsy)
Normal mucosa in the duodenum (biopsy)
Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum
Recommendations:
- No findings to explain abdominal pain
- Follow-up biopsies
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with past history of idiopathic pancreatitis 
presents with abdominal pain and elevated lipase concerning for 
recurrent pancreatitis, now w/ normalized labs, negative CT and
EGD.

# ABDOMINAL PAIN / PANCREATITIS:
Lipase elevated to 431 on admission, now normalized. Initial 
presentation consistent with pancreatitis, though unclear why 
symptoms continue to persist at this point. Negative workup
including RUQ ultrasound, CT abd/pelvis, and EGD. There may be 
some component of patient/family anxiety that something worse is 
going on. Patient's father had friend who died of pancreatic
cancer after delayed diagnosis and this may be driving some of 
the anxiety. However, patient does seem to have very real 
symptoms which may not be entirely explained by pancreatitis. 
Normal EGD rules out PUD/gastritis. Patient's diet was advanced 
and she was tolerating full liquids at the time of discharge. 
Her symptoms were ultimately felt to be due to pancreatitis plus 
perhaps R lumbar muscle spasm. She will need to follow up with 
her outpatient gatroenterologist (Dr. ___ for consideration 
of further testing for idiopathic pancreatitis vs other 
functional GI causes that could explain her pain.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
[ ] Please follow-up EGD biopsies.
[ ] Please evaluate patient further for causes of idiopathic 
pancreatitis, including genetic screening. This will likely be 
done by Dr. ___ patient's outpatient gastroenterologist.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Fish Oil (Omega 3) Dose is Unknown  PO Frequency is Unknown 
2. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Fish Oil (Omega 3) 1000 mg PO DAILY 
2. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
3. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO TID 
4. Ondansetron 8 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 
RX *ondansetron HCl 8 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth three times a day 
Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Diazepam 5 mg PO TID Duration: 3 Days 
as we discussed, may cause sedation, avoid with alcohol or 
driving 
RX *diazepam 5 mg 1 tablet by mouth three times a day Disp #*10 
Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute pancreatitis
Abdominal pain
Muscle spasm

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you. You were admitted because 
of abdominal pain. We found that you had pancreatitis, though 
your symptoms were more severe than expected based on laboratory 
findings and could be explained by other causes as well. 

We performed a CT scan of your abdomen/pelvis, as well as an EGD 
(upper endoscopy), both of which were entirely normal, as well 
as a pelvic ultrasound.

Please continue to see your outpatient GI doctor to further 
evaluate why you have these episodes of abdominal pain.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with a PMH of HTN, BPH, and 
hypothyroidism
who presented with approximately 10 hours of nausea, sweats,
chills, subjective fever and sharp ___ right flank pain
radiating to the right scapula. A RUQUS in the ED showed 
steatosis,
cholelithiasis and mild intra- and extra-hepatic ductal
dilatation without gallbladder wall thickness. His WBC was 12.4,
Tbili 1.0 and LFTs were elevated at ALT 120 and AST 115. The 
patient underwent a lap chole on ___ with no intra op 
complications. Post ___, the patient continues to do well. On 
POD 1, the patient was tolerating a regular diet, voiding 
independently, having BM, and pain was well controlled. He was 
discharged home in stable condition with follow up in ___ 
clinic. 

 
Medications on Admission:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H   
2. Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Medications:

2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth 
BID:PRN Disp #*10 Capsule Refills:*0  
3.  Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY:PRN constipation  
4.  Senna 17.2 mg PO HS  
5.  Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
acute cholecystitis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery
 
Followup Instructions:
___
