text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
VT noted on stress MIBI
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cardiac Catheterization

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with history of HTN and rheumatoid arthritis presenting 
with intermittent chest pain, SOB, and heart fluttering for the 
past 2 weeks.  He has had these symptoms off and on in the past, 
but has been much more noticeable these last 2 weeks.  In the 
past he had chest pain, mostly on exertion, but sometimes at 
rest.  Pain was always substernal, with no radiation, and would 
resolve on its own.  At times he would feel SOB along with the 
CP.  Never experienced any associated nausea or vomiting.  
.
Patient had an outpatient stress pMIBI today, able to tolerate 
11 minutes, developed chest pressure that resolved with rest.  
The stress showed minor ST changes.  During recovery patient was 
noted to have five episodes of VT, with longest episode being 18 
beats.  He was referred for admission based on these findings, 
for possible cath.  Dr. ___ him in the ED.  He is CE 
negative x1.  Received 325 mg of aspirin in the ED
.
On the floor, patient is comfortable.  Complains of a very 
slight chest pressure, but not having SOB, dizziness, 
lightheadedness, palpitations.

 
Past Medical History:
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: -Diabetes, -Dyslipidemia, +Hypertension 
 
2. CARDIAC HISTORY:  
-CABG: none 
-PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: none
-PACING/ICD: none
3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
HTN
Rheumatoid arthritis - seronegative, palindromic
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother - CHF, passed away at age ___
No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or 
sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory.  
 
Physical Exam:
On admission
VS: 126/70, 56, 18, 98%RA
GENERAL: WDWN male in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect 
appropriate.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  

NECK: Supple with no JVD
CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or 
S4.  
LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits.  
SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.  
PULSES:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+

Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+

CHEST (PA & LAT) Study Date of ___ 2:46 ___
TWO VIEWS OF THE CHEST: The cardiomediastinal contour is normal. 
The heart 
is not enlarged. The lungs demonstrate mild left lung base

There is no focal consolidation to indicate pneumonia. There is 
severe 
degenerative change of the thoracic spine and wedge deformities 
of multiple thoracic vertebral bodies.

Otherwise no significant coronary artery disease

___ 12:50PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.___ yo M with history of HTN and chronic chest pain on exertion, 
history of intermittent heart fluttering, presents with NSVT 
noted after a stress MIBI
.  
# CORONARIES: patient has experienced chest pain with exertion 
for the last few years, was found to have 5 episodes of NSVT 
during recovery after a stress MIBI.  Patient was admitted for 
concerns for ischemia, but was ruled out with cardiac enzymes 
x3.  No significant events on telemetry.  Cardiac 
catheterization showed a minor lesion in the OM artery but no 
significant pressure gradient when evaluated with aid of 
pressure wire.  There was no other significant CAD noted on 
catheterization.  It is unclear what precipitated his chest 
pain.  Patient was set up with a 30 day cardiac monitor through 
Dr. ___, and will follow up with him as an 
outpatient.  He is recommended for an outpatient lipid panel for 
further risk stratification.
.  
# PUMP: patient has no history of CHF.  Appeared clinically 
euvolemic on this admission.  Patient was continued on HCTZ.
.  
# RHYTHM: patient has no past history of arrhythmia, but has had 
intermittent heart fluttering over the last few years.  Was 
found to have NSVT following a stress MIBI just prior to 
admission.  Patient was monitored on telemetry with no 
significant events.  Patient will be set up with an outpatient 
cardiac monitor for further work up.
.  
# HTN: patient was continued on ___  

 
Medications on Admission:
___ 25mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS:
1. Noncardiac Chest pain

SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS:
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis
2. Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with chest pain. We did a 
cardiac catheterization which was normal. You will need to 
follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ weeks.  You will be set up with 
a cardiac monitor through Dr. ___.

No changes were made to your medications, please continue to 
take them as originally prescribed.

Please follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ weeks.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

antibiotics ending on ___.  He was ambulating without hypoxemia. 
 OSH TTE showed EF 30%, repeat TTE at ___ showed EF 66% with 
normal RV and LV function and no valvular lesions, thus he may 
have had temporary depressed EF related to sepsis.  He does not 
need any cardiology follow up.

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Cat bite with pain and swelling to right ring finger
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___
1. Incision and drainage right ring finger.
2. Application of drainage catheter right ring finger.
3. Application short-arm splint.
4. Wrist block by surgeon.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old right-handed Female with pain and swelling to right 
ring finger. Patient was bitten by her cat yesterday at 11:30am. 
She subsequently developed pain and swelling at the bite site, 
on her right ring finger that has progressed. She has pain over 
the bite marks and PIP joint. Her finger is most comfortable 
when held flexed. She is unable to extend her finger. She also 
complains of pain on the dorsal side of her hand. Reports slight 
numbness in finger tips. She noticed streaking up her arm. 
Denies fevers/chills, nausea/vomiting, fatigue. She presented to 
___ where she was given vanc and unasyn and transferred to 
___ for concern for flexor tenosynovitis.
 
Past Medical History:
Protein S deficiency
h/o ovarian vein thrombosis and PE
sarcoidosis

 
Social History:
Patient works as a ___, denies EtOH/smoking/drugs.

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals- 97.4 86 105/64 16 97 
Gen: NAD
Resp: unlabored
RUE: ulnar and radial pulses 2+, ring finger PIP joint and 
proximal phaylnx swollen, erythematous, and tender, 2 puncture 
wounds, slight amount of pus expressed from volar aspect of PIP 
joint, unable to extend at PIP joint ___ pain, tender on dorsum 
of ___ metacarpal, no volar metacarpal tenderness, erythema 
tracking up forearm (marked), flexion and extension of wrist 
intact

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:35PM   ___ PTT-31.4 ___
___ 03:35PM   PLT COUNT-209#
___ 03:35PM   NEUTS-58.2 ___ MONOS-5.5 EOS-1.1 
BASOS-0.5
___ 03:35PM   WBC-4.1# RBC-3.68* HGB-10.8* HCT-34.6* MCV-94 
MCH-29.5 MCHC-31.3 RDW-12.4
___ 03:35PM   estGFR-Using this
___ 03:35PM   GLUCOSE-84 UREA N-9 CREAT-0.6 SODIUM-143 
POTASSIUM-3.9 CHLORIDE-110* TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-14
___ 05:43AM BLOOD ___
.
MICROBIOLOGY:
___ 5:35 pm SWAB     Site: HAND      RIGHT ARM. 

   GRAM STAIN (Final ___: 
      1+    (<1 per 1000X FIELD):   POLYMORPHONUCLEAR 
LEUKOCYTES. 
      NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN. 

   WOUND CULTURE (Final ___: 
      PASTEURELLA SPECIES.    SPARSE GROWTH. 

   ANAEROBIC CULTURE (Preliminary):    NO ANAEROBES ISOLATED. 
.
Radiology Report HAND (AP, LAT & OBLIQUE) RIGHT Study Date of 
___ 3:36 ___ 
THREE VIEWS OF THE RIGHT HAND: The bone mineralization is within 
normal 
limits. There is no acute fracture or dislocation. No bony 
erosions are 
detected. No subcutaneous air is seen. There is no embedded 
radiopaque 
foreign body. The soft tissues overlying the ___ proximal 
phalanx are swollen. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had an incision and drainage of right ring finger 
with application of drainage catheter. The patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient was splinted and elevated with 
continuous normal saline irrigation through the catheter in her 
right hand x 24 hours.
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received dilaudid PO with 
poor effect overnight.  Patient was started on Extra strength 
tylenol around the clock and Toradol 30mg IV Q6h with great pain 
relief reported. She was discharged home on Vicodin PRN.
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV Vancomycin 
and unasyn, then switched to PO Bactrim and Augmentin, pending 
culture results. Patient grew out Pastuerella and was discharged 
home on Augmentin x 7 days.  The patient's temperature was 
closely watched for signs of infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was maintained on her home maintenance 
dose of coumadin 10mg po QOD. Patient was also covered with 
Lovenox injections while inpatient due to her history of protein 
S deficiency and of PE.
.
At the time of discharge on POD#3, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  Her right hand swelling had improved and patient 
had less tenderness over ring finger and increased ability to 
range her ring finger.  Her sutures were intact.
 
Medications on Admission:
Coumadin 10mg po QOD
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Diflucan 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once: Take for 
symptoms of vaginal yeast infection.

She subsequently developed pain and swelling at the bite site,
on her right ring finger that has progressed. She has pain over

.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on
___ and had an incision and drainage of right ring finger
with application of drainage catheter. The patient tolerated the
procedure well. Patient was splinted and elevated with
continuous normal saline irrigation through the catheter in her
right hand x 24 hours.
.

poor effect overnight. Patient was started on Extra strength
tylenol around the clock and Toradol 30mg IV Q6h with great pain
relief reported. She was discharged home on Vicodin PRN.
.

vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint;
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.

tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate,
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were
closely monitored.
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV Vancomycin
and unasyn, then switched to PO Bactrim and Augmentin, pending
culture results. Patient grew out Pastuerella and was discharged
home on Augmentin x 7 days. The patient's temperature was
closely watched for signs of infection.
.

dose of coumadin 10mg po QOD. Patient was also covered with
Lovenox injections while inpatient due to her history of protein
S deficiency and of PE.
.

afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet,
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well
controlled. Her right hand swelling had improved and patient
had less tenderness over ring finger and increased ability to
range her ring finger. Her sutures were intact.

Coumadin 10mg po QOD

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Leg pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ male who presented to the ED with 
___ days of gradual onset acute left lower back pain limiting 
his ability to walk. He has had left low back pain for about 1 
month. On ___ he awoke to pain down the side of his leg and 
anterior tenderness. This worsened over the subsequent 48 hours 
to the point where he could not stand or walk so he came to the 
ED. He denies fevers, urinary or fecal incontinence or 
retention, recent trauma, IV drug use or diabetes. He has no 
associated paresthesias or motor dysfunction.

In the ED, initial vitals: T 97.8, 96/67, 81, 16, 100%RA

Labs including CBC and Chem-7 were unremarkable.

He was treated with oral and IV pain medications with mild 
relief. He was therefore admitted to the hospital for ongoing 
pain management.

Imaging showed "tiny bony fragment adjacent to the superior 
aspect of the left acetabulum is likely an os acetabuli, a tiny 
avulsion fracture is considered much less likely."

Decision was made to admit to medicine for pain control.

On arrival to the floor, vitals were: 98.1, 116/69, 62, 16, 
99%RA.

The patient reported ongoing left hip pain radiating down the 
lateral aspect of his leg but terminating above the level of the 
knee. Reports improvement in his pain since receiving medication 
in the ED but still has ___ pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  
Denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision changes, 
rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, 
chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria.  
All other 10-system review negative in detail.
 
Past Medical History:
Right knee ACL reconstruction (___)
Right knee partial meniscectomy (___)
Left claviculectomy for thoracic outlet syndrome
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Paternal grandmother: kidney cancer
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:  
VS -  Tm 98.1, 116/69, 62, 16, 99%RA
GENERAL: Pleasant male in moderate discomfort
HEENT: Anicteric sclera, MMM
CARDIAC: RRR, S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs  
LUNG: CTAB, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi, breathing comfortably 
without use of accessory muscles  
ABDOMEN: nondistended, +BS, nontender in all quadrants, no 
rebound/guarding, no hepatosplenomegaly  
BACK: No asymmetry, no spinal process tenderness, no spasm of 
the paraspinous muscles
EXTREMITIES: Positive straight leg raise and contralateral 
straight leg raise (both reproducing the patient's pain in the 
left leg), no hip effusion or bruising
SKIN: warm and well perfused, no excoriations or lesions, no 
rashes 

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
VS -  Tm 98.1, 111/76, 64, 16, 100%RA
GENERAL: Pleasant male in NAD, using his laptop, talking on the 
phone
BACK: No asymmetry, no spinal process tenderness, no spasm of 
the paraspinous muscles. Palpation over left sciatic nerve in 
gluteal region reproduces the patient's left lateral leg pain.
EXTREMITIES: Anterior left hip pain with pressure. Pain with hip 
flexion but not abduction. ___ strength with hip flexion 
bilaterally. Positive straight leg raise and contralateral 
straight leg raise (both reproducing the patient's pain in the 
left leg), no hip effusion or bruising
 
Pertinent Results:
=== ADMISSION LABS ===

___ 02:15AM BLOOD WBC-6.4# RBC-4.86 Hgb-14.2 Hct-40.8 
MCV-84 MCH-29.2 MCHC-34.8 RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 02:15AM BLOOD Neuts-61.4 ___ Monos-4.9 Eos-4.2* 
Baso-0.6
___ 02:15AM BLOOD Glucose-97 UreaN-14 Creat-0.9 Na-139 
K-4.0 Cl-103 HCO3-27 AnGap-13

=== IMAGING ===

PELVIS AND LEFT HIP (___):
Tiny bony fragment adjacent to the superior aspect of the left 
acetabulum is
likely an os acetabuli, a tiny avulsion fracture is considered 
much less
likely.

MRI LEFT HIP (___):
No fracture. Mild left greater trochanteric bursitis. 
Proliferative changes
the anterior aspect of the left femoral neck and subtle 
acetabular roof marrow
edema, suggestive of femoroacetabular impingement.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with no significant PMH admitted with acute to subacute 
onset left low back, and left lateral and anterior thigh pain. 

# Leg Pain: The patient was found to have an incidental finding 
on hip plain film of os acetabuli vs very small rectus femoris 
avulsion fracture. Patient denied history of trauma. He was 
admitted for pain control, requiring a combination of diazepam, 
oxycodone, tylenol, naproxen and gabapentin for adequate relief 
initially. MRI hip obtained for clarification of hip plain film 
findings revealed greater trochanteric bursitis but no evidence 
of either an occult femoral neck fracture nor rectus femoris 
avulsion fracture.. The night prior to discharge complained of 
numbness in L4 distribution. ___ saw him and thought his quads on 
the L were fatiguable. This ___ be consistent with an L4 
radiculopathy and he will follow up with spine. Patient's 
preference was for lumbar MRI. The patient was informed that the 
need for further imaging will be considered by his orthopedist 
at follow up if he has new/worsening or unresolved symptoms. At 
time of discharge his pain was well controlled on naproxen 
alone, although he was also discharged with a prescription for a 
small amount of oxycodone for breakthrough pain and valium for 
muscle spasm. He will be seen in ___ clinic at ___ on 
___. He will need ortho-spine followup within one 
week.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg PO TID:PRN muscle spasm 
2. Beclomethasone Dipro. AQ (Nasal) 42 mcg Other BID 
3. Ibuprofen 800 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Beclomethasone Dipro. AQ (Nasal) 42 mcg Other BID 
2. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H pain Duration: 7 Days 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*28 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Diazepam 5 mg PO Q8H:PRN muscle spasm 
RX *diazepam 5 mg 5 mg by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*15 
Tablet Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*28 Capsule Refills:*0
5. Naproxen 500 mg PO Q12H 
RX *naproxen 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*14 
Tablet Refills:*0
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 10 mg 0.5-1.5 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0
7. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 tablet by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*28 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
-L4 radiculopathy
-Greater trochanteric bursitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ on ___ with left leg pain. You 
were seen by Orthopedic Surgery during your admission and they 
thought your symptoms were likely caused by a problem with your 
spine (nerve impingement at L4). They did not think this 
required surgery right now and thought it will likely resolve on 
its own but you should follow up with a spine doctor within one 
week.   Your pain was managed with a combination of analgesics 
and you are now ready to be discharged home with close follow 
up. An MRI of your hip did not show a cause for your symptoms.  
If your symptoms worsen or if you have any new symptoms 
(worsened weakness) you should come to the ED.  Your outpatient 
orthopedics doctor who you will see ___ order an MRI of your 
spine when you see him if your symptoms are not resolving. 

It was a pleasure to take care of you during your hospital stay.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

per routine. The patient's home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who

unremarkable.

with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is

DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ 
___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient 
regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course 
including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, 
and all questions were answered. The patient was also given 
written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and 
the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness 
for discharge.

Disp #*20 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
acetablular fracture 

 
Discharge Condition:
Discharge Condiiton:
AVSS
NAD, A&Ox3

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Touch down weight bearing 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovonox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

Physical Therapy:
weight bearing as tolerated 
Treatments Frequency:
dressing changes PRN
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ with history of recurrent diverticulitis presenting with 24 
hours of ___, constant lower abdominal pain. She denies nausea, 
vomiting, fevers, blood in the stool, changes in her bowel 
movements, urinary symptoms. 

She has been treated for diverticulitis in three occasions 
(___) with PO Cipro/Flagyl for 14 days.

CV: RRR

ABD: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Active bowel sounds.
EXT: Warm and dry. no edema. ___ pulses.
NEURO: A&Ox3. Follows commands and moves all extremities equal 
and strong. Speech is clear and fluent.

MCH-28.0 MCHC-33.0 RDW-13.1 RDWSD-40.5 Plt ___

Cl-104 HCO3-24 AnGap-13
___ 01:34PM BLOOD Glucose-90 UreaN-10 Creat-0.8 Na-138 
K-4.7 Cl-102 HCO3-21* AnGap-15
___ 01:34PM BLOOD ALT-13 AST-24 AlkPhos-71 TotBili-0.3
___ 04:45AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-4.4 Mg-2.0
___ 01:34PM BLOOD Lipase-20

___ CT Abdomen Pelvis: 
Acute sigmoid diverticulitis versus straight segment colitis 
without a 
drainable fluid collection or macro perforation. There may be 
micro 
perforation within the extensive phlegmonous change in the 
sigmoid mesocolon. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F admitted to the Acute Care Surgery 
Service on ___ with abdominal pain and white blood cell 
count mildly elevated at 11.5. CT scan was concerning acute 
sigmoid diverticulitis versus colitis without a drainable fluid 
collection or perforation but phlegmonous changes in the sigmoid 
mesocolon. She was made NPO, given IV fluids, and IV antibiotics 
and admitted to the surgical floor for serial abdominal exams. 

On HD2 the patient had minimal abdominal discomfort and white 
blood cell count decreased to 6.2 and therefore diet was 
progressively advanced to regular with good tolerability. On 
HD3, the patient had no abdominal pain and therefore antibiotics 
were transitioned to oral with continued good effect. 

On HD3 the patient was afebrile, tolerated a regular diet and 
oral antibiotics without pain or discomfort and therefore 
discharged to home. The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.
 
Medications on Admission:
Celecoxib PRN
Tylenol PRN
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Celecoxib 200 mg oral BID  
3.  Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H 
RX *ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*26 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  MetroNIDAZOLE 500 mg PO Q8H 
RX *metronidazole 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth three times a day 
Disp #*39 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute diverticulitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service on ___ 
with abdominal pain and had a CT scan that was concerning for 
diverticulits. You were given bowel rest, IV fluids, and IV 
antibiotics. Your abdominal pain improved. Your diet was 
gradually advanced to regular and you were transitioned to oral 
antibiotics. You are now ready to be discharged to complete a 
course of oral antibiotics. 

Please follow up at the Acute Care Surgery appointment listed 
below to discuss future operative intervention.

Discharge Instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to ___ after presenting in the ___ 
with a microperforation of his colon identified on CT AP done 
while in the ___. He was afebrile, with moderate abdominal pain, 
and with a WBC 13.7 at the time of presentation. He was started 
on IVF, IV Cipro/Flagyl, and bowel rest. He was initially 
admitted to ___ for observation over the course of the 
morning. By afternoon on the day of admission, Mr. ___ 
abdominal pain had essentially resolved and he was feeling very 
hungry. He was discharged home that afternoon on clear liquid 
diet to be continued for 24 hours before switching to regular 
home diet, as well as on oral cipro flagyl to be continued for a 
total of 2 weeks. He was not scheduled for follow up in the 
Colon & Rectal Surgery office however it was discussed at length 
with the patient that he should immediately seek medical 
attention in the ___ if he develops fevers/chills, 
nausea/vomiting, inability to take po, worsening pain, or any 
other new symptom. He expressed understanding and agreement with 
this plan.

hours Disp #*42 Tablet Refills:*0

Home

Colonic microperforation

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___:

You were admitted to ___ for injury to your colon that 
occurred during your recent colonoscopy. While it was 
recommended that you remain in the hospital for 24 hour 
observation, we ultimately felt it was reasonable to send you 
home on 2 weeks of oral antibiotics to continue your recovery. 
You are being discharged with the understanding that if you 
experience any nausea/vomiting, fevers/chills, worsening of your 
abdominal pain, or any other new symptoms, that you will return 
to the emergency department immediately for evaluation.

You should continue clear liquid diet for the next ___ hours. If 
your pain continues to resolve you may switch to your regular 
home diet tomorrow. 

You may resume all of your normal home medications without 
changes. You should complete the entire course of antibiotics as 
they are prescribed, even if you feel better and your symptoms 
go away.

go away.

# Syncope. Thought to be consistent with vasovagal episode given 
occurence during micturition, report of clammy sensation, 
nausea, and description of similar feelings during other common 
vasovagal triggers (eg emotional stress). Arrhythmia was a 
consideration, esp given sudden LOC w/ head strike (prodrome 
possibly PVCs or other arrhythmia). Seizure unlikely. D-Dimer 
elevated to 1600, but PE ruled out by CTA. EKG normal. Trops 
negative. Pt was monitored on telemetry with ___ concerning 
events. She was not tachycardic, BP was stable, and she was able 
to walk comfortably around the unit. She was not volume down by 
exam or labs, but was gently fluid rescusitated to ensure 
hypovolemia not playing role in event. She was sent home in good 
condition to follow up with her PCP for consideration of further 
outpatient workup.

for an arrhythmia; your heart rhythm was normal. You were 
discharged to follow up with your PCP.

once a day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Expanding AAA, now status post lumbar artery coil embolization 
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Pleas follow the following instructions: 
MEDICATIONS: 
 Take Aspirin 81mg (enteric coated) once daily  
 Do not stop Aspirin unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs you 
to do so.  
 Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed 
 You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort

At HOME:
 Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES: 
 When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs 
 You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry) 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) 
 After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity 
 After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate 
 No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Healthy kidney donor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Living laparoscopic donor nephrectomy 

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ female who is otherwise healthy who 
wishes to act as a living kidney donor to her sister.  She 
presents today for elective laparoscopic donor nephrectomy.

 
Past Medical History:
hypothyroidism, microscopic hematuria (cystoscopy negative 
___, urethral syndrome, dry eye syndrome, history of UTIs, 
hemorhroids; history of concussion, history of nasal fracture 
.
PSH: polypectomy

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father died of complications of diabetes and was on dialysis at 
___. 
Her sister has IgA nephropathy.  A maternal aunt has breast 
cancer.  Her mother died at age ___ with lupus, coronary disease, 
and was a smoker. 
Her other siblings medical history includes hypothyroidism, 
hypertension, and prediabetes.  Her two sons are healthy.

 
Physical Exam:
VS: 99, 94, 133/73, 16, 95%RA
General: Looks well, slightly pale, pain managed with oral pain 
medications
Card: RRR
Lungs: No respiratory distress
Abd: Soft, sl distended, sl bruising around port sites, 
incisions otherwise C/D/I
Extr: No edema
Neuro: A+Ox3, pain managed on PO pain meds
.
Weight at discharge: 76.3 kg
 
Pertinent Results:
Labs Post sugery day 0: ___
Hct-36.4
K-4.3  Mg-1.8
.
Labs Post op day 1: ___
WBC-11.0* RBC-3.73* Hgb-11.6 Hct-35.5 MCV-95 MCH-31.1 MCHC-32.7 
RDW-12.9 RDWSD-44.0 Plt ___
Glucose-89 UreaN-13 Creat-1.3* Na-142 K-4.4 Cl-102 HCO3-27 
AnGap-13
Calcium-9.0 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.___ y/o female who was evaluated and accepted for being a kidney 
donor to her sister.
Patient was taken to the OR with Dr. ___ for left 
donor nephrectomy.
.
At the time of surgery there were no complications noted. The 
left kidney was successfully removed, with some slight oozing, 
but no measureable drop in the hematocrit post op. She was 
extubated and transferred to the PACU in stable condition.
.
Overnight following the surgery the patient was having some 
significant nausea, and was really not taking much for clears, 
and diet was kept sips to clears the first day and IV fluids 
were continued.
.
She was feeling better the second day post op, and the diet was 
advanced to regular. Her Foley catheter was removed and she was 
voiding without difficulty. Abdominal exam showed mild 
distension, port sites had some bruising but were other wise 
clean, dry and intact.
She was ambulating and although still having c/o mild pain, was 
ready for discharge on POD 3.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 
2. Loratadine 10 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO TID 
Maximum 6 of the 500 mg tablets daily  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
No driving if taking this medication  
4.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation  
5.  Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY  
6.  Loratadine 10 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Healthy kidney donor

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fevers, 
chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, increased 
abdominal pain, pain not controlled by your pain medication, 
incisional redness, drainage or bleeding, inability to tolerate 
food, fluids or medications, dizziness or weakness or any other 
concerning symptoms.
.
You may shower, allow water to run over incisions and pat dry. 
No lotions or powders near the incisions.
Dressings may be removed on ___ and left open to the 
air.
.
No tub baths or swimming
.
No lifting more than 10 pounds
.
No driving if taking narcotic pain medication
.
Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light yellow in color
.
Constipation is very common following donor surgery. You may use 
dulcolax suppository and/or milk of magnesia in addition to the 
stool softener and senna you are sent home with. Please call if 
you have not had a bowel movement within 5 days of surgery.

 
Followup Instructions:

test showed moderate, reversible, apical perfusion defect with 
apical hypokinesis.  She was admitted and underwent 
catheterization on ___ which revealed mild intermittent 
disease with maximum stenosis present of 30%.  No intervention 
required.  She remained chest pain free during hospitalization.  
Of note, we added Imdur 30 mg qd to her home medications to help 
prevent future angina.  Also discharged on Asa 81, Plavix 75, 
and Atorvastatin 40 (home medications).     

#CAD s/p stent: Pt is s/p stent to LAD in ___.  Asa 81, Plavix 
75, and metoprolol continued in house.  

#HTN: soft pressures in house so we discontinued both HCTZ and 
Losartan, and she remained normotensive.  We made this a 
transitional issue, to revisit with PCP concerning the need for 
these two medications. 
 
CHRONIC ISSUES:  
#GERD: increased home PPI to Protonix 40 bid while in house due 
to possibility of GERD contributing to her symptoms.  Ultimately 
discharged on home dose of omeprazole.   
 
#Hypothyroidism: continued home Levothyroxine 200 mcg PO qd.
   
#Depression/Anxiety: continued home Escitalopram 10 mg PO qd.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES

angina

discussion with your PCP and cardiologist if they are needed

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with hx of hypothyroidism presenting with 
left
leg swelling and pain. She was in her usual state of health 
until
last night when she noted progressive left leg swelling and 
pain.
Over the night she developed worsening pain in her left groin
pain radiating down her leg which prompted her to present to
___ for further evaluation in the morning. On
venous duplex, she was found to extensive left leg DVT. She was
started on a heparin gtt with a loading bolus and transferred to
___ for further management. She denies recent long periods of
immobility, travel history, or history of DVT. No recent surgery
or leg trauma. Denies shortness or breath or leg weakness,
parasthesias or loss of sensation. No known hypercoaguability
disorder. Her mother notes a possible GSV aneurysm which was
resected after a pregnancy many years ago. Her father had a DVT
after a prolonged ICU course. Vascular surgery was consulted for
further management.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted on ___ for left lower extremity 
swelling. CTA demonstrated right iliac artery compression of the 
left iliac vein, and the patient was started on heparin. The 
patient was brought to the operating room on ___ and underwent 
IVC filter placement and catheter-directed thrombolysis, which 
was the patient had no evidence of hematoma and was transferred 
to the PACU for recovery, where she remained hemodynamically 
stable. Hematocrit q6hrs remained stable, and the patient 
complained of mild back pain, which improved with pain 
management.
  
The patient was closely monitored in the ICU and remained 
stable. She was brought back to the OR on ___ for mechanical 
thrombectomy and placement of left CIV wall stent. The procedure 
was without complications. The patient did well intraoperatively 
and was transferred back to the ICU, where she continued to 
recover. On ___, her diet was advanced and foley was 
d/c'ed. She was discharged to home on POD#2 in stable condition 
with rivaroxaban 15mg BID for first 3 weeks, followed by 20mg 
daily. Follow-up has been arranged with Dr. ___ in clinic 
with surveillance with LLE duplex in 3 wks.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, thrombectomy incisions were 
clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels 
spontaneously. The patient will follow up with a LLE duplex and 
Dr. ___ in three weeks. She will be discharged on xarelto. A 
thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the 
diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons 
to call the office or return to the hospital, 
and all questions were answered. The patient was also given 
written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and 
the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness 
for discharge.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
___ syndrome - DVT in LLE

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Lower Extremity Angioplasty/Stent Discharge Instructions

MEDICATION:
 Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily 
 If instructed, take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily
 Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
 You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort
WHAT TO EXPECT:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows 
every ___ hours throughout the day and night
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
 It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
 Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES:
 When you go home, you may walk and use stairs
 You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
 After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
 After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
 No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
 Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
 New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
 Bleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
 Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call 
___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___            ___ No:  ___

Admission Date: ___        Discharge Date: ___

Date of Birth: ___         Sex:  M

Service:


This is a re-dictation of a discharge summary in a somewhat
delayed fashion following nothing able to be located.  Mr.
___ was a ___ gentleman status post extended
right colectomy on early ___ with an ileum to left colon
anastomosis at an outside hospital.  There, postoperatively
he developed a troponin leak and acute renal insufficiency
which was thought to be prerenal and atrial fibrillation.  He
then was transferred at the request of the surgeon there with
an essentially an acute abdomen, respiratory at failure
requiring urgent intubation.  After initial stabilization and
resuscitation, and evaluation in the ICU, he was taken to the
___ for exploratory laparotomy with a leak at the ileocolonic
anastomosis was identified and feculent peritonitis.  He
underwent resection of the anastomosis with an end ileostomy
and ___ gastrostomy.  The placement of a G-tube additionally
.
Subsequent to that, he had a long course with many issues
with wound care requiring ultimately complicated vac and a
variety of pouches, multiple debridements of the wound care.
With retention sutures in place, the wound was more difficult
to manage and he did develop skin erosions as well during
this time.  Postoperatively, he also developed a leak from
his G-tube site requiring with leaking from the JP requiring
a long period of being n.p.o.  He was on TPN.  He had a
prolonged ICU stay with intubation because of his risk for
respiratory status.  He was ultimately extubated from that
but continued to be not mentating at his preoperative level.
He then in early ___ developed acute arterial ischemia of
the right lower extremity and required a right femoral
embolectomy and repair of the right common femoral artery by
Dr. ___ and following that, he required continued
intubation and because of his long course, family discussions
were held in which he was ultimately made a CMO on ___ and he expired on ___ at 3:50 p.m. as noted
already on the Fulmar chart.  His family was appropriately
notified.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  Expired.



                        ___, M.D. ___

Dictated By:  ___, M.D.

T:  ___ 11:13:07

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
 Hiccups, nausea, vomiting

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
 This is a year-old with a history of metastatic colon
cancer (s/p resection, FOLFOX then FOLFIRI+avastin), presenting
with nausea, vomiting and hiccups.

His disease is known to have metastatized to the lungs and the
liver. He has recently undergone cycle 3 of FOLFIRI+avastin,
which he completed on ___. He says he has tolerated
prior chemo infusions well.

Today (___) around 3PM he developed nausea, vomiting as well
as incessant hickups. This has never happened before to him. He
denies any worsened abdominal pain, though he does admit to
ongoing mid-epigastric/RUQ as well as R flank pain that has been
present for weeks at about the same level. He has not had any
fevers/chills, no diarrhea/constipation, no dysuria, dyspnea or
cough. His review of systems is otherwise negative.

In the ED, he was given IV Thorazine and IVF. He was afebrile,
but remained tachycardic in the 110s. SBPs ranged from 94-109.

 
Past Medical History:
- Metastatic colon cancer as per above
- Cocaine abuse in the past

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family History: (per Atrius records)
- GM with uterine cancer
- GGF with colon cancer 
 
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam:

VS:  T 98.2, BP 128/72, HR 110, RR 18, satting 9% on RA
General Appearance: clearly exhausted and sleeping but easily
aroused and able to sustain attention.
Eyes: PERLL, EOMI, no conjuctival injection, anicteric
ENT: no sinus tenderness, MMM, oropharynx without exudate or
lesions, no supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy, no JVD,
no carotid bruits, no thyromegaly or palpable thyroid nodules
Respiratory: CTA b/l with good air movement throughout
Cardiovascular: tachycardic, RR, S1 and S2 wnl, no murmurs, rubs
or gallops
Gastrointestinal: Sparse bowel sounds. Abdomen not distended.
Diffuse mild tenderness with more prominent pain in the RUQ and
epigastrium. No peritoneal signs/rebound tenderness. No 
guarding.
Extremities: no cyanosis, clubbing or edema
Skin: warm, no rashes/no jaundice/no skin ulcerations noted
Neurological: Alert, oriented to self, time, date, reason for
hospitalization.  Cn II-XII grossly intact.
Psychiatric: pleasant, appropriate affect
GU: no catheter in place

Discharge exam

AO-3
Heart- RRR S1 and S2 normal. No MRG
Lungs- CTAB. No crackels or wheezes
Abdomen p- Soft Normal Bs,Non tender throughout the abdomen. No 
guarding or rigidity. No RUQ tenderness. 
Extremities- No edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:00AM BLOOD WBC-7.1 RBC-4.25* Hgb-13.8 Hct-40.4 
MCV-95 MCH-32.5* MCHC-34.2 RDW-14.0 RDWSD-48.8* Plt ___
___ 07:00AM BLOOD Glucose-89 UreaN-9 Creat-0.8 Na-139 K-4.2 
Cl-104 HCO3-23 AnGap-16
___ 10:10PM BLOOD Albumin-3.9 Calcium-9.1 Phos-4.5 Mg-2.1
___ 07:13AM BLOOD Lactate-1.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ old man with a history of metastatic colon
cancer, here with nausea, vomiting and hiccups. These have now
resolved with Thorazine infusion in the ED. Exam is notable for
tachycardia and initially borderline SBPs (in the setting of
Thorazine infusion), felt better with Zofran ODT and was 
discharged home the next AM.
Nausea felt to be from chemotherapy. Responded to Zofran. 

Acute problems:

# Nausea, vomiting, hickups: Causes included delayed reaction to
chemo vs progression of primary disease vs infection (ranging
from gastroenteritis to liver abscess). 
Responded well to Zofran.
BP on the lower side (SBP ___, responded to fluids. Before DC 
SBP 110s/80s

# Transaminitis: Likely a result of liver mets though chemo
side-effect certainly also possible. RUQUS reassuring (though
would not expect to see any major abnormalities since LFTs do 
not
conform to an obstructive pattern).
Downtrending. Will need outpt LFTs to monitor trend.

# Insomnia: Ongoing issue
discontinued Trazodone since interaction with Zofran (Increases 
Qtc)

# Metastatic colon cancer:
- Chemo per primary oncologist (ongoing FOLFIRI-avastin vs
enrolment in a trial)

For hiccups, suggested using baclofen and wrote scripts. DC'd 
home in a stable condition. 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. TraZODone 50 mg PO QHS 
2. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 2 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
3. LORazepam 0.5-1 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Baclofen 10 mg PO Q8H:PRN hiccups 
RX *baclofen 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 8 hours Disp #*40 
Tablet Refills:*2 
2.  Ondansetron ODT 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 
RX *ondansetron [Zofran ODT] 4 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 
hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*2 
3.  HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 2 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Moderate  
4.  LORazepam 0.5-1 mg PO QHS:PRN insomnia  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Nausea
Hiccups

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

 You were admitted for nausea and hiccups. You responded well to 
Zofran, an anti nausea medication. Your symptoms resolved and 
you were able to eat well shortly after.

 It was a pleasure taking care of you.

Sincerely,
___ MD
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Downtrending. Will need outpt LFTs to monitor trend.
# Insomnia: Ongoing issue
discontinued Trazodone since interaction with Zofran (Increases
Qtc)
# Metastatic colon cancer:
- Chemo per primary oncologist (ongoing FOLFIRI-avastin vs
enrolment in a trial)
For hiccups, suggested using baclofen and wrote scripts. DC'd
home in a stable condition.

Tablet Refills:*2

hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*2
3. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 2 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Moderate

History of Present Illness:
 ___ yo F with no significant past medical history presenting 
with several months of intermittent palpitations, waking her up 
at night, worse overnight.  She denies associated chest pain or 
pressure, shortness of breath, loss of consciousness, 
lightheadedness.  She notes that episodes are occasionally 
related to dehydration and constipation.  They also tend to 
occur after she has eaten late at night, and if she has had 
alcoholic beverages (rare/occasional). She denies excessive 
alcohol intake, or other drug use.  She reports that the 
symptoms do not occur during the day, only at night.  She denies 
significant life stressors.  She has not recently been pregnant. 
She is taking no new medications.  She only drinks caffeine in 
the morning.  She recently saw her PCP about this issue who 
suggested keeping a log of eating.  

In the ED, initial vital signs were notable for HR 160 in 
triage.  Remainder of vital signs were 98.6 126 140/93 20 100%.  
Labs notable for normal electrolytes, ddimer 176, normal CBC, 
negative serum and urine tox, negative uhcg.  CXR negative.  EKG 
notable for sinus tachycardia without ___ wave abnormalities.  
She received 2L NS and 2mg IV lasix. HR improved to the low 
100s, and patient was admitted for further evaluation of sinus 
tachycardia.  VS on transfer were 98.2 106 116/73 19 99%.

On arrival to the floor, VS were T 98.1 BP 122/85 HR 104 RR 20 
O2 100% RA.  Patient denied ongoing palpitations, 
lightheadedness, DOE. 
 
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  
On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, 
TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the 
time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black 
stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or 
rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the 
other review of systems were negative.  
 
Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, 
dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, 
ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope.

___ wave abnormalities

Transthoracic echocardiogram- The left atrium is normal in size. 
Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global 
systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%). Tissue Doppler imaging 
suggests a normal left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP<12mmHg). Doppler parameters are most consistent with 
normal left ventricular diastolic function. Right ventricular 
chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of 
aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The

# Sinus tachycardia- No evidence of anemia, electrolyte 
imbalance, infection, pregnancy, thyroid dysfunction, or 
structural heart abnormality to explain tachycardia. No risk 
factors for coronary artery disease other than family history 
and patient has no chest pain/pressure nor EKG changes to 
suggest ACS. Patient is usually symptomatic when she is 
dehydrated, and rates have drastically improved with fluids, now 
in low 100s, even down to ___.  Recommended patient continue 
vigorous PO fluid repletion, and continue to keep a log of 
food/drink intake and timing of symptoms.  She was instructed to 
___ closely with her PCP next week.  

# Transitional issues-
- Close PCP ___ folic acid supplementation as patient is trying to 
get pregnant

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis:
Sinus tachycardia
Dehydration

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
admission.

You were admitted with palpitations and a rapid heart rate.  
This improved with fluids, and therefore, was likely due to 
dehydration.  Your blood tests were all normal, including your 
thyroid function.  An ultrasound of your heart showed no 
abnormalities.  

Please be sure to stay well hydrated.  Please avoid alcoholic 
beverages for the next week as they may cause an exacerbation of 
your symptoms. 

Please see your primary care doctor early next week to discuss 
these symptoms.  

Since you are trying to get pregnant, we recommend you start a 
daily folic acid pill, which can be purchase over the counter.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet. On POD#2, the patient became increasing 
somnelent with long and short acting narcotics, and had an 
episode of desaturation to the mid 80's.  A formal pain consult 
was obtained at this time, and the patient was administered 
Narcan with good response.  His narcotic pain medications were 
given sparingly for the remainder of his stay.  Foley was 
removed on POD#3. He was evaluated by sleep medicine who 
recommended the patient initiate CPAP therapy during sleep, and 
follow up in their clinic for formal sleep study. Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.

You have undergone the following operation: Thoracic 
Decompression With Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

-Brace: You may have been given a brace. This brace is to be 
worn when you are walking. You may take it off when sitting in a 
chair or while lying in bed.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

-Follow up:
oPlease Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks 
after the day of your operation if this has not been done 
already.
oAt the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline 
X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start 
physical therapy.
oWe will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation 
and at that time release you to full activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

training, endurance training, Pt/family edu

drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

- Please take lovenox 40mg daily for 2 weeks

- You can get the wound wet/take a shower starting 3 days after 
your surgery.  You may wash gently with soap and water, and pat 
the incision dry after showering.  
- No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.

out at your 2-week follow up appointment.

for balance and protection

Coronary angiography and atherectomy of LAD
Impella placement 

 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ year old woman has a history of HTN, HLD, tobacco 
abuse.

Of note, in ___ she presented to ___ 
with dyspnea on exertion and ___ edema. EKG revealed a possible 
inferior infarction and non specific ST T wave changes. Trop 
peak was 0.05. BNP was > 2700. Echo revealed an LVEF of ___ 
with an inferolateral akinetic wall. At that time, stress 
testing was abnormal with a large inferior lateral wall defect. 
The extent of reversibility was uncertain due to overlying 
artifact. She underwent coronary angiogram on ___. This was 
notable for both significant LAD and RCA disease. CABG was 
recommended but the patient declined and she was referred for 
RCA rotational atherectomy/stenting. She underwent shockwave 
therapy of the RCA followed by 2 DES by Dr. ___ at ___ on 
___. She was admitted this hospitalization for staging PCI to 
LAD, given ASA/Plavix in cath lab. 

An atherectomy of LAD into first diagonal was attempted. She was 
s/p stent, but procedure was complicated by perforation of LAD, 
contained without tamponade. Impella was placed in R femoral 
artery, and the team was able to put cover stent into LAD. 

Pt was placed on norepi and transferred to the CCU, where she 
was in mild distress, bolused 2 L NS, was on norepi 2 but weaned 
down to .5. Bedside echo showed known reduced EF, no e/o 
pericardial effusion. She denied any CP, SOB, N, V. She reported 
some mild pain at access site. 
 
ROS: Positive per HPI. Remaining 10 point ROS reviewed and 
negative.

HTN, HLP, Depression, UC

===========================
REPORTS AND IMAGING STUDIES
===========================
___ TTE
The left atrial volume index is moderately increased. The 
estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is normal 
left ventricular wall thickness with a moderately 
increased/dilated cavity. Quantitative biplane left ventricular 
ejection fraction is 15 % (normal 54-73%). Normal right 
ventricular cavity size with normal free wall motion. The aortic 
sinus diameter is normal for gender with normal ascending aorta 
diameter for
gender. The aortic arch diameter is normal with a normal 
descending aorta diameter. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) are 
mildly thickened. There is mild [1+] aortic regurgitation. The 
mitral valve leaflets appear structurally normal. There is 
moderate to severe [3+] mitral regurgitation. The pulmonic valve 
leaflets are normal. The tricuspid valve leaflets appear 
structurally normal. There is mild [1+] tricuspid regurgitation. 
There is no pericardial effusion.

IMPRESSION: Moderately dilated left ventricle with severely 
reduced left ventricular systolic function. No pericardial 
effusion. Moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. Impella 
device is at appropriate depth.

___: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention: Percutaneous 
coronary intervention (PCI) was performed on a planned basis 
based on coronary angiographic findings documented on a prior 
angiogram. Postatherectomy the angiogram showed perforation of 
the ___ Diagonal bifurcation. Access was obtained in the 
left femoral artery and after multiple attempts Graftmaster - 
Covered stent 2.8mm was deployed at the site of perforation. The 
stent deployement resulted in closure of the perforation. The 
diagnoal outflow segment remained patent. For hemodynamic 
support Impella was inserted through the right femoral artery. 
The echocardiogram during the procedure showed absence of 
pericardial effusion. The wire was exchanged for Rota Floppy 
wire. Three passes were performed with the 1.5 mm burr at 170K 
RPM for <30 seconds each with no decelerations.
Complications: Complication: perforation
Findings: Successful PCI with drug-eluting stent of the LAD and 
diagonal coronary arteries. Impella device insertion for 
hemodynamic support.

============
MICROBIOLOGY
============
None
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with HTN, HLD and CAD 
who was admitted for planned staged PCI to the LAD. In ___ she was found to have severe CAD including 80% diag, 100% 
mid-LAD, 90% RCA. She declined CABG due to her preference to 
avoid invasive interventions. On ___ she had an 
uncomplicated intervention of the RCA. She presented on ___ 
for intervention to the LAD and LCx. Atherectomy of the LAD was 
complicated by coronary perforation that was treated with a 
covered stent and there was no evidence of effusion. She had an 
impella placed for hemodynamic support. 

Ms. ___ expressed that she did not want further interventions 
and wanted to revert to her DNR/DNI status. Her blood pressure 
was supported with norepinephrine as well as crystalloid and 
colloid infusions. Her impella settings were slowly weaned and 
this was removed on ___. Unfortunately she required 
increasing support after the impella was removed and dobutamine 
was added. Despite this, she continued to decline throughout the 
day. She then entered an unstable ventricular arrhythmia and 
passed away. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 
2. Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY 
3. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO BID 
4. Simvastatin 25 mg PO QPM 
5. Spironolactone 25 mg PO DAILY 
6. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
N/a
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Coronary Artery Disease
Cardiogenic Shock 
Acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction 

 
Discharge Condition:
Deceased
 
Discharge Instructions:
N/a
 
Followup Instructions:
___

peak was 0.05. BNP was > 2700. Echo revealed an LVEF of ___
with an inferolateral akinetic wall. At that time, stress
testing was abnormal with a large inferior lateral wall defect.
The extent of reversibility was uncertain due to overlying
artifact. She underwent coronary angiogram on ___. This was
notable for both significant LAD and RCA disease. CABG was
recommended but the patient declined and she was referred for
RCA rotational atherectomy/stenting. She underwent shockwave
therapy of the RCA followed by 2 DES by Dr. ___ at ___ on
___. She was admitted this hospitalization for staging PCI to
LAD, given ASA/Plavix in cath lab.
An atherectomy of LAD into first diagonal was attempted. She was
s/p stent, but procedure was complicated by perforation of LAD,
contained without tamponade. Impella was placed in R femoral
artery, and the team was able to put cover stent into LAD.
Pt was placed on norepi and transferred to the CCU, where she
was in mild distress, bolused 2 L NS, was on norepi 2 but weaned
down to .5. Bedside echo showed known reduced EF, no e/o
pericardial effusion. She denied any CP, SOB, N, V. She reported
some mild pain at access site.

IMPRESSION: Moderately dilated left ventricle with severely
reduced left ventricular systolic function. No pericardial
effusion. Moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. Impella
device is at appropriate depth.
___: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention: Percutaneous
coronary intervention (PCI) was performed on a planned basis
based on coronary angiographic findings documented on a prior
angiogram. Postatherectomy the angiogram showed perforation of
the ___ Diagonal bifurcation. Access was obtained in the
left femoral artery and after multiple attempts Graftmaster -
Covered stent 2.8mm was deployed at the site of perforation. The
stent deployement resulted in closure of the perforation. The
diagnoal outflow segment remained patent. For hemodynamic
support Impella was inserted through the right femoral artery.
The echocardiogram during the procedure showed absence of
pericardial effusion. The wire was exchanged for Rota Floppy
wire. Three passes were performed with the 1.5 mm burr at 170K
RPM for <30 seconds each with no decelerations.
Complications: Complication: perforation
Findings: Successful PCI with drug-eluting stent of the LAD and
diagonal coronary arteries. Impella device insertion for
hemodynamic support.

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Elevated blood sugars
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old male with a history of colon cancer and 
lung cancer s/p lobetomy, type II DM who presents with 
hyperglycemia on labs at ___'s office. Pt had been in his usual 
state of health until about 10 days ago. He was started on a new 
"cancer pill" the name which he does not recall. Since then he 
has felt weak, tired, with blurry vision and started to have 
very poor appetite. Today he was at his PCP's office for a 
routine appointment when it was determined that his blood 
glucose was critically high (> 500) and he was asked to come to 
the ED by his PCP.  
.  
He normally takes 2 oral regimen for his type II diabetes. He 
recalls that one of his 2 agents is Actos, but does not know the 
name of the other agent. He reports excellent compliance with 
these medications. He does not routinely check his FSG, but when 
he does it has been in the low 100s. The last time he checked 
his FSG at home was about 10 days ago. He denies fevers or 
chills. He reports that he has had a non-productive cough for 
about 7 months. This is following lobectomy for "lung cancer." 
He also notes right sided chest pain that is mostly pleuritic 
that has started following his lobectomy which was about 8 
months ago. He denies abdominal pain, nausea or vomitting. He 
had 1 episode of diarrhea 2 days ago.  
.  
EDVS 97.4 HR 79 100/47 RR 16 96% RA  
He was noted to have glucose of 700 without an anion gap and 
minimal ketonuria. He was given 8 units of insulin with FSG to 
438. he was then given 4 units of insulin with resultant FSG at 
290 approximately 3 hours prior to arrival to medicine floor. He 
was given 3 L NS. He also reportedly had U waves on ECG. Normal 
lytes on arrival to ED, has not yet been repeated. He also had 
an RUQ ultrasound for reported RUQ pain (though appears to be 
right sided chest pain per history on the floor) which was 
negative for biliary process.  
.  
On arrival to the floor, he reports that he feels well. FSG on 
arrival to the floor was 436. He was given humalog 8 units. He 
was also given potassium 40 mEQ x 1 and started on maintenace 1 
L NS with potassium 40 mEQ. Repeat electrolytes on the floor 
following 40 mEQ potassium was 3.8 with glucose of 375.  
.  
ROS: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, rhinorrhea, 
congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, abdominal 
pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, BRBPR, melena, 
hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria.  

 
Past Medical History:
DM2
Colon Cancer
S/p RUL resection
R perihilar mass seen on admission CXR on ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
VS: 97.2 112/62 HR 96 RR 18 100% RA FSG 423  
GEN: Thin middle-aged man in NAD, awake, alert  
HEENT: EOMI, PERRL, sclera anicteric, conjunctivae clear, OP dry 
 
NECK: Supple, no JVD  
CV: Reg rate, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g.  
CHEST: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Absent 
breath sounds in the right upper lobe. +Well healed scar on 
chest wall on right, tenderness to palpation along right chest 
wall.  
ABD: +Well healed vertical surgical scar along umbilicus, soft, 
NT, ND.  
EXT: No c/c/e  
SKIN: No rash  
NEURO: Grossly non-focal  

 
Pertinent Results:

PHOS-158* TOT BILI-0.3

___ 07:30PM   cTropnT-<0.01
___ 07:30PM   CK-MB-NotDone

MAGNESIUM-1.7
___ 07:30PM   WBC-7.5 RBC-3.95* HGB-12.8* HCT-36.2* MCV-91 
MCH-32.5* MCHC-35.5* RDW-15.6*
___ 07:30PM   NEUTS-77.9* LYMPHS-14.7* MONOS-5.7 EOS-1.6 
BASOS-0.2
___ 07:30PM   PLT COUNT-212#
.
Admission CXR:
Evidence of prior right lung resection. Right perihilar opacity 
could represent post-treatment changes, but underlying residual 
mass lesion cannot be excluded. Comparison with previous 
examinations would be helpful as well as clinical correlation. 
If previous studies are not available, then a dedicated CT of 
the chest with IV contrast is recommended for further 
evaluation. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ y.o. M with h/o lung resection, DM on oral 
medications only who presents with hyperglycemia to the 700s.
.
Hyperglycemia: Ddx included infection, poor compliance with 
medications, toxic metabolic disturbance, MI, among others.  He 
was placed on a sliding scale of insulin and in the first 12 
hours required >20 units of SC insulin.  Initial urinalysis was 
positive for ketones.  He did not have an anion gap despite his 
blood sugar of 701 on admission.  The hyperglycemia was 
attributed to recent steroid use and infectious workup was 
negative.  The patient endorsed knowing that his blood sugars 
were high and despite this he stopped checking them regularly at 
home.  He was initially going to be discharged on a temporary 
sliding scale, however the patient was unable to comprehend or 
interpret the sliding scale despite education by nursing with an 
interpreter.  His BS were expected to continue to improve off 
steroids and it was felt that the risks of inappropriate insulin 
dosing by the patient outweighed the benefits of tight control.  
He was discharged home on his usual regimen of glipizide and 
actos.  ___ will help continue diabetes teaching and the patient 
was instructed to check his sugars routinely and seek medical 
attention if they remain above 300. At the time of discharge his 
___ were in the low 200s.
.
Hyponatremia: Na was 130 on admission. This normalized with 
correction of his hyperglycemia. 
 
Medications on Admission:
- Actos 30mg qd  
- Glipizide 5mg QD  
- Pantoprozole 40mg QD  
- Multivitamin  
- Benzonate 100mg ___ TID  
- Xeloda 1500mg BID (started ___  
- lorazepam 1mg QHS  
- Methylprednisone 4mg ___, 21 tabs with unknown taper)  
- Dexamethasone 2mg (___). Unknown regimen; duration complete. 
 
- Compazine 10mg q4 PRN  
- Hydrocodone PRN  
- Viagra PRN  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Glipizide 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).  
3. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
4. Pioglitazone 15 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Benzonatate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for cough.  
6. Lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime as 
needed for insomnia.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
Hyperglycemia
Atypical chest pain, non-cardiac

Secondary:
Lung cancer
h/o colon CA
Type II diabetes

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable.  Afebrile.  Improved ___.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with elevated blood sugars.  
This was felt to be due to your recent steroid medications.  We 
started you on insulin and your blood sugars improved.  You will 
continue to take your previous diabetes medications.  It is VERY 
important that you check your sugars regularly and call your 
doctor if they are consistently above 300.  

You were provided with diabetes teaching while in the hospital 
and you will have visiting nurses to provide more assistance at 
home.  

Please continue your other medications as prescribed.

If your blood sugars become elevated please call your doctor.  
If you develop chest pain, SOB, high fevers, inability to eat or 
other concerning symptoms please call your doctor or some to the 
emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

other concerning symptoms please call your doctor or some to the
emergency room.

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old man with a history of CODP on home O2 
and chronic steroids, HTN who presents with cough and fever.  
The patient was on his normal state of health until 2 days PTA 
when he developed a non-productive cough and malaise.  He 
subsequently began to feel worse as the day progressed and 
developed fevers, chills, mild night sweats and nausea, but no 
vomiting.  The patient also felt mildly short of breath and 
continued his home O2 at 2L.  He took ibuprofen with limited 
benefit.  He denied any sick contacts or recent 
hospitalizations.

In the ED his intial vital signs were: 98.4, 156/75, 90, 20, 95% 
on room air.  He became febrile to 102.6 and was tachycardic to 
119.  He was given 3L IVF and CXR showed RLL pna.  The patient 
was given 750mg IV Levaquin.
.
On the floor the patient was 98.1, 104/58, 108, 22, 95% 2L NC.  
The patient reports that he felt much better.  He continues to 
have non-prodcutive cough.
.
Of note, the patient has prostate adenocarinoma dx in ___, 
watchful waiting.  Additioanlly, the patient had a benign 
mesothelioma in ___ s/p resection.  
.

frequency, urgency, dysuria, lightheadedness, gait unsteadiness, 
focal weakness, vision changes, headache, rash or skin changes.

Hypertension

Glaucoma
s/p resection of Right Benign Mesothelioma

___
Family History:
Mother MI @ ___

 
Physical Exam:

MMM, clear oropharynx, no erythema, no exudates no rhinorrhea/ 
discharge, no sinus tenderness
NECK: supple, trachea midline, no LAD, no thyromegaly
LUNG: lateral scar on left side under scapula, dry crackles at 
the bases, minimal rhonchi in R lower lobe, occasional 
exteratory wheeze
CV: S1&S2, RRR, no R/G/M
ABD: Soft/+BS/ NT/ ND/no rebound/ no guarding/ no hepatomegaly/ 
no splenomegaly

+___P, ___ b/l & symetrical

Achilles

K-3.9 Cl-104 HCO3-36* AnGap-9
