MCV-86 MCH-30.1 MCHC-34.9 RDW-14.4 Plt ___
___ 08:24AM BLOOD Neuts-93.9* Lymphs-3.9* Monos-1.7* 
Eos-0.4 Baso-0.1
___ 06:45AM BLOOD ___ PTT-38.6* ___
___ 06:45AM BLOOD ___
___ 08:24AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-17 Creat-1.1 Na-143 
K-3.8 Cl-98 HCO3-36* AnGap-13
___ 06:45AM BLOOD LD(LDH)-180
___ 06:45AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-3.3 Mg-1.7
___ 06:45AM BLOOD Hapto-243*
___ 08:22AM BLOOD Lactate-1.3

Micro:
Blood Cx ___: NGTD

IMAGING:
___ CXR
FINDINGS: There is increased opacity near the right heart border 
within the area of the right middle lung, concerning for 
underlying infectious process. In addition, there is an 
approximately 17 x 12 mm ill-defined rounded opacity near the 
lateral portion of the left lung base which is not localized on 
the lateral view. Again noted is pleural thickening along the 
right apex. Again noted are several right lateral rib fractures 
and pleural thickening in this area, stable. There is elevation 
of the right hemidiaphragm, unchanged. The cardiomediastinal 
silhouette is normal. Osseous structures appear intact. No free 
air is seen below the diaphragm. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
1. Right middle lobe pneumonia. 
2. Ill-defined rounded hyperdensity in the left lower lung base, 
not seen on the lateral view. A chest CT could be done on a 
non-emergent basis for 
further evaluation. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year-old man with a history of CODP on home O2 and 
chronic steroids, HTN who presents with cough and fever and RML 
pna on CXR.

#RLL Pneumonia:  The patient with new onset cough, fever, 
chills, malaise x 2days.  He was febrile in the ED to 102.6.  A 
CXR in the ED showed findings consistent with  RML pneumonia. 
The patient has a prior history of benign mesothelioma s/p 
resection, but CT in ___ didn't show evidence of scar in RML.  
The patient was started on 750mg of levaquin and blood cultures 
were sent.  The patient had a leukocytosis of 17.6 on admission. 
On the floor the patient BP was in the low 100's and was 
responsive to IV fluids. The patient was started on hydrocort 
50mg IV q8 due to mild hyoptension and his history of chronic 
steriod use. The patient continued to improve and switched to 
his home dose of po steriods on ___. The patient was continued 
on 750mg po levaquin to complete 14-day course and continued on 
his home prednisode dose of 10mg. It is recommendeded the 
patient have repeat CT-scan in ___ weeks to evaluate an 
ill-defined rounded hyperdensity in the left lower lung base.

#HTN: The patient was initially hypotensive and responsive to 
fluids on the floor.  He was started on IV steriods and switched 
to po steroids on ___.  The patient's BP meds were held during 
his admission and restarted at discharge.

#COPD: No evidence of COPD exacerbation.  Pt was continued on 
his home O2 requirement of 2L and theophylline.  He was 
restarted on his home dose of 10mg prednisone on discharge.

#Prostate Ca: Pt dx in ___ and plan is for watchful waitng.  Is 
being followed as outpatient at ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
Enalapril 10mg BID
Atenolol 25mg daily
Prednisone 10mg daily
Theophylline SR 300mg daily
Cosopt eye drops BID
Travata eye drops QHS

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Dorzolamide-Timolol ___ % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop 
Ophthalmic BID (2 times a day).  
2. Enalapril Maleate 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day.  
3. Atenolol 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
4. Prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
5. Theophylline 100 mg Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr Sig: Three 
(3) Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. Travatan 0.004 % Drops Sig: One (1)  Ophthalmic at bedtime.  
7. Levofloxacin 250 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily) for 10 days.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
8. Prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Pneumonia 
2. Steroid-induced hyperglycemia
3. Probable adrenal insufficiency secondary to chronic systemic 
steroids 

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable, ambulating, on 2L NC, tolerating regular ___

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were in the 
hospital.  You were admitted to ___ because of pneumonia. You 
were treated with steroids and antibiotics.  You improved with 
these treatments and will continue your antibiotics for a total 
of 14 days.

Please follow the medications prescribed below.

Please follow up with the appointments below.

Please call your PCP or go to the ED if you experience chest 
pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, 
fevers, chills, or other concerning symptoms.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___.             Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
left renal mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Robotic assisted left partial nephrectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ male radiologist with an incidental left renal 
mass. 4cm, solid, hypoenhancing, partially exophytic, lower 
pole. 

This was first noted in routine screening scan as his wife and 
sister died of pancreatic ca. 

He elected for robotic laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy.
 
Physical Exam:
From last GU progress note:

Gen: NAD, resting comfortably, AAO
 Pulm: nonlabored breathing, normal chest rise, acyanotic
 Abd: soft, NT, mildly distended/tympanitic, dressings cdi, no
rebound/guarding
 GU: foley in place draining clear yellow urine
 Ext: WWP
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ went to the OR for his partial nephrectomy. Please 
see the operative report for further details. He was admitted to 
the urology service postoperatively. He recovered well. His diet 
was advanced on POD1 which he tolerated well. He had his foley 
removed and was able to void without issue prior to discharge. 
He was ambulating independently, tolerating a diet, and feeling 
well prior to discharge. He will follow up as scheduled with Dr. 
___. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 
2. Atorvastatin 10 mg PO QPM 
3. NIFEdipine (Extended Release) 60 mg PO DAILY 
4. Triamterene-HCTZ (37.5/25) 1 CAP PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg ONE capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0 
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ONE tablet(s) by mouth Q6hrs Disp #*15 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
4.  Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 
Resume on ___.  Atorvastatin 10 mg PO QPM  
6.  NIFEdipine (Extended Release) 60 mg PO DAILY  
7.  Triamterene-HCTZ (37.5/25) 1 CAP PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left renal mass

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the provided handout that details 
instructions and expectations for your post-operative phase as 
made available by your urologist. 

***please keep a log of narcotics (pain pill) used over the week 
and return the log sheet at your follow up appointment. Remember 
to also bring the narcotic prescription bottle WITH YOU for your 
follow up appointment.

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. 
ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes 
and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor.

-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your 
hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have 
been applied to reinforce wound closure.  Allow these bandage 
strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

-UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED; AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing 
products and supplements that may have blood-thinning effects 
(like Fish Oil, Vitamin E, etc.).  This will be noted in your 
medication reconciliation. 

For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, then take 
the narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain 
relief is needed.

-Call your Urologist's office to schedule/confirm your follow-up 
appointment in 4 weeks AND if you have any questions.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
couch potato

-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams 
from ALL sources

AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 
3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up.

-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
Urologist

-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a 
gentle laxative. These are  over-the-counter medications that 
may be health care spending account reimbursable. 

-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
further minimize your risk of constipation. 

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a
couch potato
-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___.
-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams
from ALL sources
AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or
3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up.
-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your
Urologist
-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or
bathe
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not
operate dangerous machinery
-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a
gentle laxative. These are over-the-counter medications that
may be health care spending account reimbursable.
-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.
-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to
further minimize your risk of constipation.
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness,
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or
go to the nearest emergency room.
Followup Instructions:
___

pt was admitted to the floor unresponsive and intubated with 
questionable diagnosis of cholangitis and biliary sepsis.  Pt HR 
steadily decreased since admission and her BP steadily declined. 
 Pt became asystolic and rescuscitation began.  Pt received 
multiple rounds of epinephrine/adenosine/HCO3/calcium gluconate. 
 A femoral line was attempted, but complicated by hematoma.  Pt 
ABG pH 7.07 pCO2 48 pO2 65 HCO3 15.  K:7.4 lactate 9.4.  Pt 
regained a rhythm and pulse.  Levophed was started,and a right 
IJ was placed. Pt became asystolic shortly after.  CPR was 
resumed.  Multiple rounds of epinephrine/HCO3/Calcium given.  Pt 
was not rescuscitated and the code was called at 1814.  Family 
arrived during the code and was updated throughout the event.

___: I&D, CRPP of open L first toe fracture
 
History of Present Illness:
___ otherwise healthy ___ worker sustained an
injury to his left foot when he accidently had an I-beam 
weighing
several hundred pounds drop down on his left foot. The patient
had his steel toe boots on at the time, and despite significant
pain he worked for the next half hour or so before driving
himself to the ED in ___. He was found to have an open 
wound
over his ___ metatarsal and a comminuted ___ proximal phalanx
fracture and was transferred to ___ for further management.
Recieved Ancef and tetanus at OSH. Denies paresthesias. 

 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/C
 
Physical Exam:
AFVSS
NAD, A&Ox3
LLE: Noted approximately 3cm horizontal wound over the distal 
end
of his ___ metatarsal. Noted swelling and ecchymosis of his left
foot, most notable in the big toe. 
No pain with passive stretch of toes 2 through 5. 
___
SILT ___
WWP, +2 DP

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:00PM   GLUCOSE-96 UREA N-13 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-138 
POTASSIUM-3.8 CHLORIDE-102 TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-17
___ 10:00PM   estGFR-Using this
___ 10:00PM   WBC-6.2 RBC-4.30* HGB-14.5 HCT-41.3 MCV-96 
MCH-33.7* MCHC-35.0 RDW-12.6
___ 10:00PM   NEUTS-62.2 ___ MONOS-7.0 EOS-2.2 
BASOS-0.8
___ 10:00PM   PLT COUNT-225
___ 10:00PM   ___ PTT-29.7 ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was admitted to the orthopaedic team and taken to the 
OR on ___ for washout and CRPP of his open L first toe 
fx. He tolerated the procedure well. His pain was controlled 
with IV and PO agents and he was started on a course of keflex 
postoperatively. His LLE remained WWP and sensate postop. 
He is being discharged to home in stable condition. He is to 
remain nonweightbearing to his LLE in a splint; he will take ASA 
for 6 weeks for DVT ppx and complete the course of keflex. Pins 
are to be removed in ortho trauma clinic in 4 weeks. 
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
3. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
4. Keflex ___ PO QID x 7 days
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Open L first toe fx

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Aspirin 325mg daily for 6 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower but keep your splint clean and dry. No baths or 
swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment. Pins are to remain in 
for 4 weeks.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Nonweightbearing LLE in splint until follow up

Orthopedic Surgery Follow-Up:

Please follow up with ___, NP in the orthopedic 
trauma clinic ___ days post-operation for evaluation. Call 
___ to schedule appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission and any new medications/refills.

Danger Signs:

Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

 
Followup Instructions:
___

No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
Attending: ___.
Chief Complaint:
L foot injury
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: I&D, CRPP of open L first toe fracture
History of Present Illness:
___ otherwise healthy ___ worker sustained an
injury to his left foot when he accidently had an I-beam
weighing
several hundred pounds drop down on his left foot. The patient
had his steel toe boots on at the time, and despite significant
pain he worked for the next half hour or so before driving
himself to the ED in ___. He was found to have an open
wound
over his ___ metatarsal and a comminuted ___ proximal phalanx
fracture and was transferred to ___ for further management.
Recieved Ancef and tetanus at OSH. Denies paresthesias.
Past Medical History:
None
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/C
Physical Exam:
AFVSS
NAD, A&Ox3
LLE: Noted approximately 3cm horizontal wound over the distal
end
of his ___ metatarsal. Noted swelling and ecchymosis of his left
foot, most notable in the big toe.
No pain with passive stretch of toes 2 through 5.
___
SILT ___
WWP, +2 DP
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:00PM GLUCOSE-96 UREA N-13 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-138
POTASSIUM-3.8 CHLORIDE-102 TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-17
___ 10:00PM estGFR-Using this
___ 10:00PM WBC-6.2 RBC-4.30* HGB-14.5 HCT-41.3 MCV-96
MCH-33.7* MCHC-35.0 RDW-12.6
___ 10:00PM NEUTS-62.2 ___ MONOS-7.0 EOS-2.2
BASOS-0.8
___ 10:00PM PLT COUNT-225
___ 10:00PM ___ PTT-29.7 ___
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was admitted to the orthopaedic team and taken to the
OR on ___ for washout and CRPP of his open L first toe
fx. He tolerated the procedure well. His pain was controlled
with IV and PO agents and he was started on a course of keflex
postoperatively. His LLE remained WWP and sensate postop.
He is being discharged to home in stable condition. He is to
remain nonweightbearing to his LLE in a splint; he will take ASA
for 6 weeks for DVT ppx and complete the course of keflex. Pins
are to be removed in ortho trauma clinic in 4 weeks.
Medications on Admission:
None
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain
3. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation
4. Keflex ___ PO QID x 7 days
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Open L first toe fx
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
or cane).
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:
MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener
(colace) to prevent this side effect.
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Aspirin 325mg daily for 6 weeks
WOUND CARE:
- You may shower but keep your splint clean and dry. No baths or
swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken
out at your 2-week follow up appointment. Pins are to remain in
for 4 weeks.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet
ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Nonweightbearing LLE in splint until follow up
Orthopedic Surgery Follow-Up:
Please follow up with ___, NP in the orthopedic
trauma clinic ___ days post-operation for evaluation. Call
___ to schedule appointment upon discharge.
Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this
admission and any new medications/refills.
Danger Signs:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid,
medications down
- Any other medical concerns
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___             Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
unresponsive

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
nasogastric tube placement

 
History of Present Illness:
Briefly, this is a ___ yo unidentified male admitted to the ICU 
after he became unrepsonsive in a police cruiser. He had been 
picked up for breaking & entering a school. 
.  
His ED course was significant for myoclonic jerking. Neurology 
was consulted and recommended EEG, which showed diffuse slowing 
w/o focal abnormalities. Tox screen was positive for cocaine and 
opiates. Toxicology saw the patient and advised conservative 
care. ABG showed 7.37/42/126 on 20% FiO2.  
.  
He was admitted to the MICU where he was hemodynamically stable, 
but continued to be unresponsive x 24 hours. On day of 
admission, he had 1 episode of a.flutter which broke with 
diltiazem and he did not have further episodes. He awoke on HD2 
during NGT placement. He refuses to identify himself and reports 
schizophrenia and not knowing his own identity. He was following 
verbal commands. He was started on continuous EEG and MRI of his 
head was without acute abnormalities.
.
Currently, he is awake and conversational. He endorses mild 
chest pain with deep breath and mild SOB. He endorses breaking 
into buildings - usually abandoned- and living in halls for the 
past few years. He had used crack earlier day of admission, ___ 
denies breaking and entering the school. He will not identify 
himself and denies recollection of events surrounding his 
presentation. He is able to give some medical history as below. 
C- spine cleared.
.
Review of sytems:  
(+) Per HPI, also endorses occassionally hearing "voices".
(-) Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations at baseline. 
Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain. 
Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. 
Denies cough, shortness of breath. No nausea, vomiting, 
diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in 
bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denied arthralgias or 
myalgias. 
 
Past Medical History:
h/o psychiatric illness - unknown but notes that he's seen 
outpatient psychiatrist in the past as well as been in inpatient 
psych. 
- endorses having been raped at an inpatient psych facility
current crack use- will not disclose amount- endorses use day of 
admission
current etoh use- will not disclose amount - says last drink was 
"1 week prior" though he had +etoh level
h/o multiple stabbings- scar from abdomen is from when he was 
little
G6PD +

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
sister w/diabetes; mother passed away with complications of 
sickle cell
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T 98, HR 72, BP 150/80, RR 20, 98% RA  
General: in neck brace, police cuffs on hands/leg 
HEENT: PERRL, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear dry MM, + mild 
conjunctival injection 
Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD  
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
ronchi  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops  
Abdomen: Large midabdominal scar noted, soft, non-tender, 
non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or 
guarding, no organomegaly  
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema
Neuro: oriented to situation, month, not aware of place, will 
not disclose person
Psych: appropriate though he does endorse "voices"
Skin: No rash, multiple scars

 
Pertinent Results:
MICROBIOLOGY:  
___ Blood Cx - no growth  
Urine Cx - no growth
.  
Imaging: 
___. No intracranial hemorrhage or fracture. 
2. Sinus disease, most significantly involving the right 
maxillary sinus. 
3. Punctate hyperdensity within the soft tissues overlying the 
frontal 
sinuses. Please correlate with physical exam for evidence of 
foreign body 

.  
___ C-SPINE CT: 
1. No fracture, malalignment or prevertebral soft tissue 
swelling. 
2. Degenerative changes at C5-6, with severe narrowing of the 
right neural foramen and moderate narrowing of the left neural 
foramen. 
3. Osteophytes at C3-4 and ___ also narrow the spinal canal. 
4. There is an old fracture of the C7 spinous process. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is an unfortunate young man who was admitted for 
unresponsiveness that was likely feigned in the setting of being 
arrested for breaking and entering. He was admitted to the ICU 
in police custody for unresponsiveness. EEG was negative for 
seizure activity, CT and MRI were negative for acute pathology 
including stroke, hemorrhage, or evidence of trauma though MRI 
revealed possible foreign body in his sinus. 
He has a severe crack cocaine addiction and also abuses Etoh. He 
had no evidence of withdrawal during his admission. He was seen 
by our neurology service as well as psychiatric service. He 
endorses "hearing voices" but the pscychiatric service did not 
feel that he had pscychosis, likely again feigned in the setting 
of his arrest. Social work consulted for his substance abuse 
issues as well as his homelessness. 
Upon admission, his CK levels were elevated but trended down 
with diuresis. His cardiac enzymes were negative and EKGs were 
with out ischemic changes.
He should be further assessed by the court clinical 
psychiatrist.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
none
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
substance abuse
Homelessness

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for unresponsiveness which resolved on the 
second day of your hospitaliztion. You were not found to have 
any acute neurologic issues. You were evaluated by our 
psychiatry service who felt that you should have further 
evaluation by the court psychiatrist.

Please have further evaluation by the court psychiatrist.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Mechanical fall
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right sided Chest tube placement

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o Male s/p mechanical fall in his bathtub 2 days ago while 
drunk. He did not seek immediate medical attention and stayed at 
home until ___ when he experienced intense right sided pain 
that prompted him to seek medical attention at ___. 
The pain was not associated with shortness of breath. At ___ 
CT chest showed contiguous right rib fractures ___ c/b
hemothorax, pulmonary contution and possible splenic hematoma. A 
chest tube was placed and the patient was transferred to ___ 
for further management. He remained hemodynamically stable at 
the ED but desating to 90% at RA and required 3L. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: none

PSH: none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAM ON ADMISSION
Vitals:98.2 96 130/88 22 96% 3L NC 
GEN: A&O, NAD
HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist
CV: RRR, No M/G/R
PULM: Chest tube on R. chest, no crepitus, tender to palpation.
ABD: mildy tender RUQ and guarding, normoactive bowel sounds, no 
palpable masses
Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused

PHYSICAL EXAM ON DISCHARGE
Vitals:97.9 82 134/76 18 94% 2L NC 
GEN: A&O, NAD
HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist
CV: RRR, No M/G/R
PULM: CTA b/l, chest tube incision C/D/I with pressure dressing 
in place
ABD: mildy tender RUQ and guarding, normoactive bowel sounds, no 
palpable masses
Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused

 
Pertinent Results:
___

137  ___   AGap=14 
-------------< 
4.0  22  0.8    

7.8 \ 12.3 / 209 
    / 35.9 \
 N:92.3 L:4.1 M:3.0 E:0.4 Bas:0.2 

___: 11.6  PTT: Pnd  INR: 1.1  

Imaging:

CT Chest (___): No images sent. Per report: Right rib 
fractures
___, hemothorax, and pulmonary contusion, possible liver
hematoma. 

CT Abdomen (___): R chest tube with small residual 
pneumothorax, basilar
atelectasis, and subcutaneous emphysema. A small right chest 
wall
hematoma surrounds the chest tube. In addition, there is a very
small subcapsular liver hematoma extending from chest tube along 
the right lateral surface of liver. It is unclear if liver 
hematoma is due to initial trauma of tube insertion which is 
ultimately intra-pleural or if the course of the tube is 
partially intra-peritoneal,though the latter is felt less likely 
significantly distended bladder 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented as detailed above and was admitted to the 
Acute Care Surgery service for management of his rib fractures, 
hemothorax and subcapsular hematoma. The plan was to ensure good 
pain control to ensure good ventilation, follow chest tube 
output and perform serial abdominal exams for the subcapsular 
hematoma. The patient remained hemodynamically stable on the 
floor and his chest tube output was low so his chest tube, which 
was initially kept to wall suction, was switched to waterseal on 
HD2. Follow-up CXR demonstrated good lung volumes and no 
pneumothorax so his chest tube was removed. A post-pull CXR was 
obtained to rule out any residual pneumothorax. By end of HD2 
the patient was maintaining his oxygen saturations on room air 
after being weaned off oxygen and his pain was under control on 
PO pain medications so he was discharged home with a scheduled 
follow up visit in the ___ clinic in 2 weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Duration: 10 Days 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID Duration: 10 Days 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Mechanical Fall; Right sided ___ rib fractures hemothorax and 
pulmonary contusion and small subcapsular liver hematoma.  

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
*  Your injury caused rib fractures on the right side of your 
rib cage which can cause severe pain and subsequently cause you 
to take shallow breaths because of the pain.

*  You should take your pain medication as directed to stay 
ahead of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep 
breaths. If the pain medication is too sedating take half the 
dose and notify your physician.

*  Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.

*  You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to 
hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing 
and deep breathing.

*  Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.

*  Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.

*  Do NOT smoke

*  If your doctor allows, non steroidal antiinflammatory drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.

*  Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs ( crepitus ).

* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour 
while awake.

* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.

* Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours.  If it 
starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change 
it  as needed to keep site clean and dry. 

* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.

* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions

* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry 

* No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed 

* No lotions or creams to incision site

* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

Come to the ED if you experience any of the following:
-Fevers > 101 or chills 
-Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other symptoms 
that concern you. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation
around your ribs ( crepitus ).
* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour
while awake.
* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or
drainage. Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.
* Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours. If it
starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change
it as needed to keep site clean and dry.
* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.
* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your
incisions
* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat
dry
* No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
* No lotions or creams to incision site
* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as
you can tolerate.
Come to the ED if you experience any of the following:
-Fevers > 101 or chills
-Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other symptoms
that concern you.
Followup Instructions:
___

prior

night sweats. He has noted onset of urinary incontinence while
sleeping around the time that he noted early abdominal
distention. He denies headaches, with decreased vision in R eye
x2 weeks. Denies rhinorrhea, sore throat, chest pain, SOB. He 
has
daily BMs, without melena or hematochezia.

O2 delivery: Ra

eating breakfast, in no apparent distress.

Posterior oropharynx without erythema or exudate, uvula midline.
Neck: Kyphotic neck. No lymphnodadenopathy.
CV: Regular rate and rhythm. Normal S1 S2, no S3, no S4. No
murmur. No JVD.
PULM: Breathing comfortably on room air. Lungs clear to
auscultation. No wheezes or crackles. Good air movement
bilaterally. 
GI: Bowel sounds present. Abdomen non-distended, soft, 
non-tender
to palpation. No HSM appreciated.
GU: Foley catheter in place draining dark red. No suprapubic
fullness or tenderness to palpation.
EXTR: Trace lower extremity edema. Distal extremity pulses
palpable throughout.
SKIN: No rashes, ulcerations, scars noted.

symmetric. Speech fluent. Moves all limbs spontaneously. No
tremors or other involuntary movements observed.

appropriately. Appropriate affect.

Labs: 
======
___ 05:55AM BLOOD WBC-9.2 RBC-3.79* Hgb-11.3* Hct-35.7* 
MCV-94 MCH-29.8 MCHC-31.7* RDW-13.6 RDWSD-47.3* Plt ___
___ 05:55AM BLOOD Glucose-93 UreaN-12 Creat-1.0 Na-141

1. Massively distended bladder measuring up to 25 x 16 x 21 cm
with bladder diverticula and dependent calculi suggesting 
chronic
bladder outlet obstruction versus neurogenic bladder. Foley
catheterization recommended for bladder decompression. 
2. Chronic severe left-sided hydroureteronephrosis with
left-sided renal atrophy, likely due to reflux.
3. Prostatomegaly.
4. Punctate hyperdensities in the right renal calices likely may
represent contrast excretion versus nonobstructing
nephrolithiasis.
5. Moderate-to-large hiatal hernia.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with hx of EtOH use disorder presenting with abdominal
distention and bilateral ___ edema, found to have massively
distended bladder, likely ___ BPH with resulting obstruction.

==================================

# Urinary retention: 
# BPH: 
Volume of urine retention and radiographic findings
suggest chronic process, likely with progressive urethral
obstruction ___ BPH, with relief of obstruction in the ED. Per

- discharged with Foley
- discharged on Tamsulosin 0.4 QHS
- set up with ___ nursing visits
- Set up with urology f/up appointment next week

Gross hematuria noted in the ___, likely related to some
trauma from the Foley. Resolved after IV fluids. Stable Hgb.

___ massively distended bladder. Resolved completely.

None

Home With Service
 
Facility:

Prostate enlargement
Urinary retention

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were referred to the Emergency Room by your primary care 
doctor because of lower leg swelling.

You were found to have a very distended bladder because you 
weren't able to pee normally. A urinary catheter was placed 
which allowed your urine out.

You developing some mild bleeding that is likely due to the 
urinary catheter and has now mostly resolved.

You are safe to go home today.

=========================

=========================

instructions

supplies
- Please take your new medication, Tamsulosin, daily before 
sleep
- You have follow-up appointments with urology and primary care

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

text:
Name:  ___.             Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Bactrim
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Vision changes and Headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old female with a past medical 
history significant for right frontal oligodendrocytoma s/p 
resction and colon cancer s/p resection now admitted with 
temporal headache and eye pain. The patient reports that the 
night before admission she developed a right-sided headache that 
was described as "dull and throbbing" with pain radiating down 
her jaw that was worse with brushing her teeth. The morning of 
presentation to the ED, the patient states that she developed a 
stabbing left retroorbital headache with associated blurriness, 
and a co-worker immediately noticed that she had blood in her 
eye. The patient denies any f/c/s, n/v/d, myalgias, weakness, 
joint pain or pain with movement, abdominal pain, palpitations.
.
In the ___ ED, initial VS initial VS 98.3 87 161/82 12 98%RA. 
The patient was noted to have conjunctival hemorrhage, with labs 
notable for a CRP 0.6 and ESR 10. She received 60 mg prednisone 
and heparin, and Rheumatology and Ophthamology were consulted. 
Ophtho exam with ___ OD/OS, right medial subconjunctival 
hemorrhage, and a normal slit lamp exam. The patient was then 
admitted to Medicine for further management.
 
Past Medical History:
Colon cancer s/p resection and chemotherapy
Right frontal oligodendrocytoma s/p resection. Followed Dr. 
___ at ___, with unchanged MRI 3 months ago.
Hyperlipidemia
Hypothyroid
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother with breast cancer at age ___.
 
Physical Exam:
Vital signs: afebrile o/n 120/76 P 68 98%RA
.
Gen: Well appearing adult in NAD. Pleasant and cooperative. 
AOx3.
Neck: Supple. No cervical LAP.
HEENT: EOMI although with R eye discomfort at extreme lateral 
gaze and ? mild blurring of vision by patient report with EOMI 
exam!; PERRLA, MMM, OP pink w/o ulcers injection or exudates.
Temporal arteries palpable bilaterally, inf jaw arterial 
pulsation noted bilaterally; + TTP mild over R temporal region 
extending over region of parietal scalp; no e/o vesicles / skin 
changes on exam; hearing on R intact to soft whisper
Chest: CTA w/o W/R/R.
Cor: RRR, S1S2, No MRG.
Abd: S/ND/NT, no HSM.
Extrem: Warm, 2+ radial and pedal pulses, no C/C/E.
Comprehensive Musc Skel:
 Jaw, neck without limited ROM.
 Shoulders, elbows, wrists, hands, fingers: no deformity, 
erythema, warmth, swelling, effusion, tenderness, limited ROM.
 Lumbosacral spine and hips without limited ROM.
 Knee, ankles, feet, toes: no deformity, erythema, warmth, 
swelling, effusion, tenderness, limited ROM.
Neuro: Good comprehension/cognition. CN ___ intact. Muscle 
strength ___ in all extremities. No sensory deficits. Reflexes 
intact. Gait not observed.
Skin: No alopecia, nail change, rash, bruising, petechiae, 
telangiectasia, icterus, tophi, or nodules.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:29PM BLOOD WBC-7.9 RBC-4.75 Hgb-14.2 Hct-39.4 MCV-83 
MCH-29.9 MCHC-36.0* RDW-13.0 Plt ___
.
.
___ 06:29PM BLOOD ESR-10
___ 08:10AM BLOOD ESR-4
.
.
___ 06:29PM BLOOD Glucose-112* UreaN-9 Creat-0.9 Na-139 
K-4.3 Cl-101 HCO3-28 AnGap-14
.
.
___ 06:29PM BLOOD CRP-0.6
___ 08:10AM BLOOD CRP-0.6
.
.
___ CT Orbit
IMPRESSION: No CT evidence of hemorrhage within or around the 
right globe.
Minimal preseptal soft tissue edema, without abnormal 
collections.
.
.
___ CT Head Without Contrast
IMPRESSION:
1. Status post resection of a right frontal oligodendrocytoma 
with frontal
lobe hypodensities likely representing post-surgical changes and
encephalomalacia. MRI can help for further assessment.
2. No acute hemorrhage or infarction is detected.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was a ___ year old female with a past medical 
history significant for right frontal oligodendrocytoma s/p 
resection and colon cancer s/p resection who was admitted with 
temporal headache and eye pain.
.
# Headache, eye pain: The differential included temporal 
arteritis, trigeminal neuralgia, and Herpes ophthalmicus. 
Symptoms of headache, temporal tenderness, and jaw pain are 
consistent with GCA, although low-normal inflammatory markers 
made this less likely; although GCA with normal ESR/CRP has been 
reported. Herpes ophthalmicus was also a possibility, although 
symptoms would be very early as no skin lesions are noted and 
corneal involvement also not noted on exam by Ophthalmology. 
Trigeminal neuralgia is also a potential etiology, although the 
constant nature of the pain makes this less likely. The 
patient's history of a right frontal brain tumor raised the 
concern for relapse with compression of the trigeminal root. 
Rheumatology was consulted and recommended temporal artery 
biopsy to rule out GCA. An outpatient biopsy was arranged with 
vascular surgery and outpatient rheumatology follow up with 
close neuro-oncology and neuro-ophthalmology surveillance was 
strongly advised. She was started on prednisone 60 mg daily and 
was asked to continue this dose until outpatient follow up with 
rheumatology.
.
# Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Unclear significance and 
association with headache and jaw pain. This may have occurred 
in setting of valsalva from pain as reported in HPI.
- Serial exams
.
# Hyperlipidemia: Continue atorvastatin
.
# Hypothyroid: Continue levothyroxine
.
FEN: Regular, replete as necessary
Prophylaxis: Heparins SQ
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
2. Atorvastatin 40 mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Levothyroxine 50 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
2. Atorvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Acetaminophen 650 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six 
(6) hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: Six (6) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*180 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Oxycodone 5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO every ___ 
hours as needed for pain for 7 days.
Disp:*25 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Temporal Arteritis
Headache
Hypothyroidism 
Hyperlipidemia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with headaches and eye pain. 
You were evaluated by the medicine, ophthalmology, rheumatology 
and vasular surgery services. You headache and eyepain 
significantly improved. You should follow up with your 
outpatient physcians as described in this discharge document. 
You should take you home medication as decribed in this 
discharge document.
.
The following changes were made to your home medications:
ADDED Prenisone 60 mg by mouth daily untill your follow up visit 
with your Rheumatologist.  
ADDED Oxycodone as needed for pain. You should not drive or 
drink alcohol while taking this medication as it can cause 
drowsiness.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Patient is a ___ year-old man with history of VT s/p ablation 
admitted with alcohol intoxication.

# Respiratory Failure: Patient was intubated at ___ 
for airway protection in the setting of obtundation. Patient was 
considerably more alert on arrival to the MICU and was arousable 
and follwing commands. Sedation was stopped and he was extubated 
promptly.

# Alcohol Intoxication: Patient was admitted in the setting of 
alcohol intoxication requiring intubation for airway protection 
in the setting of obtundation.  Patient has a history of 
alcoholism and binge drinking. He has no history of withdrawl 
from alcohol. He was given multivitamin IV bag. He was seen by 
social work. He was counseled on staying abstinent from alcohol. 


# History of VT - Patient has a questionable history VT s/p 
ablation in ___.

- Lexapro

PO once a day.

4. multivitamin     Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day.

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: Alcohol intoxication, respiratory failure

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

You were admitted to the intensive care unit at ___ 
___ because you needed a breathing tube 
placed while you were intoxicated. As the alcohol wore off, you 
woke up and we were able to remove the breathing tube. 

You should avoid alcohol and should enter a program such as 
alcoholics anonomyous to help you stay sober. 

You should take a multivitamin daily. No other changes were made 
to your medications. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___             Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: CARDIOTHORACIC
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Increasing shortness of breath
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Atrial Septal Defect Repair with Bovine Pericardial 
Patch, and Atrial Thrombectomy 
 
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ yo female with increasing SOB over past 3 
weeks, associated with a 20 punds weight gain. She also noted 
acrocyanosis one week prior to admission. Echo at outside 
hospital reported large atrial septal defect wtih primarily left 
to right shunt. There was moderate right ventricular dilatation, 
moderate right ventricular hypokinesis with moderate pulmonary 
hypertension. Echo also notable for a four centimeter clot in 
the right atrium. Prior to surgical intervention, she underwent 
cardiac catheterization which revealed normal coronary arteries. 
She was transferred to the ___ for cardiac surgical 
intervention.
 
Past Medical History:
Atrial Septal Defect with Right Atrial Thrombus 
Pulmonary Hypertension
Obesity  
History of Atrial Fibrillation  
?Obstructive Sleep Apnea  
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Denies premature coronary disease/sudden death.
 
Physical Exam:
PREOP EXAM:
Vitals: 98.7, 101/60, 92, 18, 95% 3L
NAD lying in bed
Neuro A&O nonfocal exam
Lungs with decreased breath sounds at both bases, fine crackles
Heart Irregular
Abdomen benign, obese
Extrem warm, 2+ BLE edema, Rash on bilateral ankles
 
Pertinent Results:
___ Transthoracic ECHO: The left atrium is mildly dilated.A 
left-to-right shunt across the interatrial septum is seen at 
rest across a large secundum atrial septal defect. There is mild 
symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size 
and global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Due to suboptimal 
technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be 
fully excluded. The right ventricular cavity is moderately 
dilated with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. The number 
of aortic valve leaflets cannot be determined. There is no 
aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The 
mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral 
regurgitation. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There 
is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is a 
trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 
___ Intraop TEE: PREBYPASS: A definite large (3.1cmx2cm) 
thrombus in the right atrial appendage. There is a bidirectional 
shunt across the interatrial septum at rest. A large secundum 
atrial septal defect is present. The left ventricular cavity 
size is normal. There is mild global left ventricular 
hypokinesis (LVEF = 45-50 %). The right ventricular cavity is 
markedly dilated with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. The 
ascending, transverse and descending thoracic aorta are normal 
in diameter and free of atherosclerotic plaque. The aortic valve 
leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet 
excursion. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve 
leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation 
is seen. POSTBYPASS: Pt was removed from cardiopulmonary bypass 
on epinephrine and phenylephrine infusions and was AV paced. 1. 
The large ASD has been subsequently repaired; there is no 
evidence of flow across the intraatrial septum. 2. The RV 
remains markedly dilated with moderate global hypokinesis. 3. LV 
remains with mild left ventricular hypokinesis without evidence 
of regional wall abnormalities. 4. Aortic contours are intact 
post decannulation.
___ CXR: The cardiomegaly is unchanged. The post-sternotomy 
wires are intact. Bibasilar consolidations consistent with 
atelectasis are grossly unchanged, still significant. There is 
no appreciable pleural effusion, and there is no pneumothorax.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
She was started on a heparin drips. She was started on cipro for 
a UTI. She was taken to the operating room on ___ where she 
underwent an atrial thrombectomy and ASD repair. She was 
transferred to the ICU in critical but stable condition on epi 
and propofol. She was given 48 hours of vancomycin as she was in 
the hospital preoperatively. She was extubated later that same 
day. She was started on fluconazole for the rash on her ankles. 
She was started on coumadin. She was transferred to the floor on 
POD #1.  Over the next several days the patient was gently 
diuresed, she was started on Bblockers and was anticoagulated. 
She has been in AFib with a rapid ventricular rate, up to the 
140's with activity.  By POD #7, after her Lopressor had been 
increased, her heart rate was better controlled. She was also 
started on Keflex for an IV site phlebitis. She is now stable, 
and ready to be discharged home.  Her Coumadin will be followed 
by the ___ (___), ___ has been 
notified, and records faxed to her there.
 
Medications on Admission:
Home: Aspirin, MVI 
Transfer: Lisinopril 2.5 qd, Aspirin 81 qd, Lasix IV 40 bid, 
Nexium 40 qd, IV Heparin, Metoprolol 50 tid, Silver Sulfa Cream, 
Colace, KCL 40 qd, Digoxin 0.125 qd, Vitamin C, Zinc
 
Discharge Medications:
 
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).
Disp:*30 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Warfarin 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO ONCE (Once): take 
1 tablet (5 mg) daily for 2 days, then as directed by ___ 
___ ___.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Furosemide 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day for 
10 days.
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
7. Potassium Chloride 20 mEq Tab Sust.Rel. Particle/Crystal Sig: 
Two (2) Tab Sust.Rel. Particle/Crystal PO once a day for 10 
days.
Disp:*20 Tab Sust.Rel. Particle/Crystal(s)* Refills:*0*
8. Amiodarone 200 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO once a day: 
Please take two 200mg tablets once daily for 7days. Then one 
200mg once daily until stopped by cardiologist.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
9. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO TID 
(3 times a day).
Disp:*270 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
10. Cephalexin 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) for 5 days.
Disp:*20 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Atrial Septal Defect with Right Atrial Thrombus - s/p Repair
Acute Right Heart Failure
Preoperative Urinary Tract Infection
Lower Extremity Rash
Obesity
History of Atrial Fibrillation
?Obstructive Sleep Apnea
 
Discharge Condition:
Good
 
Discharge Instructions:
 
1)Please shower daily. No baths. Pat dry incisions, do not rub.
2)Avoid creams and lotions to surgical incisions.
3)Call for redness or drainage from surgical wounds
4)No lifting more than 10 lbs for at least 10 weeks from 
surgical date.
5)No driving for at least one month.
6)Monitor ___ every ___, and ___ until INR stablizes. 
___ Health Clinic will manage Coumadin dosing as outpatient. 
___ should call or fax results to clinic. Goal INR is between 
2.0 - 3.0.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: RADIOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Flexeril
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Fibroids, menorrhagia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
uterine artery embolization, bilateral
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old female (G8P3), with past medical history significant 
for borderline hypertension, elevated cholesterol, and history 
of uterine fibroids, menorrhagia, and anemia is transfered to 
medicine service s/p uterine artery embolization for post-op 
bradycardia. Post-procedure patient became bradycardic to ___, 
with stable BP, nausea, and 6 sec block observed on telemetry. 
EKG showed 1st degree AV block. Patient denied SOB, CP, 
vomiting, LOC, or diaphoresis during this event. At the time, 
she noted significant pain.  
  
Right groin sheath removed at 12noon. Patient denied groin pain 
or sensory changes. Dose have band of b/l lower back pain, ___ 
dull, achy.  

ROS: Denies prior chest pain, palpitations, h/o arrhythmia, 
valvular heart disease, previous syncope. 

 
Past Medical History:
Iron-deficiency Anemia  
Menorrhagia ___ Fibroids  
s/p breast reduction  
Borderline Hypertension  
hypercholesterolemia  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother - ___, h/o CHF. No family history of sudden 
death, arrhythmia or early MI. 
 
Physical Exam:
VS - T 98.2 HR 56 BP 140/85 POx 100% on 3LNC  
Gen: WDWN obese young female in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect 
appropriate. Drowsy, but easily arrousable.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  

Neck: Supple with JVP at clavicle lying flat.  
CV: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. 
RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. HS 
distant.  
Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, 
wheezes or rhonchi.  
Abd: +suprapubic TTP. Obese, Soft, ND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd 
aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. Right 
groin without tenderness, no ecchymosis, no hematoma, no bruit.  

Ext: WWP. No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. Sensation intact.  
Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.  
.  
Pulses:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  

 
Pertinent Results:
Admission Labs:
___ 08:40AM   WBC-6.3 RBC-4.31 HGB-11.6* HCT-36.4 MCV-85 
MCH-26.9* MCHC-31.8 RDW-15.8*
___ 08:40AM   NEUTS-53.4 ___ MONOS-3.6 EOS-2.9 
BASOS-0.8
___ 04:30PM   WBC-6.8 RBC-3.87* HGB-10.6* HCT-32.8* MCV-85 
MCH-27.4 MCHC-32.3 RDW-15.9*
___ 04:30PM   PLT COUNT-364
___ 04:30PM   CALCIUM-8.9 PHOSPHATE-2.5* MAGNESIUM-1.8
___ 04:30PM   CK-MB-2 cTropnT-<0.01
___ 04:30PM   CK(CPK)-134
___ 07:10PM   WBC-7.5 RBC-3.91* HGB-11.0* HCT-33.1* MCV-85 
MCH-28.1 MCHC-33.2 RDW-17.1*

EKG demonstrated first degree AV block at rate of 62 with no 
prior for comparison.  
TELEMETRY demonstrated:NSR at 68  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ yo female (G8P3), with history for borderline 
hypertension, elevated cholesterol, and history of uterine 
fibroids, menorrhagia, and anemia who was transfered to medicine 
service s/p planned uterine artery embolization for post-op 
bradycardia.  
 
#. Bradycardia - Episode of bradycardia in the setting of 
post-op pain and associated nausea in a patient with no prior 
history of heart disease or arrhythmia is most likely consistent 
with high vagal tone. Patient had 1st degree AV block and one 
run of second degree ___. Patient was provided with 
adequate pain control and found to be in NSR with rates in the 
80-90s on day of discharge. 
  
#. Uterine Fibroids s/p UAE - Patient underwent uncomplicated 
b/l uterine artery embolization on ___. Right groin site 
without sign of hematoma. Baseline Hct around 34 which remained 
stable. Patient was maintained on dilaudid PCA overnight and 
switched to po regimen on the am of discharge. Patient sent home 
with po percocet/ibuprofen and to continue home iron 
supplementation after successful voiding trial.  
   
#. FEN - Regular diet. Monitored and repleted lytes prn.  
 
#. Access: PIV x2  
 
#. PPx: Heparin SC TID, no bowel regimen/PPI necessary  
 
#. Code: FULL  
 
#. Dispo: To home with stable hematocrit and pain controlled.  

 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins  
iron  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day).  
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain for 7 days.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) for 7 days: take with food.
Disp:*28 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day: 
stool softener, use while taking iron.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
fibroid
menorrhagia
vagally-induced first degree heart block and bradycardia
 
Discharge Condition:
Vital Stable, voiding, tolerating po.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were treated with uterine artery embolization for your 
fibroids.  Please continue to take percocet and ibuprofen as 
needed for pain control over the next week.

Post-procedure, you developed a slow heart rate.  This was most 
likely a vagal-nerve mediated reaction to pain combined with the 
sedating effects of pain medications, and resolved 
spontaneously. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Testosterone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
___ s/p ESWL for large Left renal stones now with symptomatic 
ureteral obstruction. Reports progresively worsening abdominal 
and flank pain, and nausea without vomiting. Denies fever, 
chills, dysuria, hematuria. Has not had bowel movement since 
ESWL. 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
THIS ADMISSION: ___ s/p CYSTOSCOPY, LEFT URETERAL STENT 
PLACEMENT

s/p ___ PROCEDURE:  Left extracorporeal shock wave 
lithotripsy.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p ESWL for large Left renal stones now with symptomatic 
ureteral obstruction. Reports progresively worsening abdominal 
and flank pain, and nausea without vomiting. Denies fever, 
chills, dysuria, hematuria. Has not had bowel movement since 
ESWL. Initial evaluation with positive urinalysis and 
leukocytosis. Urology evaluation significant for symptomatic 
obstructive uropathy in need of supportive care with IVF, PO/IV 
analgesics, and ureteral stent placement. Hospitalized for 
further evaluation and treatment. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMH:  
HTN  
Chronic back pain  
PSH: Tonsillectomy, vasectomy, disc surgery, and testicular 
surgery.  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam on date of discharge:
WdWn male, NAD, AVSS
Flank/Abdomen soft, nt/nd
Extremites w/out edema/pitting

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:08PM BLOOD WBC-13.0* RBC-5.16 Hgb-15.3 Hct-42.3 
MCV-82 MCH-29.6 MCHC-36.2* RDW-13.4 Plt ___
___ 03:08PM BLOOD Glucose-136* UreaN-20 Creat-1.2 Na-141 
K-3.6 Cl-104 HCO3-28 AnGap-13
___ 04:18PM URINE  BLOOD-LG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-7.0 
LEUK-TR
___ 04:18PM URINE  RBC-48* WBC-3 BACTERIA-FEW YEAST-NONE 
EPI-0
___ 03:08PM   WBC-13.0* RBC-5.16 HGB-15.3 HCT-42.3 MCV-82 
MCH-29.6 MCHC-36.2* RDW-13.4
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to Dr. ___ service from the ED 
for overnight
observation, pain control, and IV fluids and IV antibiotics. He 
was monitored for fever, nausea and vomiting and prepared for 
ureteral stent placement on hospital day one. He had good pain 
control and denied overnight new complaints/problems so he was 
taken to the OR on HD1 and he underwent the above procedure 
(cystoscopy and LEFT ureteral stent placement).  No concerning 
intra-operative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for full details.  The patient received ___ 
antibiotic prophylaxis.  At the end of the procedure the patient 
was extubated and transported to the PACU for further recovery 
before being transferred to the floor.  He was transferred from 
the PACU in stable condition to the general surgical floor. He 
voided prior to discharge. At discharge Mr. ___ pain was 
well controlled with oral pain medications and he was tolerating 
a regular diet and ambulating without assistance and voiding 
without difficulty. He was given explicit instructions to 
follow-up with Dr. ___ definitive stone management and 
ureteral stent removal/exchange.

 
Medications on Admission:
MEDS:  
Lipitor 10'  
diltiazem ER 360'  
HCTZ 37.5'  
Flomax 0.4' ? taking for stone or regularly  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. phenazopyridine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day) for 3 days.
Disp:*9 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. atorvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime).  
4. diltiazem HCl 180 mg Capsule, Extended Release Sig: Two (2) 
Capsule, Extended Release PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
6. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
7. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).  
8. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
9. hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO DAILY 
(Daily): (37.5mg TOTAL per day).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Symptomatic ureteral obstruction (s/p ___ LEFT ESWL for 
large renal stones) 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Resume all of your pre-admission/ home medications, unless 
otherwise noted. Please avoid Aspirin unless otherwise advised. 

-No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.

-Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequency over the next month.

-You may have already passed your kidney stones OR they may 
still be in the process of passing.

-You may experience some pain associated with spasm of your 
ureter. This is normal. Take IBUPROFEN as directed and take the 
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief 
is needed.

-If you are taking Ibuprofen (Brand names include ___ 
this should always be taken with food. If you develop stomach 
pain or note black stool, stop the Ibuprofen. Ibuprofen works 
best when taken around the clock.

-You have been given an prescription for PYRIDIUM which can turn 
your urine dark orange--this is normal. Please read the 
instructions that come with this medication. 

-Please do NOT drive, operate dangerous machinery, or consume 
alcohol while taking narcotic pain medications.

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to help keep yourself 
hydrated and facilitate passage of stone fragments.

-You may shower and bathe normally.

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics or operate 
dangerous machinery

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative

-IT IS IMPERATIVE that you follow up as advised as the 
indwelling ureteral stent must be removed or exchanged--it is 
NOT permanent.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

-IT IS IMPERATIVE that you follow up as advised as the
indwelling ureteral stent must be removed or exchanged--it is
NOT permanent.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Vancomycin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Cellulitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a healthy ___ year old female with history of severe hot 
water burn of both knees in youth complicated by scarring who 
presents for a wound evaluation three weeks after a disk 
excision of an atypical nevus. The patient has been doing 
relatively well after her surgery but noted some increased 
swelling, discomfort, and redness around the site of her 
excision starting three days prior to her ED presentation. On 
the day prior to her ED presentation she was seen by her derm 
surgeon who saw some surrounding erythema and a bit of yellow 
fibrinous material at the wound base and recommended a course of 
doxycycline for presumed cellulitis. The patient did not have 
time to fill the prescription but then noted some dark tissue at 
the base of the wound and increased redness today. She called in 
and spoke to her dermatologist again and sent some pictures and 
that provider recommended she come into the ED for evaluation. 
The patient denies any fevers or chills. She report prior to 
three days ago she had no redness surrounding her excision site 
just an open wound. She denies any pain when the area is not 
being moved or manipulated but has pain when one pushes around 
the open area or when she moves the knee, which is new. Aside 
from these symptoms she has felt well.  

 
In the ED VS T 98.4, P 96, BP 125/70, RR 16, O2 100% on RA. Labs 
were unremarkable with no leukocytosis. Exam notable for open 
area with dark eschar and surrounding erythema. She received one 
dose of IV vanc for presumed cellulitis. Because of the area of 
dark tissue at the wound base the ED team felt uncomfortable 
obs'ing the patient and therefore she is being admitted to 
medicine. Of note, pt developed total body itching with vanco 
and some flushing and therefore received diphenhydramine 50 mg 
IV *1 with good improvement in her symptoms.  
 
Currently, she reports no pain at rest and is comfortably dozing 
prior to being awoken by the night float.  

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: She denies any fevers, chills, night sweats 
or unintentional weight loss. No chest pain or SOB. No abdominal 
pain, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. No palpitations or 
lightheadedness. Denies abdominal pain. Denies any muscle or 
joint aches. No skin changes outside the affected area until 
itching from the vanc.  
 
Past Medical History:
Car accident/burn (she is unclear of the details) at age ___ 
leaving scarring over both knees  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
She denies any skin conditions. 
 
Physical Exam:
On admission: 
VS: T 99.7, BP 114/80, P 84, RR 16, O2 98% on RA  
Gen: Thin, young Asian woman in NAD  
HEENT: Normocephalic, anicteric, OP benign, MMM  
CV: RRR, no M/R/G; there is no jugular venous distension 
appreciated; DP pulses 2+ bilaterally  
Pulm: Expansion equal bilaterally, Resonant to percussion 
bilaterally, CTAB  
Abd:Soft, NT, ND, BS+, no organomegaly or masses appreciated  
Extrem: Warm and well perfused, no C/C/E  
Neuro: A and O*3  
Skin: There is hyperkeratotic skin with ridging and skin 
thickening over both knees consistent with old burn scars. On 
the lateral aspect of the left leg just below the knee there is 
an approximately 2 cm *2cm ulcer with black eschar at the base. 
There is a few inch area of erythema and induration surrounding 
this with no subcutaneous crepitus on exam.  

On discharge: 
2 x 2 cm area inferior/lateral to left knee with black eshcar; 
only very faint erythema that extends to marker borders around L 
knee; somewhat limited ROM (limited by pain) with L knee flexion
 
Pertinent Results:
On admission: 
___ 12:50AM BLOOD WBC-7.0# RBC-3.79* Hgb-12.2 Hct-34.7* 
MCV-92 MCH-32.0 MCHC-35.0 RDW-12.0 Plt ___
___ 12:50AM BLOOD Neuts-66.3 ___ Monos-5.1 Eos-0.5 
Baso-0.7
___ 12:50AM BLOOD Glucose-84 UreaN-15 Creat-0.5 Na-137 
K-3.3 Cl-99 HCO3-28 ___ Wound culture: pending

L tibia/fibula fracture: Soft tissue swelling, probably due to 
infection or bleeding in 
the left lower extremity. No subcutaneous emphysema or 
radiographic evidence 
of osteomyelitis.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
1. Cellulitis: Patient received 1 dose of Vancomycin in the ED - 
to which she had a red rash and received IV Benadryl. Wound swab 
was performed. WBC was 7. She was admitted briefly to observe 
the area of cellulitis. On the day of discharge, the 2x2cm site 
of nevus excision(inferior/lateral to left knee) was covered by 
a superficial, black eschar. There was an area of faint erythema 
that extended over the patient's kneecap - marker borders were 
drawn. She mentioned somewhat limited ROM in the left knee due 
to pain/stretching with knee flexion. She was afebrile and 
without signs/symptoms of systemic illness. She was discharged 
to complete a 10-day course of doxycycline and with a Rx for PO 
fluconazole in anticipation of potential yeast infection. She 
had dermatology follow-up within 1 week. 

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. doxycycline hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
Q12H (every 12 hours) for 7 days: avoid the son while on this 
medication as it may cause a rash.
Disp:*14 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
2. fluconazole 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day 
for 1 doses: fill if symptoms of yeast infection.
Disp:*1 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
-Cellulitis

Secondary Diagnosis:
-Atypical nevus s/p excision

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted because of a skin infection on your leg.  This 
looked a bit atypical but you never had a fever or signs of 
systemic infection.  You are being discharged to complete a 
course or antibiotics by mouth.  

Your medications have been changed.  You have been started on a 
course of doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 7 days.  You also 
have a prescription for fluconazole which you can fill if you 
have symptoms of a yeast infection including vaginal itching, 
irritation or discharge, which may occur on this antibiotic.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
