text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
lightheadedness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with h/o mantle cell lymphoma s/p R-CHOP, 
alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy with EF 50-55% on ___, 
presenting with lightheadedness and hypotension.  Patient 
reports that he went to ___ on the day of 
admission for a scheduled stress test.  He exercised without 
issue, with mild shortness of breath and no chest pain or 
tightness.  While waiting for images following exercise, he 
became lightheaded.  He denies associated chest pain, shortness 
of breath, nausea/vomiting.  His blood pressure was checked at 
that time and was systolic 98.  He went home at that time, and 
continued to feel very fatigued.  He ate for the first time, and 
drank water, as he attributed the lightheadedness to fasting 
overnight for the test.  He also took his metoprolol succinate 
25mg at that time.  

He then went to his scheduled appointment with his hematologist, 
Dr. ___ he was noted to be hypotensive to systolic 95 
and bradycardic to ___. 

Labs were notable for Cr 1.5 from baseline 0.8-1.0.  EKG was 
unchanged from prior. His port site was noted to be slightly 
pink and blood cultures were drawn. He received 1L NS with 
improvement in BP and was admitted to the cardiology service for 
further work-up.
 
On arrival to the floor, vital signs were T 97.9 BP 138/72 HR 54 
RR 18 O2 100% RA.  Patient denied ongoing lightheadedness or 
fatigue. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
He denies fever, chills, dysuria, cough, shortness of breath.  
He had one episode of diarrhea following the stress test, but 
denies abdominal pain or further episodes.  He denies any past 
or present history of anginal symptoms.  He becomes more 
dyspneic on exertion in the past several months since beginning 
chemotherapy, which he attributes to deconditioning.  He denies 
ankle swelling, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea or 
palpitations.  

 
Past Medical History:
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: +Dyslipidemia 
2. CARDIAC HISTORY:  
- depressed EF 50-55% (___)- h/o CMP thought to be alcohol 
induced, EF in ___ was ___
3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
- Mantle cell lymphoma - diagnosed ___. Treated in
___ with R-CVP chemotherapy from ___ to ___.
Adriamycin held from regimen given depressed EF of ___ thought 
to be an alcohol induced cardiomyopathy. He is currently 
undergoing assessment for autologous stem cell transplant. 
- Basal cell carcinoma - excised from back x 2. 
- history of gout
- s/p appendectomy
- s/p tonsillectomy
- s/p knee arthoscopy x 3
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother died of CVA 
Father died of 'complications of diabetes'
Paternal gradnfather died of stroke
No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or 
sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory. 
 
Physical Exam:
Admission PE:
VS- T 97.9 BP 138/72 HR 54 RR 18 O2 100% RA 
GENERAL- Well appearing man in NAD, sitting comfortably in chair
HEENT- NCAT, PERRL, oropharynx clear with dentures in place, no 
erythema or lesions 
NECK- Supple with JVP below clavicle
CARDIAC- PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. RRR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or 
S4.  
LUNGS-  CTA bilaterally, no wheezes, ronchi, or rales 
ABDOMEN- +BS, soft, NTND
EXTREMITIES- No c/c/e. No femoral bruits.  
SKIN- Port site on right chest with minimal pink tinge, 
non-erythematous, no warmth or tenderness, no exudate
No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.  
PULSES-  
Right: DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: DP 2+ ___ 2+ 

Discharge PE:
VSS, chest pain free
Orthostatics negative
Exam otherwise unchanged
 
Pertinent Results:
Admission labs:
___ 12.8 Hgb 12.5  Hct 37.7  Plts 255   
 N:77.6 L:14.6 M:4.2 E:2.4 Bas:1.1 

137  101  24     
-------------< 
5.1  27  1.5  

Ca: 9.9 Mg: 2.2 P: 4.3

ALT: 27 AST: 20  AP: 64 Tbili: 0.4 LDH: 135  
UricA:6.2 

MICROBIOLOGY:
Blood culture ___- pending, no growth to date

IMAGING:  
EKG ___ @ 17:20- Sinus bradycardia @ 47, normal axis, normal 
intervals, no ST-T wave abnormalities, Q waves in II, III, avF
 
Transthoracic echocardiogram ___:  The left atrium is mildly 
dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. 
The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. Left 
ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. 
Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left 
ventricular systolic function is low normal (LVEF 50-55%). The 
estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are 
normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal 
with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic 
regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with 
trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. 
The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. 
There is no pericardial effusion. 
   IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular cavity size with normal 
regional and low normal global systolic function.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with h/o mantle cell lymphoma s/p R-CHOP (minus 
adriamycin) and presumed alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy with EF 
50-55% on ___ presenting with lightheadedness and hypotension 
following stress test. 
 
# Lightheadedness/hypotension- Patient's symptoms began after 
fasting overnight and exercise, and were likely exacerbated by 
taking his home dose of metoprolol.  Hypotension did not occur 
during exercise, only during recovery phase so much less 
concerning for ACS.  Patient was ruled out overnight with 
negative cardiac enzymes.  In addition, he was chest pain free 
throughout admission and had no EKG changes.  Blood culture were 
negative to date, with low suspicion for infection as underlying 
cause of hypotension. He was fluid responsive at ___ 
clinic, and blood pressures remained stable throughout 
admission.  Orthostatics were negative at the time of discharge. 
 Lisinopril was held secondary to elevated creatinine, and 
metoprolol was decreased to 12.5mg succinate given hypotension.  

 
# Alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy- Patient had depressed EF of 
___ during pre-chemotherapy work-up in ___.  This 
was attributed to long-term, excessive alcohol use.  Patient was 
started on lisinopril and metoprolol at that time, and has 
significantly cut down on his alcohol and tobacco intake.  His 
most recent echo in ___ showed an improved EF to 50-55%.  
Patient has no evidence of decompensation during admission with 
flat neck veins, no lower extremities edema and clear lungs. As 
above, home metoprolol was decreased and lisinopril was held 
given ARF.

# Acute renal failure- Creatinine elevated to 1.5.  Likely 
prerenal, supporting theory that hypotension was due to 
hypovolemia.  Creatinine trended down, and lisinopril was held 
at the time of discharge to be restarted by cardiologist in 
follow-up.

# Mantle cell lymphoma- s/p R-CHOP (without adriamycin given 
cardiomyopathy), now preparing for stem cell transplant. No 
active issues during admission. 

# Transitional issues-
- metoprolol succinate decreased to 12.5mg daily, lisinopril 
held on discharge
 
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril 7.5 mgs daily
Metoprolol Succinate 25 mgs daily
Rosuvastatin 20 mgs daily
Multivitamin
Omega-3 Fatty Acids
 
Discharge Medications:
1. rosuvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
2. metoprolol succinate 25 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: 
0.5 Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO once a day.  
3. multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
4. omega-3 fatty acids  Oral

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis:
# Hypotension due to dehydration
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
admission.

You were admitted with low blood pressure and lightheadedness.  
You received IV fluids and your pressure improved.  You had 
blood tests and EKGs which showed you were not having a heart 
attack.  Your symptoms and low blood pressure were likely 
related to fasting for you stress test and becoming dehydrated 
with exercise. 

You will be discharged home to complete your stress test 
imaging.

The following changes were made to your medication regimen:
- STOP lisinopril 
- DECREASE metoprolol to 12.5mg (split the pill in half!)
continue the remainder of your medications without changes
 
Followup Instructions:
___

taking his home dose of metoprolol. Hypotension did not occur
during exercise, only during recovery phase so much less
concerning for ACS. Patient was ruled out overnight with
negative cardiac enzymes. In addition, he was chest pain free
throughout admission and had no EKG changes. Blood culture were
negative to date, with low suspicion for infection as underlying
cause of hypotension. He was fluid responsive at ___
clinic, and blood pressures remained stable throughout
admission. Orthostatics were negative at the time of discharge. Lisinopril was held secondary to elevated creatinine, and
metoprolol was decreased to 12.5mg succinate given hypotension.
# Alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy- Patient had depressed EF of
___ during pre-chemotherapy work-up in ___. This
was attributed to long-term, excessive alcohol use. Patient was
started on lisinopril and metoprolol at that time, and has
significantly cut down on his alcohol and tobacco intake. His
most recent echo in ___ showed an improved EF to 50-55%.
Patient has no evidence of decompensation during admission with
flat neck veins, no lower extremities edema and clear lungs. As
above, home metoprolol was decreased and lisinopril was held
given ARF.
# Acute renal failure- Creatinine elevated to 1.5. Likely
prerenal, supporting theory that hypotension was due to
hypovolemia. Creatinine trended down, and lisinopril was held
at the time of discharge to be restarted by cardiologist in
follow-up.
# Mantle cell lymphoma- s/p R-CHOP (without adriamycin given
cardiomyopathy), now preparing for stem cell transplant. No
active issues during admission.
# Transitional issues-
- metoprolol succinate decreased to 12.5mg daily, lisinopril
held on discharge
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril 7.5 mgs daily
Metoprolol Succinate 25 mgs daily
Rosuvastatin 20 mgs daily
Multivitamin
Omega-3 Fatty Acids
Discharge Medications:
1. rosuvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY
(Daily).
2. metoprolol succinate 25 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig:
0.5 Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO once a day.
3. multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
4. omega-3 fatty acids Oral
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis:
# Hypotension due to dehydration
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent
admission.
You were admitted with low blood pressure and lightheadedness.
You received IV fluids and your pressure improved. You had
blood tests and EKGs which showed you were not having a heart
attack. Your symptoms and low blood pressure were likely
related to fasting for you stress test and becoming dehydrated
with exercise.
You will be discharged home to complete your stress test
imaging.
The following changes were made to your medication regimen:
- STOP lisinopril
- DECREASE metoprolol to 12.5mg (split the pill in half!)
continue the remainder of your medications without changes
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted at 22 weeks with mono-di twins with 
exam findings and history concerning for appendicitis.

Mrs ___ was transferred from ___ with pain 
concerning for acute appendicitis. An ultrasound at the outside 
hospital revealed a normal gallbladder. The appendix was not 
documented on the ultrasound. The initial WBC was 13.5 upon 
arrival to ___. An MRI could not be performed secondary to 
patient discomfort in the scanner. The general surgery team 
recommended diagnostic laparoscopy for further evaluation. 
Intravenous antibiotics (ampicillin, gentamicin and clindamycin) 
were started in the emergency room. Intraoperatively, a 
gangrenous appendix was found and a laparoscopic appendectomy 
was performed on ___. Please see operative report for further 
details.
.
Post-operatively, she was closely monitored on labor and 
delivery. The surgery team continued to follow her daily. She 
began contracting every ___ on POD#0. Her cervix was 
closed/long/high. She was treated with a 48 hour course of 
Indocin with good result. Fetal testing was reassuring. She was 
continued on triple antibiotics and remained afebrile. She had 
some low oxygen saturation levels which were likely due to 
atelectasis and resolved spontaneously. She received her weekly 
dose of immune globulin on ___ (hx CVID). By POD#4, she was 
tolerating a regular diet and ready for discharge. She had no 
further contractions and her cervix remained long/closed. She 
was discharged home on Augmentin which will be continued for a 
total of 14 days.

Levoxyl 112mcg daily
prenatal vitamin

6 hours) as needed.

(1)  Intramuscular ONCE (Once) for 1 doses.  
5. Amoxicillin-Pot Clavulanate 500-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 hours) for 2 weeks.
Disp:*42 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

Home

Ruptured appendix
Twin pregnancy
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

Call your physician ___: fever, chills, increasing abdominal 
pain, inability to tolerate food/drink, redness around 
incisions, decreased fetal movement, contractions, loss of 
fluid, vaginal bleeding. 

Continue to take your Augmentin antibiotic for 14 days.

Do not drive for 2 weeks. do not drive while on narcotics

___ CULTURE-FINALEMERGENCY WARD
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to urology for nephrolithiasis as 
noted in HPI and prepped for urgent operative intervention. On 
hospital day two he was take to the operative theatre and 
underwent cystoscopy, left ureteroscopy, laser lithotripsy
and stent placement. Mr. ___ tolerated the procedure well 
and recovered in the PACU before transfer to the general 
surgical floor. See the dictated operative note for full 
details. He voided on arrival to general ward, was ambulated and 
diet advanced. He was subsequently discharged home with plan for 
follow up for ureteral stent removal in about two weeks time. 
Mr. ___ was explicitly advised to follow up as directed as 
the indwelling ureteral stent must be removed and or exchanged.

 
Medications on Admission:
as noted in omr
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild/Fever  
2.  Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS  
3.  Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO QID:PRN reflux  
4.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
5.  Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H  
6.  Zonisamide 400 mg PO QHS  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left UVJ stone

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You can expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to 
possibly experience some urgency and frequency over the next 
month; this may be related to the passage of stone fragments or, 
if applicable to you, the indwelling ureteral stent. You may 
also experience some pain associated with spasm of your ureter.

-The kidney stone may or may not have been removed AND/or there 
may fragments/others still in the process of passing.

-Ureteral stents MUST be removed or exchanged and therefore it 
is IMPERATIVE that you follow-up as directed. 

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds)

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urinethis, as noted above, is expected and will gradually 
improvecontinue to drink plenty of fluids to flush out your 
urinary system

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. 
-You should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any 
medication changes and your post-operative course with your 
primary care doctor.  

-IBUPROFEN (the active ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be 
taken even though you may also be taking ACETAMINOPHEN 
(Tylenol). You may alternate these medications for pain control. 


-For pain control, try TYLENOL FIRST, then the ibuprofen (unless 
otherwise advised), and then take the narcotic pain medication 
(if prescribed) as prescribed if additional pain relief is 
needed.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your 
stool (dark, tarry stools)

-You MAY be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

-You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a 
gentle laxative. These are over-the-counter medications that may 
be health care spending account reimbursable. 

-Docusate sodium (Colace) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
further minimize your risk of constipation. 

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old female with a PMH significant for 
small PFO admitted for left lower extremity cellulitis that 
worsened while being treated with duracef.

Cellulitis: Patient's cellulitis worsened with ___ hours of 
cefadroxil treatment.  Per the patient, she had xrays performed 
at an OSH ED that were negative.  The patient received 3 g IV 
amp/sulbactam in the ED. She received an additional 1.5g IV 
amp/sulbactam overnight and on the morning of discharge was 
converted to PO amoxicillin/clavulanate po tid x14 days. The 
patient was instructed to keep her foot clean and dry, and to 
call her PCP or go to the local emergency department if she 
developed fevers, chills, or sweats or if her foot became more 
erythematous, swollen, or painful.  She was instructed to take 
acetaminophen (no more than 4g/day) for pain relief.  A 
follow-up appointment was scheduled for her with her PCP, ___ 
___, MD for next week.

Home

Good

infection, of your left ___, and ___ toes.  You are 
receiving an antibiotic for this infection, which you would need 
to take as directed.  If you have any clinical worsening of your 
symptoms, including increased pain, redness, swelling, or 
fevers, chills, and sweats, you should contact your PCP or go to 
your local emergency department immediately.  You should keep 
the area clean and dry, and you may put cotton balls between 
your toes to facilitate this.

2. Your antibiotic regimen is:
Augmentin 500 mg by mouth 3 times a day for 14 days (STOP ON 
___

4. It is very important that you take all of your medications as 
prescribed.

appointments.

6. If you develop any fevers, chills, sweats, chest pains, 
shortness of breath, or other concerning symptoms, call your PCP 
or go to your local emergency department immediately.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented and was evaluated by the orthopedic 
surgery team. The patient was found to have a R femoral shaft 
fracture and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The 
patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for R TFN 
ORIF, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the 
procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. 
The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
and oral medications by POD#1. The patient has baseline dyspnea 
on exertion for "years" according to him and was given nebs as 
needed.  The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked 
with ___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. 
The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
touchdown weight bearing in the left lower extremity with 
posterior hip precautions, and will be discharged on lovenox for 
DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ 
___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient 
regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course 
including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, 
and all questions were answered. The patient was also given 
written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and 
the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness 
for discharge.

as needed for pain Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0

Home With Service

R femoral shaft fracture

 
Discharge Condition:

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

- ___ were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Weight bearing as tolerated

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so ___ should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox 40 mg at bedtime daily for two weeks 

WOUND CARE:
- ___ may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if ___ experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:

___ will have follow up with ___, NP in the 
Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic 14 days post-operation for evaluation. 
Call ___ to schedule appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

Weight bearing as tolerated

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
On POD#2, patient was complaining of calf pain.  An ultrasound 
was performed, which showed a small fluid collection (likely a 
popiteal fossa hematoma), no clot noted.  No intervention 
needed.  She had an elevated heart rate throughout her 
hospitalization with increased activity.  Per patient report, 
this is not new.  She was instructed to follow-up with her 
primary care physician after discharge to have her TSH 
rechecked.  On day of discharge, her hematoma was 25.5.  She was 
started on iron supplementation and instructed to follow-up with 
her primary care physician ___ to have her labs 
checked and determine whether this medication needs to be 
continued.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled on oral and IV pain 
medications.  The patient received Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis 
starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was removed on 
POD#2 and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. The 
surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision 
was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs 
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted 
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating 
a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with 
stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and 
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative 
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.
 

Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
3. Methimazole 0.5 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
2. Methimazole 0.5 mg PO DAILY 
3. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
5. Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC DAILY Duration: 4 Weeks 
6. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
8. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left knee pain

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.  
___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment in two weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure.
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.
Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
On POD#2, patient was complaining of calf pain. An ultrasound
was performed, which showed a small fluid collection (likely a
popiteal fossa hematoma), no clot noted. No intervention
needed. She had an elevated heart rate throughout her
hospitalization with increased activity. Per patient report,
this is not new. She was instructed to follow-up with her
primary care physician after discharge to have her TSH
rechecked. On day of discharge, her hematoma was 25.5. She was
started on iron supplementation and instructed to follow-up with
her primary care physician ___ to have her labs
checked and determine whether this medication needs to be
continued.
Otherwise, pain was initially controlled on oral and IV pain
medications. The patient received Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis
starting on the morning of POD#1. The foley was removed on
POD#2 and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. The
surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision
was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal
drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs
were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted
accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating
a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with
stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.
The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as
tolerated on the operative extremity.
Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable
condition.
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain
2. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY
3. Methimazole 0.5 mg PO DAILY
Discharge Medications:
1. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY
2. Methimazole 0.5 mg PO DAILY
3. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
5. Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC DAILY Duration: 4 Weeks
6. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain
8. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left knee pain
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker
or cane).
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5,
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this
admission and any new medications and refills.
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent
this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you
are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your
home.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your
surgeon.
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your
follow-up appointment.
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time,
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex,
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4)
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). If
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.
___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths,
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4)
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air.
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up
appointment in two weeks.
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as
instructed, wound checks.
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative
extremity. Mobilize. ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or
heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Physical Therapy:
WBAT
Unrestricted ROM
Mobilize
Treatments Frequency:
Dry dressing daily as needed.
Staples to be removed at post-op appointment
Followup Instructions:
___

pain for 6 days, improving signficantly over the past 48 hours.  
He has been unable to take in food because it worsens the pain 
and causes substantial nausea. No vomiting. This seems typical 
of his ___ flares except for the fact that he has only had 
___ bowel movements per day and his usual flares cause 20 loose 
stools per day. He reports sweats daily but without fever.  The 
patient notices that his pain is worse with eating and has 
decreased signficant since 2 days prior to admission because he 
stopped eating.  Of note, the patient was started on ___ 2 
weeks prior to admission with a decrease in his Prednisone from 
15 to 10.  At the onset of this flare he was increased to 30 
with continued ___.  The patient also reports that he had low

normal-appearing 
gallbladder.

Ab CT ___
IMPRESSION: 
1. Findings consistent with progressed ___ disease in the 
terminal ileum. Appendiceal inflammatory changes may relate to 
adjacent terminal ileitis, but close clinical follow up is 
necessary as primary appendicitis could appear similar. 
2. Mild inflammatory change in the sigmoid, consistent with 
___ 
involvement but overall improved from ___. No pericolonic 
abscess or CT 
evidence for microperforation. 
3. Minimal to no peripancreatic stranding to correlate with 
apparent 
laboratory evidence of pancreatitis.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old gentleman with ___ disease presented with 
complaints of abdominal pain and N/V, and increased stool 
frequency. 

#) Acute Pancreatitis:
The patient was found to have lipase near 3000 on admission with 
normal Triglycerides & calcium.  RUQ unrevealing for a 
mechanical etiology. He was kept NPO and hydrated aggressively 
while maintaining adequate pain control.  His lipase reached 
approximately 200 within 36 hours and he then tolerated a clear 
diet.  His acute pancreatitis was ultimately attributed to ___. 
 He was discharged on a low residue diet and without ___. 

#) ___ flare:
The patient had an atypical presentation of his ___ disease 
with ___ episodes of diarrhea daily and guaiac positive stool.  
His oral Prednisone 30mg was converted to Solumedrol 20, then 
30.  He was discharged on Prednisone 40mg with close Primary GI 
follow-up.  In addition the patient was started on Cipro/Flagyl 
for a ___ PPD was placed should Remicade be 
initated, to be read at his follow-up appointment. 

#) Hypokalemia:
The patient was Hypokalemic to 3.1 on admission based likely on 
diarrhea.  He was repleted in the ED with follow up labs showing 
successful repletion.
 
Medications on Admission:
-Prednisone 15' until 2 weeks ago; 10' after starting ___ now 
at 30' since flare began
-___ 50' started 2 weeks ago
-Omeprazole 20'
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day.  
2. Prednisone 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO once a day for 
4 days: Until directed by Dr. ___ to change your dose.
Disp:*8 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Cipro 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 4 
days.
Disp:*8 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Flagyl 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a day 
for 4 days: Do not drink any alcohol while taking this 
medication.
Disp:*12 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Acute pancreatitis 
2. ___ disease exacerbation 
 

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable and afebrile, tolerating oral medications and diet

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for treatment of an acute 
___ flare. In addition to the potential ___ flare, you 
were found to have inflammation of your pancreas (also known as 
pancreatitis) which we believe was most likely caused by 
starting 6-mercaptopurine. We treated you for the potential 
___ flare with antibiotics (including Cipro and Flagyl) and 
Solumedrol (methylprednisolone, which is a steroid like 
prednisone, which we used because it is available intravenously 
vs by mouth). For the acute pancreatitis, we kept you with 
nothing by mouth, gave you copious intravenous fluids, and gave 
you pain control medications. Your symptoms improved with 
treatment, and we were able to advance you to drinking and then 
a full diet.

We placed a PPD on your right forearm because you may be 
starting Remicade, a biologic agent for treatment of ___. 
This should be read on ___. Please have this read at Dr. 
___ or return to the ___ ___ floor 
and ask for any member of the ___ to have it read.

Please do not resume your home 6-mercaptopurine, as we suspect 
this may have precipitated your acute pancreatitis. Please 
continue prednisone 40 mg daily until evaluated by Dr. 
___ dose changes may be made at that time. You will 
continue antiobiotics (flagyl and ciprofloxacin) for four more 
days as well. You may resume your home omeprazole.

Please follow-up with your outpatient gastroenterologist Dr. 
___ tomorrow as scheduled.

Please return to the ___ ED or call your physician if you 
experience worsening or returning pain, nausea, vomiting, 
fevers, chills, worsening diarrhea, back pain, dizziness, 
light-headedness, blood in the stool, or any other medical 
emergency.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

prep for her colonoscopy but denies Hx of vomiting. Denies SOB,

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the TICU, made NPO, hydrated with IV 
fluids and started prophylactic Zosyn.  She denied abdominal 
pain, nausea or vomiting.  She underwent a Barium swallow on 
___ which confirmed no esophageal leak and was started on 
clear liquids.  She remained afebrile, without leukocytosis or 
abdominal pain.  She may have had a microperforation which 
sealed off.  She was eventually able to tolerate soft foods 
without difficulty.

She still had some unresolved issues including severe anxiety 
and depression which initially lead to her seeking treatment at 
___.  She also has had unexplained weight loss, possibly related 
to her depression.  Her initial work up including upper 
endoscopy and Abdominal CT is negative.  Both the patient and

Brief Hospital Course:
1) Acute Appendicitis: ___ yr old male with no significant PMH 
was admitted on ___ under the acute care surgery service for 
management of his acute appendicitis. He was taken to the 
operating room and underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy. Please 
see operative report for details of this procedure. He tolerated 
the procedure well and was extubated upon completion. He was 
subsequently taken to the PACU for recovery.

He was transferred to the surgical floor hemodynamically stable. 
His vital signs were routinely monitored and he remained 
afebrile and hemodynamically stable. He was initially given IV 
fluids postoperatively, which were discontinued when he was 
tolerating PO's. His diet was advanced on the morning of ____ to 
regular, which he tolerated without abdominal pain, nausea, or 
vomiting. He was voiding adequate amounts of urine without 
difficulty. He was encouraged to mobilize out of bed and 
ambulate as tolerated, which he was able to do independently. 
His pain level was routinely assessed and well controlled at 
discharge with an oral regimen as needed.
On ____, he was discharged home with scheduled follow up in ___ 
clinic.

Transitional Issues: 

 
Medications on Admission:
None 
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute appendicitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You presented with abdominal pain and were admitted for acute 
appendicitis.  Your appendix was removed laparoscopically on 
___.  You were treated with antibiotics and IV pain 
medications, and tolerated your procedure well.  
PLease seek medical attention if:
Fever greater than 101
Redness that is spreading
Pain not adequately relieved with medication
Drainage from wound
Opening of incision

You may shower in 48 hours, you may bathe in 6 weeks
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ year old woman with history of COPD/asthma, 
hypertension who presents with complaints of wheezing, fevers, 
productive cough.
Pt states she was in her usual state of health until 
approximately 2 weeks ago when she traveled to ___ for a 
wedding.  She states she started feeling ill after the wedding 
and states "the air conditioning was too high".  She describes 
onset of wheezing and cough.  Also, per pt's daughter, there 
were other family members at the wedding who subsequently fell 
ill with the flu, and were hospitalized.  The patient did 
recieve her flu shot this year.  While down there, the patient 
filled a subscription for amoxicillin (she had an outstanding 
prescription from her dentist as prophylactic if/when needed 
dental procdure) - so she filled this prescription and took this 
medication for 5 days, thinking it might help with her symptoms, 
and she stated it helped somewhat, but then her symptoms 
returned after completing the antibiotics.
She states she saw her pulmonologist this past week on ___ 
(note in OMR) at which time her symptoms were felt to be 
improving and no further antibiotics/treatment were given.
More recently, over the past week, she reports continued 
cough/congestion, wheezing.  Also has developed fevers over past 
2 days.  Reports some occasional right sided pleuritic chest 
pain, and some anorexia.  Denies chest pain/pressure, dysuria, 
abdominal pain, diarrhea.  
In ED, patient was initially febrile to 101, other vital signs 
stable (O2 100% on 2L NC).  EKG unremarkable.  Labs notable for 
marked leukocytosis with WBC 24, lactate initially elevated at 
2.6, recheck after IVF 1.3.  CXR prelim read with possible left 
lower lobe pneumonia (although dictated read fairly 
unremarkable).  Urinalysis pending, blood cultures pending.  
Patient received IVF fluids x 1 liter, levofloxacin, nebulizers, 
and solumedrol.
Currently feels "much better already".

.

negative.  Patient had nasal swab for influenza which was 
pending.

FINDINGS: PA and lateral views of the chest are obtained. There
is a severe S-shaped scoliosis, which is stable, though somewhat
limits evaluation.

pneumonia or
CHF. Left basilar plate-like atelectasis is stable. There is a
small amount of right pleural effusion, which is stable. The
rounded density in the right cardiophrenic angle is compatible
with the markedly tortuous thoracic aorta seen on CT. Heart size
is difficult to assess though appears stable. Bony
structures appear intact.

with markedly
tortuous thoracic aorta. Probable small right pleural effusion.
___ view CXR: no infiltrate, heart failure, consistent with
___ CXR.

wheezing, leukocytosis consistent with URI with asthma
exacerbation.
.

cough, wheezing consistent with infection. Initial CXR was
fairly unremarkable but pt was slightly dehydrated. Repeat ___
CXR no infiltrate. Per daughter, had exposure to influenza, but
was a couple weeks ago. Also had numerous people become ill
after wedding in air-conditioned locale. Urine legionella
negative. Patient had nasal swab for influenza which was
pending.
Patient treated for URI with asthma exacerbation. Patient
initially received 2 days of levofloxacin that was changed to
azithromycin for 3 days on discharge. Patient discharged on
steroid burst.
.

.

.

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Peanut / Peanut Oil
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Blood Patch

 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ year old female with no significant pmhx who presents 
with 4 days of intractable headache. The headache began when she 
awoke on ___ and persisted all day; she went to the ED 
where CT head was negative and LP was performed showing normal 
cell counts and chemistries but elevated opening pressure of 46 
(however, this was performed in a seated position.) She was 
discharged home with percocet and the headache recurred several 
hours after she returned home. She again presented to the ED on 
___ and underwent a repeat LP with OP of 26 and again normal 
chemistries and cell ___. She was seen by neurology, who 
believed this was a migraine HA, and sent home with fioricet and 
percocet with no relief. Since that time, her headache has 
persisted in severity; she describes it as a bifrontal HA with 
pounding and radiation to the neck, and "pressure" in the face. 
It is improved with lying flat and worse with sitting up. She 
also has associated lightheadedness, nausea, photo and 
phonophobia, but no visual changes or other neurologic symptoms. 
Additionally, the patient reports falling down three steps today 
and twisting her ankle. She did not injury hear head or have any 
LOC.  
.  
In the ED, initial vs were: T97.1 HR75 BP135/69 RR16 100%on RA, 
pain ___. A urinalysis was performed showing +bacteria and 
nitrites but no WBCs, and urine HCG was negative. She was 
evaluated by neurology, who felt that this was likely a migraine 
headache with a component of post-LP pain. They recommended 
supplemental O2, opiates and a blood patch in the morning. 
Patient was given 500 mg caffeine in 1L NS, vicodin 2 tabs PO, 
toradol 30 mg IV, and compazine 10 mg PO. Additionally, the 
patient underwent ankle xrays showing no fracture.  
.  
On the floor, patient reported continued ___ pain in head and 
right ankle. She states that the vicodin had improved her pain 
from 10 to 7 in intensity, but had worn off. She also c/o nausea 
 

 
Past Medical History:
Migraine HA - only one prior during high school  
s/p Lap band  
Obesity  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Paternal grandmother with DM, maternal GM died of cervical Ca. 
No known hx of HTN or MI. 
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T: 97.9 BP: 147/104 P: 78 R: 18 O2: 100% on RA  
General: well-appearing young AA female, Alert, oriented, no 
acute distress  
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, PERLLA, EOMI, MMM, oropharynx clear  
Neck: supple, no LAD  
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
ronchi  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops  
Abdomen: obese, soft, non-tender, non-distended, + BS  
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema. No significant swelling or bruising of right ankle.  
Neuro: A&Ox3, CN II-XII intact, normal tone, strength and motor 
throughout, moving all extremities equally, gait assessment 
deferred  

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:15AM BLOOD WBC-8.7 RBC-3.71* Hgb-11.6* Hct-33.6* 
MCV-91 MCH-31.2 MCHC-34.4 RDW-14.4 Plt ___
___ 06:15AM BLOOD ___ PTT-24.3 ___
___ 06:15AM BLOOD Glucose-90 UreaN-10 Creat-0.6 Na-137 
K-3.6 Cl-104 HCO3-23 AnGap-14
___ 07:20PM URINE RBC-<1 ___ Bacteri-MOD Yeast-NONE 
___ 07:20PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-POS Protein-NEG 
Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.5 Leuks-NEG

X-RAY:
RIGHT ANKLE: There is circumferential soft tissue swelling 
around the ankle.  The ankle mortise is preserved, the talar 
dome is intact. No fracture is evident. There is no ankle 
effusion. 
  
RIGHT FOOT: Mineralization and alignment are within normal 
limits. Joint 
spaces are preserved and appropriately aligned. No fracture or 
dislocation is evident. The regional soft tissues are 
unremarkable. 
  
IMPRESSION: Soft tissue swelling around the ankle. This may 
indicate 
ligamentous or other soft tissue injury. No fracture noted in 
ankle or foot. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ Female with history of migraine headache for 5 days prior to 
admission, acutely worsened after LP x 2 during previous ED 
visits.

Headache - On admission, patient had presented to ED 3 times in 
5 days.  During those evals, headache had been most consistent 
with migraine, however underwent LP x 2.  After her lumbar 
punctures, her headache worsened, associated with nausea and 
positional.  Neurology evaluated her and recommended blood 
patch.  Pending blood patch, headache was treated with vicodin 
and fioricet with minimal improvement.  Patient underwent blood 
patch on ___ with improvement in headache.  She was continued 
on fioricet and given ibuprofen for residual headache.  Due to 
social stressors, patient was seen by social work prior to 
discharge.  Patient is due to follow-up with PCP.

Right Ankle Sprain - Status post mechanical fall on stairs prior 
to admission, xray negative for fracture.  Recieved air sling 
cast for right ankle to use during activity.
 
Medications on Admission:
Vitamin D
 
Discharge Medications:
1. butalbital-acetaminophen-caff 50-325-40 mg Tablet Sig: ___ 
Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for headache.
Disp:*15 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for pain for 5 days.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Migraine
Post-LP Headache

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital for evaluation and treatment 
of your headaches. It was felt that while your headaches likely 
started as migraines.  Due to the 2 lumbar punctures, you 
developed worsening of your headache.  Medications in the 
hospital were not very helpful in alleviateing your symptoms, 
and you had a blood patch placed by anesthesia that helped your 
symptoms.  You are being discharged home to follow-up with your 
PCP.

Changes in Medication:
Fioricet ___ tab PO every 6 hours as needed for headache
Ibuprofen 800 mg PO every eight hours for 5 days 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Diffuse inflammatory changes around the pancreas, lesser sac, 
fluid extending along the right and left paracolic gutter and 
around the splenic margin consistent with acute pancreatitis.

RUQ US ___:
 
IMPRESSION:  
Edematous pancreas with small amount of surrounding fluid, 
consistent 
pancreatitis. 
Mild intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary dilatation, probably 
within normal limits for post cholecystectomy, recommend 
clinical correlation.  If ampullary stone is suspected, MRCP can 
be done. 
Echogenic liver consistent with steatosis. Other forms of liver 
disease and more advanced liver disease including 
steatohepatitis or significant hepatic fibrosis/cirrhosis cannot 
be excluded on this study. 

CT A/P ___:
IMPRESSION:  
1. Findings consistent with acute necrotic pancreatitis, with 
areas of 
necrosis in the pancreatic uncinate process and body/ tail. 
Peripancreatic fluid is present (acute necrotic collection) 
without organized collection. 
2. Splenic vein narrowing. 
3. 7 mm left upper pole hypodense renal lesion unchanged since 
___ consistent with a benign cyst. 
4. Fat containing umbilical hernia. Calcific density at the base 
of the hernia may reflect calcified lymph nodes or sequelae of 
prior fat necrosis. 
5. Bilateral pleural effusions and bibasilar atelectasis.

2d
of thumb pain and redness. Was found to have limited range of

evidence of flexor tenosynovitis/felon/parnonithcia and thought
she may have had early cellulitis. Was given vancomycin and
transitioned to Keflex with mild improvement in ED, so sent home
on ___ with 10d script Keflex.
Presented again on ___ to the ED for persistent pain. 
In ED, AVSS. Was seen by hand surgery who thought she had 
abscess
and performed I&D of purulence. Was given a partial dose of CTX
and then started on IV Bactrim. Admitted to medicine for slow
improvement.

Patient reports the above history. She has had no fevers, 
chills,
nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, chest pain, shortness of breath. She
denies any animal or human bites, no punching/fights. She
endorses other rashes on her body, most recently on her RUE 
which
she has currently. These lesions will appear on other parts of
her body but right now she only has them on her R arm. This
lesions are pruritic, intermittent, last for an unknown period 
of
time, but have been going on in last 6 months. She thinks she 
has
bugs in her apartment based on this and just had it fumigated. 
No
bed partner and no roommates. Previously used injection drugs 
but
not in last many months to a year. Quit cocaine as well which 
she
used to smoke. 

Denies dysuria, urgency, joint pain. 

She thinks that since the I&D the pain has gotten better and
swelling has improved too.

___ w prev use of injection drugs, polysubstance use p/w

--now on Bactrim/Keflex and improving

to have this performed.  purpose of packing is to allow for 
controlled healing to prevent skin from covering incision and 
then causing risk of reforming another abscess

- outpatient follow up with her psychiatrist

- repeat UA; w/u as outpt if persistent

- U tox performed in ED

Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions

"over the summer I started having suicidal thoughts"

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o single ___ with
prior psychiatric hx of outpatient treatment and cutting but no
known hx of substance abuse, inpatient admissions, or suicide
attempts, who was sent to ___ from school counseling ___ after
being directed there by old high school friend with concern for
suicidal ideation after patient had sent him alarming message 
via
Facebook. Patient has been increasingly depressed, isolated, and
with neurovegetative sx over the last three weeks, initially 
with
suicidal ideation wihtout plan; in last ___ hours has
begun contemplating a plan to kill herself and thinking about
writing suicide notes to say goodbye to people, and she has not
been able to go to school this week. In past she has made plans
to overdose or cut wrists. Sx not consistent with mania or
psychosis as per Dr. ___. She denies physical or sexual trauma
hx as a child, but grew up in very chaotic household where all
adults were substance abusers and intoxicated or high most of 
the
time; she states she did fear for her safety and that of her
mother many times. She does not have nightmares about it, but
does find the memories are very painful and she finds herself
thinking about it frequently. No clear dissociation but cuts to
relieve pressure. Stressors appear more chronic financial 
issues.
She is in a longterm, supportive relationship with a boyfriend
(who was here last night visiting patient in ED), who is a
student at ___. The friend from high school whom she
contacted is at ___, and she and he hang out every 
so
often, but she states she really has not made a lot of friends
here at ___. She is a ___. 

 
Past Medical History:
Denies any medical problems

Past psychiatric history: 
-Diagnoses: Depression, anxiety
-Prior Hospitalizations: none
-History of suicide attempts or self-injurious behavior: h/o of
cutting, first at age ___, usually on legs, with goal of relief
not suicide. Last cut this past ___ but otherwise hadn't cut
in years
-Prior med trials: Prozac ("zombie")
-Therapist: none currently. Had one this summer 
-Psychiatrist: Dr. ___ in ___, ___. Has not seen
her since the summer. She is prescribing wellbutrin

___

mother and sister have problems with anxiety

CV: Regular rate and rhythm; no murmurs/rubs/gallops; 2+ pedal
pulses
Abdomen: Soft, nontender, nondistended; no masses or
organomegaly.
Extremities: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema.
Skin: Warm and dry, no rash or significant lesions.

___ 06:02AM BLOOD calTIBC-371 VitB12-540 Folate-16.8 
Ferritn-24 TRF-285
___ 06:02AM BLOOD TSH-2.7
___ 06:02AM BLOOD HCG-<5
 
Brief Hospital Course:
PSYCHIATRIC
#Depression/Anxiety: Patient's distress appears to be due to 
combination of depressive and anxious symptoms.  She has had 
trouble adjusting to being at a larger school and felt betrayed 
and abandoned by the friends she has made. Her feelings of 
isolation led to suicidal thoughts. Upon admission to the unit 
patient was already starting to feel better as these issues were 
being addressed and she had communicated her distress to her 
boyfriend and parents which improved feeling of isolation. Her 
wellbutrin was discontinued as she did not feel like it was 
helping her and she was started on Zoloft 50mg which she 
tolerated well. Due to her current lack of insurance, she will 
be given a month supply of Zoloft on discharge and will f/u with 
___ student counseling until her insurance starts and she 
can see a private therapist and psychiatrist.

GENERAL MEDICAL CONDITIONS
No acute issues during admission

PSYCHOSOCIAL:
#Collateral: The therapist at ___ that ___ had seen 
prior to admission was contacted and agreed with dispo plan. 
Boyfriend ___ came in for meeting. Her family also visited 
her on the unit and she was discharged with her mother.

#Groups/milieu: Patient was visible in the milieu and interacted 
well with other patients and staff.  She appeared to have good 
mood.  She participated in groups.

LEGAL: ___
RISK ASSESSMENT: Likely low risk for suicide. Risk factors 
include depression, age, and passive suicidal thoughts prior to 
admission. Her mood quickly stabilized in the hospital, though, 
and on discharge she clearly denied any suicidal 
thoughts/plan/intent. No prior suicide attempts or substance 
abuse. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Wellbutrin 150mg XR daily
Nuvaring

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Sertraline 50 mg PO QAM 
RX *sertraline 50 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth DAILY Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
  I   MDD, recurrent, severe, without psychotic symptoms
  II  deferred
  III none
  IV  loss of friends, social isolation
  V   ___

 
Discharge Condition:
Discharge Condition: Stable
Ambulatory Status: Independent
Mental Status: Alert and oriented without deficits. Appears well 
groomed. Mood is 'good.' Affect full range, nonlabile. Focused 
on returning to school. Patient denies SI/HI, hallucinations, 
delusions.  Has good insight and judgment. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Ms ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___.  You were admitted to 
the psychiatry service because of worsening depression and 
anxiety which led to some suicidal thoughts.  It appeared that 
these were related to feeling socially isolated at school and 
not having a current therapist for support. After you were 
admitted and were able to discuss these problems with your 
boyfriend ___ and your parents, your mood improved 
significantly.  Your medication was also changed to Zoloft as 
you did not feel that Wellbutrin was working any longer. It is 
important that you follow up with a therapist and continue to 
see your outpatient psychiatrist.

-Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - 
take this discharge paperwork to your appointments.
-Please continue all medications as directed.
-Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether 
prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen 
your medical and psychiatric illnesses.
-Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers 
if you have any concerns.
-Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you 
feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your 
health care providers.

*It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you the 
best of health.*
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___        ___ No:  ___

Admission Date: ___        Discharge Date: ___

Date of Birth:  ___        Sex:  female

Service:


SERVICE:  OB service.

This is a ___ malip that presented to triage for
induction of labor for elevated blood pressures in the
150s/100s.  She presented earlier in
pregnancy with diagnosis of preeclampsia, admitted to the
hospital and then was discharged and followed outpatient for
preeclampsia.  Due to worsening blood pressure in the office,
at 37 weeks, a decision was made to admit this patient for
induction of labor.  The patient was admitted, started with
Cytotec for induction of labor.  Blood pressure remained
elevated.  Labetalol IV was used to maintain her blood
pressure.  Magnesium bolus was started too after admission.
After Cytotec was used, Pitocin was initiated.  The patient's
exam had been unchanged.  Low dose Pitocin was started.  The
patient went up to 20 of Pitocin.  The cervix remained
closed, continued to use IV labetalol as needed to control
blood pressures, maintain the patient on magnesium.  We
continued induction.  We restarted Cytotec again.  Pitocin
for the ___ time had been restarted.  On going up on Pitocin
the fetal heart rate had been in a category 1, but the
patient had started to have late decelerations and decision
was made with the patient to turn off the Pitocin, proceed
with C section for minimal change on her exams.

The patient delivered, on ___, in the morning after
decision was made to go with a C section after failed
induction in the setting of severe preeclampsia with a
nonreassuring fetal heart tracing.  The patient agreed.  The
patient did well postoperatively on the floor.  We continued
labetalol orally at 200 mg b.i.d.  During the ___
hospital course, the patient was given nifedipine, because
the labetalol, patient was responding well to, her blood
pressures were still elevated.  Then the patient was switched
over to 30 mg of the extended release nifedipine which she
tolerated well.  The patient was discharged home on the
nifedipine to follow up in the office within 1 week for
another blood pressure check with monitoring for her
medication.



                        ___, M.D.

Dictated By:  ___, M.D.

MEDQUIST36
D:  ___ 14:35:33
T:  ___ 07:29:22
___:  ___

text:
Name: ___ Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: M Service: ORTHOPAEDICS Allergies: No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: Low back pain s/p L5-S1 anterior/posterior lumbar decompression with fusion Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: Exploration with removal of hardware at L5-S1 on ___ History of Present Illness: ___ underwent an anterior and posterior decompression and fusion. He is ___ years old and had a lytic spondylolisthesis at L5-S1. Currently he complains of back pain over the instrumentation. The procedure was performed at ___ on ___. Past Medical History: non contributary Social History: ___ Family History: Non Contributary Physical Exam: On examination the patient is well developed, well nourished, A&O x3 in NAD. AVSS. Range of motion of the lumbar spine is intact throughout. Ambulating well with the assistance of ___, with lumbar corset brace for support. Gross motor examination reveals good strength throughout the bilateral lower extremities. There is no clonus present. Sensation is intact throughout all affected dermatomes. The lumbar incision is clean, dry and intact without erythema, edema or drainage. The patient is voiding well without a foley catheter. Brief Hospital Course: Briefly, the patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and taken to the Operating Room on ___ for the above procedure. Refer to the dictated operative note for further details. The surgery was performed without complication, the patient tolerated the procedure well, and was transferred to the PACU in a stable condition. TEDs/pneumoboots were used for postoperative DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initially, postop pain was controlled with dilaudid and percocet. Diet was advanced as tolerated. The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when tolerating PO diet. A foley catheter was inserted after surgery for urinary retention and was removed the following day. The patient was placed on flomax and was able to void. Post-operative labs were grossly stable. Physical therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate. Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet. Medications on Admission: None Discharge Medications: 1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN for breakthrough pain Discharge Disposition: Home Discharge Diagnosis: Lumbar spondylosis Discharge Condition: Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Discharge Instructions: You underwent a lumbar exploration with removal of hardware at L5-S1 on ___ Physical Therapy: Activity: Activity: Ambulate Pneumatic boots Ambulation as per pathway
Encourage turning, deep breathing and coughing while awake
Treatments Frequency: Wound care: Site: Incision Type: Surgical Dressing: Gauze - dry Comment: Will be changed on POD#2 by ___ reinforce dressing if saturated Followup Instructions: ___

hours Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0

RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 by mouth at bedtime Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0

11. HELD- Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY  This medication was held. 
Do not restart Lisinopril until follow up with Dr. ___

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Healthy liver donor

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever of 
101 or higher, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, 
inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of 
skin or eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, 
drainage or bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine 
output or dark, cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, or 
any other concerning 
symptoms.

You may shower with soap and water, rinse, pat dry. Do not apply 
lotion or powder near the incision. You may leave the incision 
open 
to the air. The staples will be removed approximately 3 weeks 

No tub baths or swimming

Empty and record the JP drain output twice daily and as needed 
so that the drain is never more than half full. 

Call the transplant office ___ if the drain output 
increases by more than 100 cc from the previous day,  becomes 
bloody or develops a foul odor.

Change the drain dressing once daily or after your shower. Do 
not allow the drain to hang freely at any time. Inspect the site 
for redness, drainage or bleeding. Make sure there is a stitch 
at the drain site.

No driving if taking narcotic pain medications
Do not drink alcohol

Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and 
you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast 
or Ensure

 
Followup Instructions:
___

for redness, drainage or bleeding. Make sure there is a stitch
at the drain site.

or Ensure

___ CT SINUS/MANDIBLE/MAXILLA:
Non-displaced left orbital floor fracture just adjacent to the 
infraorbital canal and extending into the pyriform sinus causing 
left maxillary sinus hemorrhage.  

Non-displaced left superior orbital wall (roof) fracture 
extending into the lesser wing of the sphenoid (planum 
sphenoidale) causing hemorrhage in the posterior left ethmoid 
air cells and sphenoid sinus.  

___: X-ray right hand: no acute fracture, no foreign body 
noted.

___: X-ray left wrist: minimally displaced triquetral 
fracture; no foreign body noted, no other fractures.

  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted to ___ s/p mechanical fall at work.  On 
arrival to the ___ she was A&O. Her head, spine and torso were 
scanned, all negative findings. CT of the sinus revealed left 
orbital fracture. OT evaluation demonstrated the need for 
ongoing neuro occupational therapy, however the patient was 
determined safe for discharge home.  She was able to ambulate 
out of bed with a steady gait. Follow up with cognitive 
neurology was scheduled prior to discharge. 

Ophthalmology was consulted and recommended follow-up eye exam 
within the next few weeks. Upon evaluation she was found to have 
no visual changes or evidence of entrapment. Plastic surgery was 
also consulted with recommendations to follow sinus precautions 
until seen in follow-up in the plastic surgery clinic by Dr. 
___ on ___.  

On the day of discharge the patient complain of right thumb and 
left wrist pain with full range of motion, but with mild pain 
doing so. Plain films of these extremities were obtained with no 
fracture seen of the right hand, but minimally displaced left 
triquetral fracture.  The patient was seen by the Plastics-Hand 
service, and her left hand splinted with recommendations to 
follow-up in Hand clinic in one week. No operative interventions 
were done or recommended at this time.

The patient was discharged home with recommendation for use of 
ibuprophen or Tylenol for pain relief. A prescription was 
provided for Ultram as needed for breakthrough pain. Colace was 
encouraged for stool softening as needed for constipation r/t 
Utram use. Follow-up appointments with ophthamology and plastic 
surgery have been arranged for the patient.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for headache: Do not exceed 3200mg per 24 
hours.  
2. tramadol 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.  
4. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed for fever/pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p fall 
Left orbital roof and floor fracture
Left triquetral fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital today after falling.  You had 
a concusion and fractured your left orbit. You have been seen by 
the opthomologist, who recommends that you have a repeat eye 
exam in two weeks. You have an appointment scheduled with your 
PCP next week ___. Please follow up at this appointment so that 
your future eye exam can be arranged. 

You have a fracture in your left wrist which was splinted, you 
will follow up with the Hand doctors on ___.

You can take Ibuprofen, or similar medications, for your 
headache.  However these medications have side effects, please 
talk to your primary care doctor if you need to continue to take 
these medication beyond two weeks.

If you need a stronger pain medication, we have provided you 
prescription for Ultram. You can take 1 tablet every 6 hours as 
needed for pain.  This medication may cloud your judgement.  Do 
not make important decision, use machinery, or drive while 
taking this medication. Ultram may also cause constipation.  You 
may take an over the counter stool softner, such as Colace, as 
needed for constipation. 

Because of your eye socket fracture, you should maintain sinus 
precautions until you follow up with the plastic surgeon at the 
apopintment listed below. This includes:
-Do not forcefully spit for several days.
-Do not smoke for several days.
-Do not use straws for several days.
-Do not forcefully blow your nose for at least 2 weeks, even 
though your sinus may feel stuffy or there may be some nasal 
drainage.
-Try not to sneeze; it will cause undesired sinus pressure. If 
you must sneeze, keep your mouth open.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

to ___ she was offered additional pain meds

pelvic ultrasound imaging performed which revealed a multicystic 
and

volume free fluid.  Given new diagnosis of pelvic mass and 
concern for torsion she was transferred to be ___ see for

Ms. ___ is a  ___ year old G5P4 transferred from

for observation.

On presentation, she was hemodynamically stable with only mild 
discomfort. Physical exam was notable for mild RLQ tenderness 
without peritoneal signs. Throughout her admission, her pain was 
stable and not requiring analgesics; serial abdominal exams were 
likewise stable and reassuring. Ovarian torsion was deemed 
unlikely. There was not an indication for urgent surgical 
intervention.

appropriate follow-up scheduled.

Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the gynecology service for an adnexal cyst 
and concern for intermittent torsion (twisting of the ovary). 
Your exam is reassuring and we do not think the ovary is twisted 
at this time. Your doctors feel that ___ are safe to go home 
with close followup in the clinic this week to plan for surgery. 
Please call Dr. ___ office at ___ with any 
questions or concerns.

Please follow these instructions when you go home: 
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may take ibuprofen and Tylenol for pain control.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* You may eat a regular diet.

Call our office for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the gynecology service for an adnexal cyst
and concern for intermittent torsion (twisting of the ovary).
Your exam is reassuring and we do not think the ovary is twisted
at this time. Your doctors feel that ___ are safe to go home
with close followup in the clinic this week to plan for surgery.

questions or concerns.
Please follow these instructions when you go home:
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may take ibuprofen and Tylenol for pain control.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* You may eat a regular diet.

* fever > 100.4F

* difficulty urinating

* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication

hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

inferior leads. He underwent nuclear stress which was positive

respiratory symptoms and nonproductive cough. CTA of his chest

nodular ground glass opacity in the right lung suspicious for

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was transferred to ___ and underwent routine 
preoperative evaluation. Workup was notable for URI symptoms and 
was started on Ceftriaxone for empiric PNA. Remainder of pre-op 
work up was unremarkable and he was cleared for surgery. He 
remained pain free on medical therapy.

The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where 
the patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting surgery - 
for details, please see operative note.  Overall the patient 
tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring.  
 POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery.  Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued 
without complication.  The patient was evaluated by the Physical 
Therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility.  By 
the time of discharge on POD#4 the patient was ambulating 
freely, the wound was healing with scant serosang drainage, 
sternum was stable and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. 
 The patient was discharged to home in good condition with 
appropriate follow up instructions.

Moderate layering right and small layering left pleural effusion
