demonstrated for surgical planning. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent uncomplicated resection of biliary 
cystadenoma (segment 7) with intra-op placement of JP drain. On 
POD 1, her pain was not controlled by mixed epidural, it was 
d/c'ed and she was placed on Dilaudid PCA and given tordol 30mg 
IV q6 x3 days with better pain control. She was nauseous and 
given chompazine. Her foley was also d/c'ed and she voided 
spontaneously. She was noted to have SBP to ___ and was given 
500cc NS bolus to good effect. On POD 2, she complained of 
migraine; she was evaluated by anesthesia who were confident her 
migraine was unrelated to epidural and she was started on 
fiorcet. She underwent CXR for dyspnea and was noted to have 
moderate layering right and small layering left pleural effusion 
with likely compressive atelectasis; she was encouraged to use 
IS. On POD 3, she was switched to PO pain medication, tolerating 
regular diet, and had flatus. Her JP drain was removed. On POD 
4, she was in better pain control with increased Dilaudid 
dosage, ambulating, tolerating regular diet, and was discharged 
home.

Tablet Refills:*0

prn: headache 
Please wait 7 days after surgery before restarting this 
medication

hepatic cyst
biliary cystadenoma

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
For pain control: please Tylenol ___ every 6 hours as needed. 
Do not take more than 3g of Tylenol in a 24 hour period. You can 
also take ibuprofen 400 mg every 8 hours as needed. If your pain 
is not controlled with Tylenol and ibuprofen, you can take 
Dilaudid ___ every 3 hours as needed. Do NOT take more than 3 
pills every 3 hours. You should try to take less Dilaudid over 
the next few days as your post-operative incisional pain 
improves. 

Please call Dr. ___  at ___ for fever > 
101, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, inability 
to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of skin or 
eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or 
bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine output or dark, 
cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, or any other 
concerning symptoms.

No straining or heavy lifting (nothing heavier than 10 pounds)
You may shower, rinse and pat incision dry. Do not apply 
powder/lotion/ointment to incision. 
No tub baths or swimming

No driving if taking narcotic pain medication

 
Followup Instructions:

PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS:
1. Right ovary and tube with large mass, excision:
Mucinous carcinoma, arising in a background of borderline 
mucinous tumor, intestinal type. See note
and synoptic report.
Note: Areas of destructive pattern invasion are present (for 
example, block ___, where it measures
1.6 cm in expanse on a single slide), as well as areas of 
cribriform growth and other areas with
prominent intraluminal papillary growth.
2. Omentum, biopsy:
- Benign fibroadipose tissue with acute and chronic 
inflammation, reactive mesothelial changes, and
focal decidualization.
- No malignancy identified.
3. ___ placenta, 296 grams (approximately ___ percentile 
for gestational age of ___ weeks 3
days):
- Placenta with multifocal infarct, involving approximately 10% 
of the placental body, and chorionic
villi with accelerated maturity, consistent with maternal 
vascular malperfusion.
- Unremarkable three-vessel umbilical cord and fetal membranes.
- No malignancy identified.

Peritoneal washings ___
DIAGNOSIS:
PELVIC WASHING:
NEGATIVE FOR MALIGNANT CELLS.
Unremarkable and reactive mesothelial cells, lymphocytes, 
histiocytes and red blood cells
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ G1 P0 who was transferred from an 
outside hospital with severe IUGR, oligohydramnios, newly 
diagnosed severe gestational hypertension.  She was started on 
magnesium.  She developed recurrent late decelerations.  
Decision was made to proceed
with cesarean section.  Decision was made to proceed through a 
vertical skin incision due to a large 24 cm ovarian mass, with 
plan to remove the mass at time of cesarean section. She thus 
underwent an urgent primary low transverse, right 
salpingo-oophorectomy, washings, omental bx via midline vertical 
incision for decreased FM and 24cm pelvic mass on ___ with 
both maternal fetal medicine and gynecologic oncology present. 
She was also with Crohn's disease and severe gestational 
hypertension. 

She completed 24 hours of IV magnesium infusion postpartum, and 
was initiated on nifedipine 30mg daily on ___ for elevated 
blood pressure readings. Her serum pregnancy-induced 
hypertension labs were notable for elevated uric acid of 6.2, 
but were otherwise within normal limits. For her Crohn's 
disease, she was maintained on Zantac daily, and Zofran as 
needed.

Final pathology of the pelvic mass was found to be mucinous 
carcinoma in background of borderline, with planned presentation 
at gynecologic oncology tumor board for further treatment 
planning and follow-up scheduled. 

Her pain was treated with oral pain medications. She ambulated 
and her foley was discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her 
diet was advanced without incident. 

By postpartum day 5, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS:
1. Right ovary and tube with large mass, excision:
Mucinous carcinoma, arising in a background of borderline
mucinous tumor, intestinal type. See note
and synoptic report.
Note: Areas of destructive pattern invasion are present (for
example, block ___, where it measures
1.6 cm in expanse on a single slide), as well as areas of
cribriform growth and other areas with
prominent intraluminal papillary growth.
2. Omentum, biopsy:
- Benign fibroadipose tissue with acute and chronic
inflammation, reactive mesothelial changes, and
focal decidualization.
- No malignancy identified.
3. ___ placenta, 296 grams (approximately ___ percentile
for gestational age of ___ weeks 3
days):
- Placenta with multifocal infarct, involving approximately 10%
of the placental body, and chorionic
villi with accelerated maturity, consistent with maternal
vascular malperfusion.
- Unremarkable three-vessel umbilical cord and fetal membranes.
- No malignancy identified.
Peritoneal washings ___
DIAGNOSIS:
PELVIC WASHING:
NEGATIVE FOR MALIGNANT CELLS.
Unremarkable and reactive mesothelial cells, lymphocytes,
histiocytes and red blood cells
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ G1 P0 who was transferred from an
outside hospital with severe IUGR, oligohydramnios, newly
diagnosed severe gestational hypertension. She was started on
magnesium. She developed recurrent late decelerations.
Decision was made to proceed
with cesarean section. Decision was made to proceed through a
vertical skin incision due to a large 24 cm ovarian mass, with
plan to remove the mass at time of cesarean section. She thus
underwent an urgent primary low transverse, right
salpingo-oophorectomy, washings, omental bx via midline vertical
incision for decreased FM and 24cm pelvic mass on ___ with
both maternal fetal medicine and gynecologic oncology present.
She was also with Crohn's disease and severe gestational
hypertension.
She completed 24 hours of IV magnesium infusion postpartum, and
was initiated on nifedipine 30mg daily on ___ for elevated
blood pressure readings. Her serum pregnancy-induced
hypertension labs were notable for elevated uric acid of 6.2,
but were otherwise within normal limits. For her Crohn's
disease, she was maintained on Zantac daily, and Zofran as
needed.
Final pathology of the pelvic mass was found to be mucinous
carcinoma in background of borderline, with planned presentation
at gynecologic oncology tumor board for further treatment
planning and follow-up scheduled.
Her pain was treated with oral pain medications. She ambulated
and her foley was discontinued and she voided spontaneously. Her
diet was advanced without incident.
By postpartum day 5, she was tolerating a regular diet,
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Nothing in the vagina for 6 weeks (No sex, douching, tampons)

Do not drive while taking narcotics (i.e. Dilaudid, Percocet)

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Assault

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
 ___ yo RH ___ s/p assault while at fraternity party earlier
this evening.  Does not remember circumstances, but supposedly
body slammed to ground.  + LOC.  Since then been thinking 
clearly
without any seizures, focal weakness or numbness.  Denies pain
elsewhere besides facial abrasions.

 
Past Medical History:
None, no surgeries

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission: 
Gen: WD/WN, comfortable, NAD.
HEENT: Multiple areas of facial abrasions
Neck: Supple.  No TTP, full ROM without collar.
Lungs: CTA bilaterally.
Cardiac: RRR. 
Abd: Soft, NT, 
Extrem: Warm and well-perfused.
Neuro:
AOx3, CN II-XII intact bilaterally, ___ ___, no sensory
deficits to LT throughout, 1+ DTR

Upon discharge: 
a&ox3. conversant. speech fluent. Comprehension intact
PERRL, EOMs intact, face symmetric, tongue midline 
___ Strength 
No drift 
senstation grossly intact 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ NCHCT
1.  Nondisplaced fracture of the left frontal bone extending 
through the left frontal sinus, left anterior ethmoid air cells, 
and left olfactorygroove. 
2.  Left inferior frontal epidural hematoma associated with the 
fracture. 
3.  Small left temporal extraaxial hematoma, likely subdural in 
the absence of an adjacent fracture. 
4.  Small right inferior temporal hemorrhagic contusion. Small 
amount of 
subarachnoid blood in the right sylvian fissure and right 
temporal sulci. 
Small subdural hematoma along the right tentorium. 
5.  The anterior falx is slightly tented to the right. All 
components of the right lateral ventricle are smaller than the 
left, suggesting congenital or developmental etiology, rather 
than compression, but this could be clarified on follow up.  

___ CT Cspine
 No cervical spine fracture or malalignment.

___ NCHCT
1.  Stable small right inferior temporal hemorrhagic contusion 
with minimally increased edema, as expected. Stable small amount 
of adjacent paratentorial subdural blood. Decreased right 
temporal and sylvian fissure subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
2.  Unchanged to slightly decreased small epidural hematoma 
underlying the nondisplaced left frontal bone fracture. 
Decreased pneumocephalus. 
3.  Previously noted small left temporal subdural hematoma is 
now less 
conspicuous; this area is partially obscured by bone related 
artifacts.  
4.  The nondisplaced left frontal bone fracture extends into the 
left frontal and anterior ethmoid sinuses, as well as the left 
olfactory groove, as seen previously. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo s/p assault with TBI who was admitted to the neurosurgical 
service. Cspine was cleared and cervical Collar removed in ED.  
Neurologically intact without signs of CSF leak.  Admitted to 
the floor for observation, start on 7 day course of keppra. 
Repeat head CT stable. 

On ___ Patient remains neurologically stable. Denies HA, 
nausea. Continues keppra. Patient was discharged home in stable 
conditions with instructions for follow up. 

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN fever or pain 
2. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN constipation 
3. LeVETiracetam 500 mg PO BID Duration: 7 Days 
RX *levetiracetam 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*12 Tablet Refills:*0
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q ___ hours PRN pain 
Disp #*45 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Traumatic Brain Injury 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, or 
Ibuprofen etc. 
You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will 
not require blood work monitoring.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion, lethargy or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
New onset of the loss of function, or decrease of function on 
one whole side of your body.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ y/o highly functional man with GERD presented with ___ days 
of abdominal pain and distention.  He saw his PCP after having ___ 
few episodes of loose stool.  At that time his symptoms were 
attributed to resolving gastrointestinal infection, however his 
abdominal pain progressed and he developed progressive 
distention.  He then presented to ___ where a CT abdomen 
was completed which showed impressive large bowel obstruction 
without volvulus.  He was then transferred to ___ for surgical 
evaluation.  
.
In the ED, initial VS were: 98.1 78 117/79 16 95%.  He received 
1L NS, and was given morphine 4mg x3 for pain control, zofran 
for nausea, and KCL replacement.  He was seen by surgery who 
recommended hemi-colectomy and diverting colostomy, however he 
adamently refused.  GI was then consulted for possible 
decompression and he was transferred to the MICU.  Most recent 
set of vitals is 82, 126/74, 16, 93%.
.  
On arrival to the MICU, he reports improved pain control with 
morphine.  He has not passed flatus or stool for the past three 
days.  Endorses nausea, but no vomitting.  Poor PO intake and 
feels very thirsty.

CT abdomen: CTA/P: official read pending but per verbal report 
there is a complete obstruction of the colon at the level of the 
sigmoid. 
Some swirling in mesentery but not consistent with volvulus.  No

Sigmoidoscopy ___: A volvulus was seen in the sigmoid colon at 
approximately 30 cm. The colon above the volvulus was dilated. 
The colon was successfully decompressed with improvement in his 
abdominal distention. No mass or other lesions were seen. 
Otherwise normal sigmoidoscopy to descending colon

Sigmoidoscopy ___: A volvulus was seen in the sigmoid colon at 
approximately 30 cm. The colon above the volvulus was dilated. 
The colon was successfully decompressed with improvement in his 
abdominal distention. No mass or other lesions were seen. The 
mucosa proximal to the volvulus was noted to be edematous. 
Otherwise normal sigmoidoscopy to transverse colon
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w history of GERD, highly functional baseline, presents 
with colonic obstruction and was found to have recurrent 
volvulus refractory to decompression.
.  
ACTIVE ISSUES
Colonic obstruction: The pt was found to have a sigmoid volvulus 
on CT.  The pt was transfered to ___ for further evaluation, and 
the pt was offered operative treatment.  The pt did not want a 
surgery, but agreed to attempt to have colonoscopic 
decompression.  The pt underwent a decompression on the first 
day he was here, but he failed to pass flatus and stools the 
next day.  In the setting of a rising WBC, patient was started 
empirically on vanco/ceftriaxone.  A repeat KUB showed that he 
had a recurrent volulus, and the pt was decompressed again.  
Again, he failed to improve and didn't pass stool or flatus the 
next day, and again a repeat KUB showed that he had another 
sigmoid volvulus.  The pt continued to decline surgery for fear 
of a colostomy.  After family meeting with primary and 
palliative care teams, the decision was given to advance to 
comfort care, as patient wished to stay comfortable with no 
aggressive intervention.  Pt developed abdominal pain on HD3, 
and responded well to morhpine.  
OUTPATIENT ISSUES
- Comfort measures only
- Morphine IV ___ mg every two hours prn for pain
- Tylenol ___ IV prn for headache
- Zofran 4 mg IV q8 for prn for nausea
.
CHRONIC ISSUES
#) GERD: Pt initially tx with PPI, d/c'ed given change of goals 
of care.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
Pt is DNR/DNI, and is on comfort measure only.  Pt's family is 
aware and supportive of his decision. 
 
Medications on Admission:
OMEPRAZOLE - 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) - 1 Capsule(s)
by mouth once a day

 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every six 
(6) hours as needed for pain, tactile fever: please do not 
exceed 4gm acetaminophen per day.  
2. ondansetron HCl (PF) 4 mg/2 mL Solution Sig: ___  Injection 
Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for nausea.  
3. acetaminophen 1,000 mg/100 mL (10 mg/mL) Solution Sig: One 
(1)  Intravenous Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain: Please 
do not exceed daily dose of 4 gram.  
4. morphine 5 mg/mL Solution Sig: One (1)  Injection Q2H (every 
2 hours) as needed for pain: can titrate to RR >8, < 20.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Sigmoid volvulus
 
Discharge Condition:
Fair
 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

___ was a pleasure to take care of you while you were here in the 
hospital.  As we discussed, part of your intestines is twisted 
upon itself, and despite trying to untwist twice with the 
colonoscope, it continues to remain twisted.  The area of your 
intestine that's twisted is called the sigmoid colon, and the 
medical word for "twisted" is "volvulus", so your diagnosis is a 
sigmoid volvulus.  

After considerable discussion about your options and what would 
be in your best interest, you arrived at the conclusion that the 
best thing for you would not be a surgery, and rather to focus 
on comfort care and control your pain.  We agreed with this, and 
arranged for you to go to a hospice home where they will 
continue to treat your pain and make you comfortable.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ 04:44AM BLOOD Lactate-1.4
CT abdomen: CTA/P: official read pending but per verbal report
there is a complete obstruction of the colon at the level of the
sigmoid.
Some swirling in mesentery but not consistent with volvulus. No
obvious sigmoid mass.
Sigmoidoscopy ___: A volvulus was seen in the sigmoid colon at
approximately 30 cm. The colon above the volvulus was dilated.
The colon was successfully decompressed with improvement in his
abdominal distention. No mass or other lesions were seen.
Otherwise normal sigmoidoscopy to descending colon
Sigmoidoscopy ___: A volvulus was seen in the sigmoid colon at
approximately 30 cm. The colon above the volvulus was dilated.
The colon was successfully decompressed with improvement in his
abdominal distention. No mass or other lesions were seen. The
mucosa proximal to the volvulus was noted to be edematous.
Otherwise normal sigmoidoscopy to transverse colon
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w history of GERD, highly functional baseline, presents
with colonic obstruction and was found to have recurrent
volvulus refractory to decompression.
.
ACTIVE ISSUES
Colonic obstruction: The pt was found to have a sigmoid volvulus
on CT. The pt was transfered to ___ for further evaluation, and
the pt was offered operative treatment. The pt did not want a
surgery, but agreed to attempt to have colonoscopic
decompression. The pt underwent a decompression on the first
day he was here, but he failed to pass flatus and stools the
next day. In the setting of a rising WBC, patient was started
empirically on vanco/ceftriaxone. A repeat KUB showed that he
had a recurrent volulus, and the pt was decompressed again.
Again, he failed to improve and didn't pass stool or flatus the
next day, and again a repeat KUB showed that he had another
sigmoid volvulus. The pt continued to decline surgery for fear
of a colostomy. After family meeting with primary and
palliative care teams, the decision was given to advance to
comfort care, as patient wished to stay comfortable with no
aggressive intervention. Pt developed abdominal pain on HD3,
and responded well to morhpine.
OUTPATIENT ISSUES
- Comfort measures only
- Morphine IV ___ mg every two hours prn for pain
- Tylenol ___ IV prn for headache
- Zofran 4 mg IV q8 for prn for nausea
.
CHRONIC ISSUES
#) GERD: Pt initially tx with PPI, d/c'ed given change of goals
of care.
.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
Pt is DNR/DNI, and is on comfort measure only. Pt's family is
aware and supportive of his decision.
Medications on Admission:
OMEPRAZOLE - 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) - 1 Capsule(s)
by mouth once a day
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every six
(6) hours as needed for pain, tactile fever: please do not
exceed 4gm acetaminophen per day.
2. ondansetron HCl (PF) 4 mg/2 mL Solution Sig: ___ Injection
Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for nausea.
3. acetaminophen 1,000 mg/100 mL (10 mg/mL) Solution Sig: One
(1) Intravenous Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain: Please
do not exceed daily dose of 4 gram.
4. morphine 5 mg/mL Solution Sig: One (1) Injection Q2H (every
2 hours) as needed for pain: can titrate to RR >8, < 20.
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
Sigmoid volvulus
Discharge Condition:
Fair
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,
___ was a pleasure to take care of you while you were here in the
hospital. As we discussed, part of your intestines is twisted
upon itself, and despite trying to untwist twice with the
colonoscope, it continues to remain twisted. The area of your
intestine that's twisted is called the sigmoid colon, and the
medical word for "twisted" is "volvulus", so your diagnosis is a
sigmoid volvulus.
After considerable discussion about your options and what would
be in your best interest, you arrived at the conclusion that the
best thing for you would not be a surgery, and rather to focus
on comfort care and control your pain. We agreed with this, and
arranged for you to go to a hospice home where they will
continue to treat your pain and make you comfortable.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ via transfer from 
___ with a right open calcaneal fracture.  He 
was admitted, consented, and taken to the operating room.  He 
underwent an I&D with VAC placement of his right calcaneal 
fracture wound.  He tolerated the procedure well, was extubated, 
transferred to the recovery room and then to the floor.  On 
___ he returned to the operating room and underwent a 
repeat I&D of his right calcaneal fracture with VAC change.  He 
tolerated the procedure well, was extubated, transferred to the 
recovery room and then to the floor.  On ___ he returned to 
the operating room and underwent an I&D of the right calcaneal 
wound with ORIF by orthopaedics and a split thickness skin graft 
to his wound by plastic surgery.  He tolerated the procedure 
well, was extubated, transferred to the recovery room and then 
to the floor.  He remained on bedrest per plastic surgery for 
graft protection.  His splint was changed on ___ to provide 
improved padding.  On ___ his VAC was removed by plastic 
surgery and his antibiotics were stopped.  On ___ he was 
taken off bedrest and worked with physical therapy, though was 
only allowed to dangle his leg (have it dependent for 15 minutes 
3 times a day).  On ___ he was able to start physical 
therapy and was cleared for home with ___.  Foley ___ was 
removed and he voided 500cc prior to discharge.

The rest of his hospital stay was uneventful with his lab data 
and vital signs within normal limits and his pain controlled.  
He is being discharged today in stable condition.

Antidepressant - unknown med and dose

6 hours).

Subcutaneous Q12H (every 12 hours) for 18 days.
Disp:*36 syringes* Refills:*0*
5. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Fall from ladder
Right open calcaneus fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable/Good

 
Discharge Instructions:
Continue to be non-weight bearing on your right leg

Continue to take your lovenox injections as instructed

Please take all medication as prescribed

If you have any increased pain, swelling, and or numbness, not 
relieved with rest, elevation and or pain medication, or if you 
have any other concerning symptoms, please call the office or

You have been prescribed a narcotic pain medication.  Please 
take only as directed and do not drive or operate any machinery 
while taking this medication.  There is a 72 hour ___ 
through ___, 9am to 4pm) response time for prescription refil 
requests.  There will be no prescription refils on ___, 
___, or holidays.  Please plan accordingly.

total thyroidectomy

thyroidectomy

asthma, reflux

___
Family History:
NC

AVSS

HEENT - neck soft, incision CDI
CV - rrr
Pulm - CTAB
abd - soft NTND
extrem - no c/c/e
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:45AM BLOOD Calcium-8.0*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted postperatively to the ___ surgery service 
under the care of Dr ___. The patient tolerated the 
procedure well. her diet was advanced from clrs to regular and 
her pain was well controlled on PO pain medication. Her calcium 
came back at 8 on POD 1 and she was started on a regimen of 
synthroid and TUMS 1000 TID. She will be discharged to home on 
that regimen and have her medications adjusted in clinic when 
she follows up with Dr ___.
 
Medications on Admission:
albuterol prn

 
Discharge Medications:
1. hydrocodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every six (6) hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. calcium carbonate 200 mg calcium (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable 
Sig: Three (3) Tablet, Chewable PO TID (3 times a day).
Disp:*270 Tablet, Chewable(s)* Refills:*2*
3. levothyroxine 100 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
multinodular goiter

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure to take care of you after your surgery. You 
have adequate pain control and have tolerated a regular diet and 
may return home to continue your recovery. You will be 
discharged home on thyroid medication Levothyroxine take 100 mcg 
once a day and Tums(Calcium Carbonate)1500 mg three times a 
day.Please monitor for signs and symptoms of low Calcium such as 
numbness or tingling around mouth or fingetips. If you 
experience any of these signs or symptoms you may take an extra 
dose of Tums, however if symptoms continue please call Dr. 
___ or go to emergency room.
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication and take any new 
medications as prescribed. You will be given a prescription for 
narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed.It is recommended 
that you take a stool softner such as Colace while taking oral 
narcotic pain medication ton prevent constipation. You may also 
take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 
mg in one day. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk 
several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 
Incision Care:
Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your 
surgeon.Gently pat the area dry.You have a neck incision with 
steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own. 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Pt is a ___ y/o F with PMHx bulimia, who is presenting with 
intractible vomiting. The patient reports she last induced

that recommended the ___. She tried to check into

her persistent vomiting and was referred to the ___ ED. On

bicarb of 19. She received 3L of IVF. She vomited 3 times in the 
ED despite receiving zofran and compazine. There was some 
initial concern for QT prolongation on her ECG; however, this 
was ultimately not felt to be the case. Given her persistent 
vomiting, she was admitted to the medicine service for further 
management.  
 
On arrival to the floor, the patient's VS were Temp 99.4 F, BP 
122/80, HR 61, RR 18, O2-sat 99% RA. She endorsed the above 
symptoms. She reported intermittent dizziness and 
lightheadedness. She endorsed some nausea and abdominal cramping 
associated with her vomiting. She also reported some slight 
tingling in her fingers and toes. She denied any blood in her 
emesis. She also endorsed some recent chills. She reported that 
these symptoms have been present for the past week.

congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, 
diarrhea, dysuria, hematuria. She reports that she has not had a 
bowel movement in several days.

KUB - IMPRESSION: No evidence of obstruction or ileus.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was started on the eating protocol the day of 
admission.  On HD #1 she was started on solid foods and vomited 
after eating which was not believed to be induced.  She was then 
started on ensure supplements which she tolerated throughout HD 
#2.  She was started once again on solids on HD #3 and vomited 
once again, which was again not believed to be induced. The 
patient expressed concern that limited food options were 
available to her because she was vegetarian.  It was also 
thought that anxiety was playing a large role in her inability 
to tolerate solid foods.  She reported severe anxiety at the 
thought of eating foods which she felt was causing her vomiting. 
She was therefore started on zyprexa and ativan.  She was also 
taken off of the eating protocol because after three days she 
had not tolerated any solid food intake, and the medical staff 
felt that if she had more choice that maybe she would be less 
likely to vomit.  On HD #4 and #5 she remained off of the eating 
protocol but was also reporting significantly more anxiety and 
she was therefore able only to tolerate popsicles and juice.  
Her ativan and zyprexa were switched to be given prior to meals 
with mild impact on her anxiety.  On HD#6 her ativan dosing was 
increased, however the patient still reported being too anxious 
to tolerate any oral intake.  

The day of admission the patient's potassium was 3.4 and she 
received 40meq of potassium.  Her Potassium remained normal for 
4 days.  On ___ her potassium was 3.2 and she was given 60meq 
of potassium.  On ___ her potassium was 4.2.  her calcium and 
magnesium remained normal throughout her hospitalization.  Her 
phosphate was mildly elevated.

The patient was considered to be medically stable throughout her 
entire hospital course.  Per family request, the patient was 
transferred to ___.  ekg the day of transfer was read as 
normal sinus rhythm at 65, normal axis, no hypertrophy, normal 
PR QRS and QT intervals, no ischemic ST or t wave changes.

- prozac 40 mg daily (hasn't taking since last ___  
- ativan PRN

(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).  
2. Olanzapine 2.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a 
day as needed for anxiety or nausea/vomiting: administer ___ 
minutes prior to meals.  
3. Lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 times a 
day): administer ___ minutes prior to meals.  
4. Fluoxetine 20 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Ondansetron 4 mg Tablet, Rapid Dissolve Sig: One (1) Tablet, 
Rapid Dissolve PO Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for nausea.  
6. Zolpidem 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) 
as needed for insomnia.  
7. Alum-Mag Hydroxide-Simeth 200-200-20 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: 
___ MLs PO QID (4 times a day) as needed for heartburn.  
8. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times a day) 
as needed for constipation.  
9. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).

Extended Care

___

Primary Diagnosis
- Eating disorder not otherwise specified.
- Anxiety

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted ot the hospital with vomiting related to your 
eating disorder.  During the course of your hospitalization it 
was unsuccessfully attempted to get you to tolerate oral food 
intake.
It was decided that an eating disorder facility would be better 
able to manage your eating disorder.

You were started on zyprexa while you were here.
You were started on ativan while you were here.
You were also started on ambien for sleep.

It was a pleasure taking part in your medical care.

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
achalasia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
laparoscopic ___ myotomy

 
History of Present Illness:
she is a ___
woman who has had increasing dysphagia since last year.  She has
progressively gotten worse where both liquids and solids get
stuck.  She knows the cold liquids are the worst.  She also has 
a
choking sensation, which gets worse toward the end of the meal. 
She wakes up at night coughing and spitting up without a true
vomiting.  The patient has had a workup, which included an
endoscopy, which showed some tight sphincter.  Normal mucosa.  A
motility study is consistent with achalasia.

 
Past Medical History:
achalasia
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family history is
notable for father with prostate cancer, reflux, hypertension,
and stroke.

 
Physical Exam:
vitals: 98.3 73 103/49 16 97RA
Abd: s/ND/NT, incisions c/d/i
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ ng tube was discontinued, she was started on a 
clear liquid diet which she tolerated well.  Her foley was 
removed POD1, she voided without assistance.  Pain well 
controlled on po meds.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Q4hour Disp #*40 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
achalasia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Your diet will be advanced from clear liquids to solids as you 
recover from your surgery.  Every patient is recovers 
differently and will tolerate diet advancement based on that.  
Foods that are soft in texture makes swallowing easier as the 
operative swelling of the esophagus decreases.  These 
suggestions will help you as you recover.  Remember that your 
stomach was also used as part of the fundoplication wrap so you 
will be eating much less than prior to surgery and will fill 
much more quickly.  It is suggested that you eat smaller, more 
frequent meals including snacks.  Limit drinking large amounts 
of liquids at meal time to avoid filling quickly.  Also avoid 
drinking liquids through a straw as this may cause you to 
swallow air leading to gas in your abdomen and bloating.  Avoid 
chewing gum, tobacco and carbonated beverages as these items can 
cause the same problem.

You will be discharged on clear liquids and very soft moist 
foods such as eggs, yogurt, cottage cheese, soups, chowders, 
puddings, Jell-O, ice cream, sherbet, etc.  Sweet foods may 
digest faster than others so eat sweets at the end of your meal. 
 If you are having no hold-up or the feeling of food sticking, 
you may advance your diet to canned fruits and vegetables, 
whipped white and sweet potatoes, squash, etc.  If you have 
continued success, you may now implement things like flaky fish, 
chicken and ___ steak.  If you continue to have no issues, 
you may then advance your diet to foods like fresh fruits and 
vegetables, side dishes of pasta and rice and salads such as 
tuna, chicken, pasta and potato.   

A high percentage of patients are able to advance their diet so 
that when they return for their 2 week postoperative check-up, 
they are digesting everything except  bread / cake like products 
including crackers, chips, pizza crust, tortilla chips etc.  
Foods that have a sharp consistency are prohibited for at least 
4 to 6 weeks to avoid puncturing the wrap. You should also avoid 
items like popcorn, nuts and meats with a lot of gristle.

The postoperative adjustment period is approximately 4 to 6 
weeks so do not feel discouraged if you cannot advance your diet 
as quickly as youd like.  It is a trial and error type effort.  
If initially you try something and you have some issues, wait 
and try again in several days.  The wrap initially is very tight 
and will loosen over time.  Every patients body reacts to 
surgery differently and the esophagus could be still swollen 
enough so that you cannot advance your diet to your liking.  
Some patients are seen for their first postoperative visit and 
are still on very soft solids.  You should not be alarmed by 
this and Dr. ___ will further discuss this with you at the 
time of your postoperative visit.  

Also, some patients have the feeling of having a stiff neck, 
shoulder discomfort or some chest pressure.  This could be the 
result of the laparoscopic surgery when air is used as part of 
the procedure and, oftentimes, gets trapped into the diaphragm.  
If the pain does not warrant narcotic use but is still annoying 
you can try taking ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours.  Use this 
medication only if you can take aspirin based medication and you 
do not get stomach upset or have issues with bleeding.  This 
does, however, take a week or so to resolve.

If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to 
contact the office at ___.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ 04:45PM URINE  COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___
___ 04:45PM   GLUCOSE-115* UREA N-16 CREAT-1.1 SODIUM-138 
POTASSIUM-4.2 CHLORIDE-100 TOTAL CO2-29 ANION GAP-13
___ 04:45PM   ALT(SGPT)-12 AST(SGOT)-13 ALK PHOS-57 TOT 
BILI-1.8* DIR BILI-0.3 INDIR BIL-1.5
___ 04:45PM   WBC-12.7* RBC-4.68 HGB-15.0 HCT-42.7 MCV-91 
MCH-32.1* MCHC-35.2* RDW-13.1

CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: Lung bases 
demonstrate mild 
bibasilar atelectasis. There is no pleural effusion. There is no 
focal 
consolidation at the lung bases. The visualized portions of 
heart and 
pericardium are unremarkable. 
  
The liver, gallbladder, spleen, adrenals, pancreas, right kidney 
are 
unremarkable. A tiny splenule is incidentally noted. There is 
mild cortical 
thinning at the inferior pole of the left kidney which may 
reflect prior 
infectious/ischemic insult. There is no mesenteric or 
retroperitoneal 
adenopathy. There is no intraperitoneal free fluid or free air. 
Small bowel 
loops are well opacified and appear normal. 
  
CT OF THE PELVIS WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: There is 
fluid-filled mildly 
dilated distal appendix with enhancing wall measuring 
approximately 9 mm in 
widest cross section. There is no associated free air, fluid, 
phlegmon 
consistent with acute noncomplicated appendicitis. There is 
minimal 
periappendiceal fat stranding. Terminal ileum and the cecal base 
are within 
normal limits. Distal ureters, urinary bladder, rectum, sigmoid 
colon, 
prostate, seminal vesicles are within normal limits. There is no 
intrapelvic 
or inguinal adenopathy. 
  
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: No suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous 
lesions are 
noted. 
  
IMPRESSION: Acute noncomplicated appendicitis.

Patient was admitted to general surgery service and underwent 
laparoscopic appendectomy on ___. Tolerated procedure 
well. Diet was advanced as tolerated. Postoperative course was 
uneventfull and he was discharged in stable condition 
ambulating and voiding independently. Requested to f/u with Dr 
___ in ___ weeks.

none

PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain for 1 weeks.

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p laparoscopic appendectomy

stable

Please seek immediate medical attention for fever grater than 
101.5, chills, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, 
shortness of breath or anything else that is trobling you. OK to 

shower, but do not soak the incisions. Please keep your f/u appt 

with Dr ___.

almost 24 hours of abdominal pain that localized to the right
lower quadrant.
Past Medical History:
none
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam:
Afebrile, vs wnl
HEENT PERRLA
Lungs CTAB
Heart RRR
Abd:
Tenderness in RLQ area. + peritoneal signs
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:45PM URINE COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___
___ 04:45PM GLUCOSE-115* UREA N-16 CREAT-1.1 SODIUM-138
POTASSIUM-4.2 CHLORIDE-100 TOTAL CO2-29 ANION GAP-13
___ 04:45PM ALT(SGPT)-12 AST(SGOT)-13 ALK PHOS-57 TOT
BILI-1.8* DIR BILI-0.3 INDIR BIL-1.5
___ 04:45PM WBC-12.7* RBC-4.68 HGB-15.0 HCT-42.7 MCV-91
MCH-32.1* MCHC-35.2* RDW-13.1
CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: Lung bases
demonstrate mild
bibasilar atelectasis. There is no pleural effusion. There is no
focal
consolidation at the lung bases. The visualized portions of
heart and
pericardium are unremarkable.
The liver, gallbladder, spleen, adrenals, pancreas, right kidney
are
unremarkable. A tiny splenule is incidentally noted. There is
mild cortical
thinning at the inferior pole of the left kidney which may
reflect prior
infectious/ischemic insult. There is no mesenteric or
retroperitoneal
adenopathy. There is no intraperitoneal free fluid or free air.
Small bowel
loops are well opacified and appear normal.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: There is
fluid-filled mildly
dilated distal appendix with enhancing wall measuring
approximately 9 mm in
widest cross section. There is no associated free air, fluid,
phlegmon
consistent with acute noncomplicated appendicitis. There is
minimal
periappendiceal fat stranding. Terminal ileum and the cecal base
are within
normal limits. Distal ureters, urinary bladder, rectum, sigmoid
colon,
prostate, seminal vesicles are within normal limits. There is no
intrapelvic
or inguinal adenopathy.
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: No suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous
lesions are
noted.
IMPRESSION: Acute noncomplicated appendicitis.

laparoscopic appendectomy on ___. Tolerated procedure
well. Diet was advanced as tolerated. Postoperative course was
uneventfull and he was discharged in stable condition
ambulating and voiding independently. Requested to f/u with Dr
___ in ___ weeks.

none

Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p laparoscopic appendectomy

stable

Please seek immediate medical attention for fever grater than
101.5, chills, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, chest pain,
shortness of breath or anything else that is trobling you. OK to
shower, but do not soak the incisions. Please keep your f/u appt
with Dr ___.

___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
"my boyfriend broke up with me, I got drunk and
I did a stupid thing"

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o woman with no prior
psychiatric admissions but a prior diagnosis of "mood disorder"
presents via ambulance with a BAL of 166. Two days prior, the
patient states her boyfriend broke up with her and she was
extremely upset, as she states she is "in love with him". Last
night, despite the break up, they had plans to celebrate their
one year anniversary together and he stood her up. She was very
upset over this and in an attempt to calm down and sleep, took 4
extra 1mg Xanax tablets. Later on, she decided to go out with 
her
friends and she became intoxicated. When she arrived home, she
coincidently ran into her ex-BF (they live in the same 
building),
and the patient became argumentative. She admits to questioning
him repeatedly, yelling at him, and pulling his hair and 
punching
him. As she gives this history she is sobbing. She states she 
was
so angry with him, but says "I wish I didn't do this, now he
won't take me back". She then took a knife from his kitchen and
states she held it to her body. She decided to call her mother
during this time, and although does not remember stating that 
she
was suicidal, believes she could have. Her mother encouraged her
boyfriend to call ___ and she was brought to ___.

The patient states she just spoke to her BF because she needed 
to
know whether they are going to be together. She states "I'm 
going
to go insane without him". She says it is going to be very
difficult to go back to the apartment complex where they both
live and he also attend the same school as she does, which she
finds unbearable to think about. She admits to being very
dependent on him and not wanting to be alone.

In ___, patient had a miscarriage and required surgery (8
weeks gestation). Patient was unsure whether she was going to
have the child. Patient seems unsure of whether this event has
affected her.

The patient denies current SI and states that she is afraid of
dying. She denies ever having SI in the past and has no prior
suicide attempts. She states her mother has tried to kill 
herself
a dozen times and believes her behaviour last night was to gain
attention. When asked about depression, the patient admits to
being depressed "always". She has very poor sleep and states she
is extremely moody, especially in the mornings. She sees a
someone for her moods and is currently on Lamcital, as well as
Xanax.

Spoke to her family. Mother and father both have concerns for
their daughter as she is functioning very poorly and is highly
dependent on her boyfriend. Mother says that her daughter told
her earlier in the ED that she would continue to have suicidal
thoughts if she does not get back together with her boyfriend.
However, they deny that she has ever been suicidal before. They
suggest that this is the ___ breakup, but even when she is not
broken up with her BF, she is depressed and recently during a
trip home, could not get out of bed for days. She is also doing
poorly in school. Of note, she sees an NP for her psych meds ___
times yearly.

 
Past Medical History:
PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:
Diagnoses: Mood disorder
Hospitalizations: None, though at age ___, patient became very
upset that she was going to die (question of brain tumor) and 
she
was admitted to a neuro-onc unit.
Medication Trials: Prozac, Zoloft - neither worked per patient.
SA/SIB: None
Outpatient treaters: ___ x ___ years.
 
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Alopecia since age ___, wears wig, recent
surgery for miscarriage

 
Social History:
SUBSTANCE ABUSE HISTORY:
Etoh: Drinks ___ times weekly to intoxication. Does not believe
she has a problem with drinking. Used to blackout but can now
control her drinking. No seizures or DTs.
___ pack per week
Illicit Drug Use: Marijuana once weekly. Denies other drug use 
or
IVDA
 
SOCIAL HISTORY: ___
Family History:
"a ton". Describes her family as
"paranoid and worried". Mother: 12 prior suicide attempts that
the patient relates to attention seeking.

 
Physical Exam:
MENTAL STATUS EXAM:
     APPEARANCE & FACIAL EXPRESSION: Caucasian woman with makeup
running down face, crying intermittently and sometimes
uncontrollably for much of the interview
     POSTURE: Lying in bed facing away from interviewer
     BEHAVIOR: Poor eye contact, no psychomotor deficits
     ATTITUDE: Cooperative
     SPEECH: Regular rate, rythym, and volume
     MOOD: "I have a headache, butterflies in stomach and my 
mind
is racing" 
     AFFECT: depressed and distraught
     THOUGHT FORM: linear, goal oriented
     THOUGHT CONTENT: + paranoia about the way she looks, though
no evidence of delusions
     ABNORMAL PERCEPTIONS: No AH/VH
     SUICIDALITY/HOMICIDALITY: Denies SI/HI
     INSIGHT AND JUDGMENT: fair/limited

     COGNITIVE ASSESSMENT:
          SENSORIUM: Alert
          ORIENTATION: Fully x 3 (person, place, time)
          ATTENTION: MOYB <20 sec
          MEMORY: ___ ___ and ___ after 3 minutes
          CALCULATIONS: 9 quarters in $2.25
          FUND OF KNOWLEDGE: "the inauguration...___'s son
just died"
          PROVERB INTERPRETATION: The grass is greener on the
other side = "something better will happen...just keep on
going...I don't know"
          SIMILARITIES/ANALOGIES: apple/orange = round

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:35AM   GLUCOSE-88 UREA N-6 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-141 
POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-20* ANION GAP-20
___ 07:35AM   estGFR-Using this
___ 07:35AM   TSH-1.1
___ 07:35AM   HCG-43 (of note sequential HCG levels of 40 
and 38)
___ 07:35AM   ASA-NEG ___ ACETMNPHN-NEG 
bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG
___ 07:35AM   WBC-7.4 RBC-4.54 HGB-14.0 HCT-39.7 MCV-87 
MCH-30.8 MCHC-35.2* RDW-13.2
___ 07:35AM   NEUTS-62.1 ___ MONOS-2.8 EOS-3.8 
BASOS-0.3
___ 07:35AM   PLT COUNT-385
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was initially admitted to the inpatient 
psychiatric unit on a ___.  She did sign a conditional 
voluntary on the following day.  She was able to contract for 
safety and was kept on 15 minute checks and remained in good 
behavioral control.  She was monitored for signs of alcohol 
withdrawal and showed no evidience of signficant alcohol 
withdrawal. Her CIWA was discontinued as was her Xanax and she 
was put on Ativan 0.5mg po BID.  There was a concern of a 
possible pregnancy given elevated HCG on admission.  The patient 
had a miscarriage in ___ and OB recommended following 
serial HCG levels and a downward trend should be seen if she is 
in fact not pregnant.  Ms. ___ HCG levels did decrease 
on sequential laboratory tests. At the time of discharge, Ms. 
___ was less anxious and denied any suicidal intent or 
plan.
 
Medications on Admission:
Lamictal 100mg po daily
Xanax 1mg q4-6hrs po prn
Birth Control

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Lamictal 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Ativan 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Adjustment disorder with depressed/anxious features

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable, in agreement with aftercare plans

 
Discharge Instructions:
You should return to the ER if you have thoughts of suicide 
after leaving the hosptial.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
amoxicillin / clavulanic acid / trihydrapotasium
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
L long finger pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Left long finger ORIF, tenden repairs, nerve repairs, artery 
repairs

 
History of Present Illness:
ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY HAND CONSULT NOTE

NAME: ___   
MRN: ___   
DATE: ___
RESIDENT: ___, MD
FELLOW: ___, MD
ATTENDING: ___, MD
CONSULTING SERVICE: ED

CC: Left ring finger band saw injury

HPI: This is a health ___ y/o RHD male p/w a L middle finger band
saw injury. Patient was using band saw at school when his finger
was pulled into the apparatus. He presented to ___ and
was found to have a large laceration extending obliquely from 
the
radial side of the middle phalanx distally over the extensor
surface and wrapping around onto the flexor surface of the 
distal
phalanx. The distal phalanx was noted to be dusky with no flexor
action at the distal phalanx and no extensor capability at the
DIP or PIP. He is insensate over the radial aspect of the finger
distal to the injury. The injury occurred approximately 1145.
Tetanus is UTD, received ceftriaxone 1g at OSH. 

 
Past Medical History:
PMH/PSH: ADHD

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
n/a
 
Physical Exam:
ADMIT

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
In general, the patient is a young male who appears somewhat
uncomfortable.
Vitals: T 98, HR 68, BP 128/82, RR 16, SpO2 96%

Left upper extremity:
Loss of soft tissue and large skin defect along the radial 
aspect
of the middle finger extending from the proximal phalanx on the
extensor surface obliquely to the radial aspect of the finger 
pad
Middle finger fires at the MCP, PIP, does not fire extensor
mechanism or at the PIP
SILT ulnar aspect of middle finger. Insensate radial aspect
distal to injury and volar aspect of finger
+Radial pulse
Distal aspect of middle finger dusky with poor capillary refill

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have L long finger table saw injury and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on ___ for 
1. Irrigation and debridement down to bone.
2. Open reduction and internal fixation of intra-articular
    middle phalangeal fracture at the distal phalangeal
    joint.
3. Open reduction and internal fixation of distal
    phalangeal fracture at the PIP joint.
4. Extensor tendon segmental repair over the distal insertion 
and
middle phalanx.
5. Repair of the FDP tendon in zone 1 with a button.
6. Repair of both digital nerves under the operating room
    microscope.
7. Repair of the ulnar digital artery under the microscope., 
which the patient tolerated well (for full details please see 
the separately dictated operative report). The patient was taken 
from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after recovery 
from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was 
initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and 
progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The 
patient was given perioperative antibiotics and anticoagulation 
per routine. The patients home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The ___ hospital course 
was otherwise unremarkable.  
 At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable 
vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well 
controlled with oral medications, incisions were 
clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels 
spontaneously.The patient will follow up in two weeks per 
routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient 
regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course, and 
all questions were answered prior to discharge.  

 
Medications on Admission:
n/a
 
Discharge Medications:
oxycodone
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left long finger fracture, tendon lacerations, artery 
lacerations, nerve lacerations

 
Discharge Condition:
good

 
Discharge Instructions:
leave splint on. keep hand elevated and warm.  do not use left 
hand for anything.  call ___ to make an appointment for 
follow up.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

normothermic. Dopamine drip was started. CT head/C spine were 
reviewed with radiology, and there was no evidence of traumatic 
injury. CXR showed a tiny left apical pneumothorax status post 
left-sided chest tube placement. Hand x rays showed 1. Right 
hand: Comminuted fracture of the third metacarpal neck. 2. Left 
hand: Mildly displaced fractures involving the metacarpal bones 
and proximal phalanges of the second (index) and third (middle) 
fingers subtle  which are severely comminuted. Hand surgery 
service recommended cefazolin. Toxicology tests were positive 
for barbiturates. An MRI brain was recommended. However, after 
discussion with the family, the patient was made CMO based on 
his wishes manifested prior.

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OTOLARYNGOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
amoxicillin / Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
thyroid cancer
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
LEFT THYROID LOBECTOMY, LEFT CENTRAL NECK DISSECTION

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ y.o. female known to our group for a
papillary thyroid cancer metastatic to left level ___ cervical
lymph nodes returning for follow-up.  She was last seen on
___, and the visit history/exam was notable for a biopsy
proven PTC, and the patient was recommended for lateral neck
ultrasound and tissue sampling as radiographically abnormal 
lymph
nodes were noted.  FNA showed a node was positive for PTC.  She
returns for preoperative counseling.

 
Past Medical History:
thyroid cancer
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
denies problems with anesthesia, denies bleeding
disorders

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: AVSS

General: No apparent distress.
HEENT: CN 5,7,11,12 intact. Neck flat, soft, incisions c/d/i.
OC/OP clear w/o bleeding. Neck dressing in place, clean with
minimal staining. JP x1 holding suction with S/S drainage.
Cardiac: regular rate
Respiratory: Unlabored breathing, without stridor or stertor,
strong voice
Neuro: Alert and oriented, communicative

FOE: 
Left vocal cord hypomobility noted with decrease abduction and 
adduction but cord is mobile.  Cords do not fully approximate, 
suspicion for glottic gap. Right vocal cord mobility is normal. 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 12:54PM BLOOD K-4.5
___ 06:13AM BLOOD Glucose-138* UreaN-9 Creat-0.6 Na-142 
K-4.2 Cl-104 HCO3-20* AnGap-18
___ 12:54PM BLOOD Albumin-4.7 Calcium-8.9 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.6
___ 06:13AM BLOOD Albumin-4.6 Calcium-8.7 Phos-4.0 Mg-1.8
___ 01:25PM BLOOD PTH-69*
___ 01:25PM BLOOD 25VitD-23*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted after undergoing left thyroidectomy and 
left central neck dissection.  Please see the separately 
dictated operative note for details of procedure. The patient 
was extubated and transferred to the hospital floor for further 
post-operative care. The post-operative course was uneventful 
and the patient was discharged to home. 

 

Hospital Course by Systems:

 

Neuro: Pain was well controlled, initially with IV regimen which 
was transitioned to oral regimen once tolerating oral intake. 
Post-operative anti-emetics were given PRN. 

Cardiovascular: Remained hemodynamically stable.  

Pulmonary: Oxygen was weaned and the patient was ambulating 
independently without supplemental oxygen prior to discharge.

HEENT: Calcium, albumin and phosphorus were monitored 
postoperatively and calcium management adjusted accordingly. The 
patient had negative Chvostek and no evidence of paresthesias 
prior to discharge.  She has mild hoarseness with left vocal 
cord hypomobility noted on scope exam. 

GI: Diet was advanced as tolerated after patient passed a video 
swallow. Bowel regimen was given prn

GU: Patient was able to void independently.

Heme: Received pneumatic compression boots for DVT prophylaxis.

Endocrine: Calcium was monitored perioperatively as indicated 
above

ID: Received perioperative antibiotics 

 

At time of discharge, the patient was in stable condition, 
ambulating and voiding independently, and with adequate pain 
control.  The patient was given instructions to follow-up in 
clinic as scheduled. Pt was given detailed discharge 
instructions outlining wound care, activity, diet, and 
follow-up. The patient was provided with prescriptions for new 
medications and informed of the risks and side effects. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroxine
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen (Liquid) 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg/15 mL 650 mg by mouth q6h PRN Disp 
#*473 Milliliter Refills:*0 
2.  Methylprednisolone 4 mg PO DAILY 
TAPER AS INSTRUCTED 
This is dose #  of  tapered doses
RX *methylprednisolone 4 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp 
#*1 Dose Pack Refills:*0 
3.  Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
papillary thyroid cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Division of Otolaryngology  Head and Neck Surgery
Post-Operative Instructions 
Thyroidectomy

ACTIVITY
Go home and rest today.
If you have received general anesthesia, you may feel tired 
and drowsy for a few hours. You should not drink alcoholic 
beverages, drive, operate any machinery, or make legal decision 
for 24 hours.
You need to avoid strenuous activity for 2 weeks
Do NOT lift any weight greater than 10 Lbs for 2 weeks.
You need to follow up with both your surgeon and your 
endocrinologist as scheduled.

FLUIDS & DIET
Start with liquids and, if tolerated, you can eat normal 
foods.

MEDICATIONS
Take pain medication as prescribed.
Resume other medications as prescribed except any aspirin or 
aspirin containing products unless cleared by your surgeon.

CARE OF PROCEDURE SITE
Some swelling of the neck incision is expected
You may note some bloody looking drainage from the region 
where the plastic drain was removed (if you had a drain), for up 
to 5 days.
Apply antibiotic ointment to your incision twice daily for 7 
days after surgery, then STOP antibiotic ointment and use 
vaseline. If there is tape on your incision apply the ointment 
over the tape.
Keep incision dry for 3 days. You may be able to take a bath 
from your shoulders down as long as the incision stays dry. The 
tape will start to fall off on its own.
If there are any crusts/clots on your wound you may gently 
clean them with a Q-tip and Half strength hydrogen peroxide 
(10cc water + 10cc peroxide) as needed. Do not be too vigorous 
or your stitches or staples may break
The stitches do not need to be removed as they are 
dissolvable.

WHEN TO CALL YOUR DOCTOR
Excessive redness of your incision site
Fever greater than 101 degrees Fahrenheit
Sudden excessive swelling of incision site
Make sure you have a follow up appointment with your 
Endocrinologist or Primary Care to have your thyroid labs and 
calcium level checked after surgery.

For questions or problems, please call ___ and ask to 
speak to the nurse during clinic hours.

After hours, or on weekends, dial ___ and ask the 
operator to page the Otolaryngology resident on-call.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
multinodular goiter
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total thyroidectomy, intraoperative nerve monitoring, excision 
of thyroglossal cyst.

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ woman with a previous medical 
history significant for hypercholesterolemia but was otherwise 
previously mainly healthy.The patient has been followed for a 
multinodular goiter for several years.She was moderately 
hyperthyroid in ___ at which time the hyperthyroidism resolved 
spontaneously.  She now more recently has developed evidence of 
recurrent hyperthyroidism and she is presently on antithyroid 
medication.The patient now presents for total thyroidectomy. It 
should also be added that a seemingly cystic nodule has been 
noticed in the midline of her neck and on recent imaging test 
evidence of a thyroglossal cyst has been found. At the time of 
the thyroidectomy we also planned to excise the thyroglossal 
cyst. 
 
Past Medical History:
Hyperthyroidism 
Multinodular goiter
Thyroglossal cyst 
PSH:
Total thyroidectomy, intraoperative nerve monitoring, excision 
of thyroglossal ___
Hypercholesterolemia
TAH/BSO

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No coronary artery disease. 
 
Physical Exam:
VS:98.5,62,116/50, 18, 98% room air
General: well appearing, NAD, clear phonation
HEENT:incision C/D/I, no neck fullness,no hematoma 
Cardiac:regular rate rhythm,S1 S2 normal
Pulmonary:clear,no stridor
Abdomen:soft,nontender, nondistended, normoactive bowel sounds
Extremities: warm,well-perfused, no CCE

 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.5
 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old female with history of multinodular goiter 
who is status post total thyroidectomy, intraoperative nerve 
monitoring, excision of thyroglossal cyst.
The patient tolerated the procedure well and was admitted to the 
inpatient surgical unit. 

Neurological: Post-operatively, she received IV pain medication 
and had good pain control. When tolerating oral intake, the 
patient was transition to oral pain medications. 
Cardiovascular: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
Pulmonary:The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint.
Gastrointestinal:Post-operatively, the patient was given IV 
fluids until tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced the 
same evening, which was tolerated well. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. 
Genitourinary: Patient voided without any difficulty.
ID:The patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection, as was her incision, which was clean, dry, intact,and 
without erythema or hematoma.
Endocrine: The patient's calcium prior to discharge was normal. 
Prophylaxis: The patient wore pneumatic compression boots, and 
was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. 
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.
 
 
 
Medications on Admission:
Aspirin 81 mg PO QD
methimazole 10 mg PO QD
simvastatin 20 mg PO QD
 
Discharge Medications:
1. hydrocodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every six (6) hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. levothyroxine 100 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
4. simvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day as 
needed for constipation.  
6. calcium carbonate 200 mg calcium (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable 
Sig: Three (3) Tablet, Chewable PO BID (2 times a day).
Disp:*180 Tablet, Chewable(s)* Refills:*2*
7. calcitriol 0.25 mcg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
8. Aspirin Childrens 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, 
Chewable PO once a day: Restart on ___.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Multinodular goiter with recurrent hyperthyroidism, thyroglossal 
cyst.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have adequate pain control and have tolerated a regular diet 
and may return home to continue your recovery.We have started 
you on a new thyroid medication,take Levothyroxine 100 mcg once 
a day.Please discontinue taking your Methimazole. Please take 
Tums(Calcium Carbonate)1500 mg twice a day and take Calcitriol 
0.25 mcg once a day. Please monitor for signs and symptoms of 
low Calcium such as numbness or tingling around mouth or 
fingertips. If you experience any of these signs or symptoms you 
may take an extra dose of Tums, however if symptoms continue 
please call Dr. ___ or go to emergency room. 
Please have your Calcium level drawn on ___ day before your follow-up visit).Your blood work can be 
drawn at ___ on the ___ floor.Your follow-up 
appointment with Dr. ___ is scheduled for ___, the interpreter will call you with your follow-up 
appointment time. 
Medications:
Please restart your home dose Aspirin on ___. 
You will be given a prescription for narcotic pain medication, 
take as prescribed. It is recommended that you take a stool 
softner such as Colace while taking oral narcotic pain 
medication to prevent constipation. You may also take 
acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg 
in one day. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several 
times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 
Incision Care:
Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your 
surgeon.Gently pat the area dry.You have a neck incision with 
steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own. 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was a same day admit and on ___ he was brought to 
the operating room where he underwent a coronary artery bypass 
graft x 4. Please see operative report for surgical details. 
Following surgery he was transferred to the CVICU for invasive 
monitoring in stable condition. Within 24 hours he was weaned 
from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and extubated. On 
post-op day one he was started on beta-blockers and diuretics 
and gently diuresed towards his pre-op weight. Later on this day 
he was transferred to the telemetry floor for further care. On 
post-op day two his chest tubes were removed. On post-op day 
three his epicardial pacing wires were removed. During his 
post-op course he worked with physical therapy for strength and 
mobility. And on post-op day 4 he was discharged home with 
visiting nurse and the appropriate ___ appointments.

___ Abdominal xray
Large amount of fecal loading within the colon and rectum 
without evidence for small bowel obstruction or free 
intraperitoneal gas. 

___ CT A/P
1. Findings suggestive of early or partial small bowel 
obstruction, likely due to adhesions, with transition point in 
the left lower quadrant. 

___ CXR
Status post orogastric tube placement.  The tip of the tube is 
beyond the 
film.  The side port is in the stomach. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on 
___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain.  
Admission abdominal/pelvic CT revealed early  or  partial  small 
bowel  obstruction  with transition  point  in  the  left  lower 

quadrant.  The patient was hemodynamically stable and was having 
flatus in the Emergency Dept. The patient was admitted for 
non-operative management of her bowel obstruction. She was kept 
on bowel rest with IV fluid resuscitation, nasogastric tube for 
stomach decompression, and serial abdominal exams. 
.
Pain was resolved. On HD2 the patient was endorsing bowel 
function so the nasogastric tube was discontinued. Diet was 
progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good 
tolerability. The patient voided without problem. During this 
hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was 
adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and 
actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.
.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and denies 
abdominal pain. She was having bowel movements.  The patient was 
discharged home without services. The patient received discharge 
teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding 
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Partial small bowel obstruction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ with abdominal pain and were found to 
have a partial small bowel obstruction. You were managed 
non-operatively with bowel rest, IV fluids, nasogastric tube for 
stomach decompression, and serial abdominal exams. Your pain has 
resolved and you are now tolerating a regular diet and having 
bowel function. You are ready to be discharged home to continue 
your recovery. Please note the following discharge instructions: 


Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Ms ___ is a ___ with mild generalized, bulbar predominant 
AChR+
myasthenia ___ with thymic hyperplasia. She is doing well on
mestinon 60mg TID and prednisone 10mg daily. A chest CT ___
noted a 2.5 cm anterior mediastinal mass. Subsequent chest MRI 
on
___ which noted it to be noted thymic hyperplasia. She
presents today for evaluation for thymectomy. 

She reports that her myasthenia symptoms are well
controlled with prednisone and Mestanon. She endorses diplopia,
ptosis, fatigue with chewing and general exercise, as well as
shortness of breath that resolves quickly with rest. She denies
major muscle weakness, respiratory distress, or falls. She 
presents now for thymectomy.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the 
Operating Room where she underwent a robotic thymectomy via left 
VATS.  She tolerated the procedure well and returned to the PACU 
in stable condition.  She maintained stable hemodynamics and her 
pain was controlled with Toradol and Oxycodone.  Her ___ tube 
drained a scant amount of bloody fluid and had no air leak.  

Following transfer to the Surgical floor she continued to 
progress well.  Her oxygen was weaned off as her room air 
saturations were 94%.  She was able to cough and deep breath 
effectively and use her incentive spirometer. Her port sites 
were healing well.  Her ___ drain was removed on post op day 
#1 and her post pull chest xray revealed a small left apical 
pneumothorax, smaller than ___.  She had some pruritis of 
both calves following removal of her venodyne boots but Sarna 
lotion was applied and relieved her symptoms.  She was up and 
walking independently and was discharged to home on ___ and 
will follow up with Dr. ___ in 2 weeks.

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. PredniSONE 10 mg PO DAILY 
2. norethindrone ac-eth estradiol 1.5-30 mg-mcg oral DAILY 
3. Naproxen 275 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 
4. Pyridostigmine Bromide 60 mg PO Q8H 
5. Calcium 500 + D (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 500 
mg(1,250mg) -200 unit oral TID

1. Pyridostigmine Bromide 60 mg PO Q8H 
2. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID

Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*2
4. Calcium 500 + D (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 500 
mg(1,250mg) -200 unit oral TID 
5. Naproxen 275 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 
6. norethindrone ac-eth estradiol 1.5-30 mg-mcg oral DAILY 
7. PredniSONE 10 mg PO DAILY 
8. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
9. Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q12H:PRN constipation 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Myasthenia ___ with thymic hyperplasia.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
* You were admitted to the hospital for surgery on your thymus 
and you've recovered well. You are now ready for discharge.

* Continue to use your incentive spirometer 10 times an hour 
while awake.

* Check your incisions daily and report any increased redness or 
drainage.   Cover the area with a gauze pad if it is draining.

* Your chest tube dressing may be removed in 48 hours.  If it 
starts to drain, cover it with a clean dry dressing and change 
it  as needed to keep site clean and dry.
 * You will continue to need pain medication once you are home 
but you can wean it over a few weeks as the discomfort resolves. 
 Make sure that you have regular bowel movements while on 
narcotic pain medications as they are constipating which can 
cause more problems.  Use a stool softener or gentle laxative to 
stay regular.

* No driving while taking narcotic pain medication.

* Take Tylenol  ___ mg every 6 hours in between your narcotic.  

* Continue to stay well hydrated and eat well to heal your 
incisions

* Shower daily. Wash incision with mild soap & water, rinse, pat 
dry
 * No tub bathing, swimming or hot tubs until incision healed
 * No lotions or creams to incision site

* Walk ___ times a day and gradually increase your activity as 
you can tolerate.

Call Dr. ___ ___ if you experience:
 -Fevers > 101 or chills
 -Increased shortness of breath, chest pain or any other 
symptoms that concern you.

 

 
 
Followup Instructions:
___
