Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted to the thoracic surgery service
following her right upper lobectomy and right atrial repair. For
detailed description of her procedure please see the
corresponding operative note. She was recovered in the PACU and
later transferred to the floor without issue. She was seen by
the acute pain service who placed a right ESP catheter which
worked well to control her pain initially . Over the following
day her pain control was less adequate so a dilaudid PCA was
added with good response. Her chest tube was also placed to
water seal, but after an increasing pneumothorax was noted, it
was placed to suction. On POD 3 her chest tube was again placed
to water seal. A pneumothorax was noted, but she was otherwise
clinically stable so she remained on water seal. The chest tube
remained with minimal output. On POD 5 she was transitioned to
oral analgesia without issue. On POD 6 it was decided that her
chest tube could be removed. A stitch was placed at the chest
tube site due to some leakage of fluid. Post-pull chest xray
showed a slightly increased pneumothorax. Because of this, we
obtained a repeat chest xray two hours later that showed a
stable size of the small pneumothorax. At this point she was
deemed to be fit for discharge with no active issues. She will
follow up in thoracic clinic in the coming weeks and have her
stitch removed.

___ 10:30AM BLOOD Glucose-90 UreaN-19 Creat-0.7 Na-143 
K-3.7 Cl-105 HCO3-28 AnGap-14

___ 10:30AM BLOOD TSH-2.2

Imaging:
========
FOOT AP,LAT & OBL LEFT  ___ 6:18 ___.
FINDINGS: The bones are diffusely demineralized which reduces 
the sensitivity for detecting subtle non-displaced fracture. 
There is a tiny osseous fragment at the base of the fifth 
metatarsal. Given the morphology and size I doubt this is of 
clinical significance. Otherwise, no definite fracture or 
dislocation is identified. Alignment is anatomic. There is mild 
soft tissue swelling over the dorsum of the foot. Extensive 
vascular calcification is noted.
IMPRESSION: No definite traumatic injury of the foot identified. 
Please note the study is limited secondary to inherent baseline 
severe osteopenia

 
Brief Hospital Course:
1. Foot Pain/Probable fifth metatarsal fracture
- Points to pain on lateral side of left foot.   
- Tylenol ___ every six hours around the clock although she 
sometimes refuses this related to delirium/dementia.
- Ordered for lidocaine patch to start today for more constant 
pain relief in addition to the Tylenol.
- podiatry recomended conservative managment, weight bearing as 
tolerated. 
.
2. Dementia/Depression/Delrium 
- Dementia diagnosed in past six months
- Delirium related to Ativan, change in environment ( to 
assisted living and then hospitalization).  No infectious cause 
found.  TSH normal.  RPR non-reactive.  Family does not want 
brain imaging at this time.  B12 low, received one dose IM then 
oral replacement therapy was started.
- Psych and Geriatric teams consulted to assist with delirium 
workup, possible pain, and assistance with medication 
management.
- She was given Ativan TID three weeks prior to admission, this 
seemed to exacerbate her behavior.  It was tapered off in the 
hospital last dose ___ am.  She was getting Haldol BID while 
in the hospital with little effect.  With consultation with 
geriatrics and psych her regimen was changed to start Seroquel 
12.5mg BID PRN agitation to start tonight, along with trazodone 
25mg QHS.  She did receive one dose of this ___ night which 
helped her sleep and she was calm and oriented the morning 
after.
- Very hard of hearing.  Debrox ear drops used for 4 days this 
hospitalization for cerumen impaction, last dose ___.
- Non-pharmacological management strategies include toileting 
every ___ hours, assess for and manage constipation, 
nutrition/hydration, regulating sleep wake cycle.  Avoid 
restraints.
- ___ have component of depression to dementia as her husband 
recently passed away.  
- Would strongly recommended starting  SSRI as long as stable on 
seroquel and trazadone. 
.
3. Ankle sprain
- Pain management with Tylenol
- ___ consult
- Ambulate and weight bear as tolerated with assistance
- Seen by Ortho tech, Cam locker brace while ambulating, does 
not need to wear when in bed.  Please wear with right foot shoe.
- Calcium and Vitamin D started during this hospitalization
.
4. Urinary incontinence
- Functional related to fall and foot pain.  Per daughter the 
patient was continent before falling 4 days prior to admission.  
She is now incontinent because of decreased ambulation and 
inability to get to the toilet on time.  Would benefit from a 
toilet schedule every few hours.
.
5. Hypertension
- History of HTN per daughter but she was not taking any 
medications for this at time of admission.  BP ranged from 
___ while hospitalized.
- Previous use of quinapril in the past.
- Please follow up after discharge.
.
Discharge Planning: She was scheduled to move into the 
___ in ___ on 
___ last week but was unable to do this because she was not 
walking or able to toilet herself.  Per ___ she is expected to 
get back to baseline in 2 weeks after her foot heals and should 
be able to return to the assisted living.  Contact person at 
___ is ___ RN.
.
Code Status: DNR/DNI
.
Daughter ___ HCP ___ cell
 
Medications on Admission:
Ativan 0.5mg po TID PRN agitation
Ibruprofen 400mg po with meals PRN pain
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) 
Tablet, Chewable PO TID (3 times a day).  
4. Cyanocobalamin 500 mcg Tablet Sig: Four (4) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. Carbamide Peroxide 6.5 % Drops Sig: ___ Drops Otic BID (2 
times a day) for 2 days: Last dose ___ to complete 4 days of 
therapy.  
6. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
7. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
8. Trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO HS (at bedtime).  
9. Quetiapine 25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for agitation.  
10. Lidocaine 5 %(700 mg/patch) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Sig: 
One (1) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Topical DALIY (): 12 hours on 
12 hours off.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left ankle sprain
probable fifth metatarsal fracture
dementia
delirium
depression
hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Alert to person, family.  Needs reorientation to place and date. 
 Agitated at times.  Able to walk around unit and to bathroom 
with rolling walker and assistance.  Boot available for left 
foot to aid in pain with ambulation.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with left foot swelling, redness, and pain.  
You had an x-ray that did not show fracture; treatment includes 
ice, elevation, and immobilization using boot.  Please continue 
to take your tylenol when needed for pain.  You are able to walk 
on the foot as needed without restrictions.

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___

Service: MEDICINE

No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Shortness of breath
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ and ___ catheter placement.
 
History of Present Illness:
___ w/ HCV and HBV cirrhosis, pulmonary arterial hypertension, 
___, who presented with 2 days SOB, complaining of exertional 
dyspnea that progressed to rest dyspnea. No hemoptysis, ___ 
swelling, no fevers, chills. (+) cough, productive of white 
sputum. 

Initial vitals in the ED were:  100.1 123 127/61 24 77% RA. He 
then was satting in ___ on 15L NRB. On arrival there was initial 
concern for PE, so received 1 dose lovenox on way to stat CTA, 
which was negative for PE, but did show some lingular GGO. He 
was placed on bipap due to increased work of breathing, but had 
oxygen sats in the ___ and was therefore intubated w/ etomidate 
and succinylcholine. Immediately after paralysis and sedation, 
spO2 increased to ___, then declined to ___. He was bagged and 
came back to ___. PEEP was increased to 15, and he received 80 
iv Lasix, vanc/cefepime. R femoral arterial and central venous 
lines were placed.

On arrival to the MICU, he was hypoxic to the ___. Paralysis had 
worn off, so he was paralyzed again and started on Flolan. He 
then acutely desatted to ___ and became hypotensive to SBP 
___ requiring dopamine and levophed. Flolan was stopped. He was 
given Lasix 80 mg IV. Beside ECHO was performed by cardiology 
that showed no intracardiac shunt, markedly dilated RV, trivial 
pericardial effusion without tamponade physiology. Leg raise 
showed that he was fluid responsive so he was given 1L NS. He 
was switched to dobutamine, levophed, and briefly on 
neosynephrine. Oxygenation improved.

He then acutely desaturated to ___ in the absence of any 
provocation. Multiple adjustments to the vent were made without 
effect. He was retrialed on Flolan with further desaturation. He 
subsequently had a PEA arrest. He received one round of chest

levophed, and vasopressin. Thermodilution cardiac output was

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo man w/ hep C, hep B cirrhosis w/ HCC, pulm HTN who 
presented with dyspnea on exertion progressing to rest dyspnea 
and ultimately hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring 
intubation. His hypoxia worsened despite multiple escalating 
interventions. The patient underwent 2 PEA arrests, which 
responded to epinephrine, compressions, and bagging. The patient 
was partially stabilized on inhaled nitrous oxide. Ultimately, 
after multiple family discussions, the patient was made CMO in 
accordance with his anticipated wishes. He was terminally 
extubated and expired from hypoxic respiratory failure.

# Hypoxic respiratory failure: The acute precipitant was 
unclear. Patient may have recently discontinued his macitentan. 
Etiology likely pulmonary hypertension with some component of 
infection in the setting of underlying COPD. CTA with no PE but 
with lingular ground glass opacity. He was intubated in the 
emergency department. We maintained paralysis for optimal 
respiratory dynamics. Patient with evidence of severe shunt 
physiology and with markedly elevated pressures on PA catheter. 
He decompensated with the addition of inhaled Flolan, but the 
interpretation of its effect was complicated by multiple 
concurrent hemodynamic issues. He mildly improved with inhaled 
nitric oxide and inotropic support.

# Refractory Shock, mixed cardiogenic and septic: Most likely 
cardiogenic secondary to RV failure. Possible septic component 
in setting of fever, leukocytosis, and possible lingular 
pneumonia. Pt required escalation of pressors to epinephrine, 
levophed, vasopressin, and dobutamine. He was treated with 
vancomycin, cefepime and azithromycin. Pt had end-organ damage 
including ___ and acute liver injury. 

# Cardiac Arrest: Patient had 2 PEA arrests ___ due to hypoxemia 
w/ ROSC after 1 round each time. Unable to assess mental status 
after due to paralysis. Cooling protocol deferred due to concern 
for pulmonary vasoconstriction. The goal was for normothermia. 
He was placed on an EEG for monitoring. He had a formal Echo in 
the morning, which was not resulted by the time of the family's 
decision. 

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. Albuterol Inhaler 1 PUFF IH PRN SOB 
2. Symbicort (budesonide-formoterol) 160-4.5 mcg/actuation 
inhalation 2x daily 
3. Enalapril Maleate 5 mg PO DAILY 
4. macitentan 10 mg oral DAILY 
5. NIFEdipine CR 30 mg PO DAILY 
6. Tiotropium Bromide 1 CAP IH DAILY 
7. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
n/a
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hypoxic Respiratory Failure. Severe Pulmonary Hypertension
 
Discharge Condition:
Expired.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Patient admitted for weight reduction surgery.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Status Post Laparoscopic Gastric Bypass

 
History of Present Illness:
___ has class III morbid obesity with weight of 250 pounds as
of ___ (her initial screen weight on ___ was 247.8
pounds), height is 64 inches and BMI of 43.  Her previous weight
loss efforts have included self-initiated program of 10 hours 
per
week of aerobic exercise would restricting carbohydrates for 18
months ___ losing 20 pounds that she maintained for 6
months, ___ years of the ___ diet in ___ losing 20 pounds, 6
months of Weight Watchers in ___ losing 50 pounds that she
maintained for ___ years and Slim-Fast continual use for weight
loss maintenance.  She has not taken prescription weight loss
medications or used over-the-counter ephedra-containing appetite
suppressants/herbal supplements.  Her weight at age ___ was
approximately 240 pounds with her lowest adult weight 170 pounds
and her highest weight is her current weight of 250 pounds.
 
Past Medical History:
sleep disordered breathing (Dx: ___ CPAP recommended, 
migraines, iron deficiency, dyslipidemia, fatty liver and 
cholelithiasis s/p cholecystectomy 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family history is noted for father living age ___ with heart
disease and hyperlipidemia; sister living age ___ with asthma and
thyroid disease.  There is a history of diabetes on her father's
side of the family although father is not affected.
 
Physical Exam:
Her blood pressure was 124/80, pulse 109, respirations 16 and O2
saturation 100% on room air.  On physical examination ___ was
casually dressed, mildly anxious but in no distress.  Her skin
was warm, dry with no rashes or lesions. Sclerae were anicteric,
conjunctiva clear, pupils were equal round and reactive to 
light,
fundi were normal, mucous membranes were moist, tongue was pink
and the oropharynx was without exudates or hyperemia.  Trachea
was in the midline and the neck was supple with full range of
motion, no adenopathy, thyromegaly or carotid bruits.  Chest was
symmetric and the lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally
with good air movement.  Cardiac exam was slightly tachycardic
rate and normal rhythm, normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, rubs or
gallops.  The abdomen was obese but soft and non-tender,
non-distended with normal bowel sounds and no masses or hernias,
there were no incision scars.  There is no spinal tenderness or
flank pain.  Lower extremities were without edema, venous
insufficiency or clubbing, perfusion was good.  There was no
evidence of joint swelling or inflammation of the joints.  There
were no focal neurological deficits and her gait was normal.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 10:50AM BLOOD Hct-29.5*
___ 07:05AM BLOOD Hct-29.4*

UGI study on ___
Severe stenosis at the gastrojejunostomy likely related to post- 

surgical edema. There is no evidence of leak. 

___ Chest CT 
IMPRESSION:  
1. Limited study, no evidence of central PE. 
2. Findings consistent with aspiration with extensive opacities 
in both lower 
lobes. Recommend PA and lateral chest radiograph, to establish 
baseline and 
monitor resolution. 
3. Status post gastric bypass with trace intraperitoneal air. 
4. Fatty liver.  
5. Mild splenomegaly. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient underwent a laparoscopic gastric bypass without event. 
Postoperatively she did quite well with noted tachycardia and 
decrease in saturations. To rule out pulmnary emboli sh ewas 
sent for a chest CT that confirmed no evidence of emboli.

On postoperative day one she had an upper gi study that 
confirmed n leak or obstruction. She was slowly advanced to a 
stage three bariatric diet without nausea or vomiting.

Discharge instructions were extensively reviewed with patient 
with emphasis on maintaining a stage 3 diet and hydration needs. 


She will follow up with Dr. ___ nutritionist in 2 
weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
Adderall 20' Lexapro 20', MVI, vitamin B12 1000' 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Roxicet ___ mg/5 mL Solution Sig: ___ ml PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*500 ml* Refills:*0*
2. Colace 50 mg/5 mL Liquid Sig: Ten (10) ml PO twice a day.
Disp:*500 ml* Refills:*0*
3. Zantac 15 mg/mL Syrup Sig: Ten (10) ml PO twice a day: Please 
take for one month.
Disp:*600 ml* Refills:*0*
4. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.  
5. Lexapro 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day: 
Please crush.  
6. Adderall 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day: 
Please crush.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis: Obesity

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you.

Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment. 
Do not self advance
diet, do not drink out of a straw or chew gum.

Medication Instructions:
Resume your home medications, CRUSH ALL PILLS.
You will be starting some new medications:
1.  You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.
2. You should begin taking a chewable complete multivitamin with 
minerals twice a day. No gummy vitamins.
3. You will be taking Zantac liquid ___ mg twice daily for one 
month. This medicine prevents gastric reflux.
4. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.
5. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and 
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your 
digestive system.

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

3. You will be taking Zantac liquid ___ mg twice daily for one
month. This medicine prevents gastric reflux.
4. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel
pattern.
5. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory
drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and
Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your
digestive system.
Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.
Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming.
If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with
clean, dry gauze.
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling,
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo male with hx of achalasia s/p myomectomy 
+ partial funduplication ___ yr ago who presents with abdominal 
cramps for the past 1 week. Patient notes fecal urgency with 
yellowish liquid stools that smelled of ammonia over the same 
time period. The day of admission patient endorsed onset of 
vomiting with yellow emesis with occasional flecks of blood.  
.  
In the ED, initial VS 98.7, 113, 18, 126/73, 97%. Exam notable 
for TTP in the left lower quadrant with mild rebound. Patient 
had CT which demonstrated perforated diverticuli in proximal 
sigmoid colon. Labs were notable for a normal WBC, lipase and 
non elevated lactate. He was guaiac negative. Patient was given 
levofloxacin, flagyl and 4 L of IVF. He was evaluated by surgery 
who recommended IV antibiotics, NPO with admission to medicine. 
Vitals on transfer were 98.7, 113, 18, 126/73, 97% RA.  
.  
Currently, he feels better after the morphine in the ED. He is 
very hungry but understands why he is NPO. Patient has had 
decreased appetite over the past week or so, and had an episode 
of nausea with dry heaves this AM. His abdominal pain is 
localized to the LLQ without radiation and feels crampy in 
nature. No fevers or chills.  
.  
ROS: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, congestion, 
sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, vomiting, 
BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria.  

 
Past Medical History:
s/p Total left hip replacement in ___  
s/p Left shoulder repair for dislocation  
Achalasia s/p Myomectomy and partial fundoplication ___ 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father has dysphagia but has never been worked up. Mother and 
maternal uncle both had CAD with MIs.  

 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:  
VS - Temp 98.4 F, BP 118/74, HR 111, RR 20, O2-sat 96% RA  
GENERAL - well-appearing man in NAD, comfortable, appropriate  
HEENT - Sclerae anicteric, MMM, OP clear  
NECK - supple,  
LUNGS - CTA bilat, no r/rh/wh, good air movement, resp 
unlabored, no accessory muscle use  
HEART - PMI non-displaced, RRR, no MRG, nl S1-S2  
ABDOMEN - NABS, soft/NT, LLQ tenderness to deep palpation 
without rebound or guarding, no masses or HSM  
EXTREMITIES - WWP, no c/c/e, 2+ DPs bilaterally  
SKIN - no rashes or lesions  
NEURO - awake, A&Ox3  

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
VS- T98.5 BP 121/75 HR 98 RR 20 O2 98RA
ABD - active BS, tender to palpation in LLQ without rebound, 
guarding
Exam otherwise unchanged
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
WBC-10.6 RBC-5.10 HGB-14.1 HCT-42.0 MCV-82 MCH-27.6 MCHC-33.5 
RDW-13.7
 PLT COUNT-324
 NEUTS-84.8* LYMPHS-10.3* MONOS-4.2 EOS-0.5 BASOS-0.2
 GLUCOSE-118* UREA N-15 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-136 POTASSIUM-4.2 
CHLORIDE-102 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-13
ALT(SGPT)-21 AST(SGOT)-19 ALK PHOS-75 TOT BILI-0.5
LIPASE-22
ALBUMIN-4.0
___ 12:00PM   LACTATE-1.3

Urinalysis- negative

Microbiology:
Blood culture x ___- pending, no growth to date
Urine culture ___- pending

Imaging:
CT abd/pelvis ___- Findings consistent with perforated sigmoid 
diverticulitis. No drainable fluid collection. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo male with a history of achalasia s/p myomectomy and 
fundoplication presenting with perforated diverticulitis. 

# Perforated Diverticulitis- Patient presented with abdominal 
pain for 9 days with imaging consistent with perforated 
diverticulitis. Patient evaluated by surgery who felt that given 
___ score of ___ did not need surgery should be medically 
managed. Patient was kept NPO overnight and started on IV 
ciprofloxacin and metronidazole.  Patient was able to tolerate a 
slowly advancing diet, and antibiotics were changed to oral 
regimen.  He was discharged on 7 days ciprofloxacin and 
metronidazole, with instructions to avoid high fiber diet for 
the upcoming weeks. Pain was well controlled at the time of 
discharge, and patient was given small amount of oxycodone for 
breakthrough pain.
   
# Hx of achalasia- Stable s/p myomectomy one year ago.

# Transitional issues-
- blood cultures and urine cultures pending at time of discharge
- 7 days of antibiotics, ending ___
- PCP ___ not yet scheduled; patient will be called with 
time/date of appointment
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H 
(every 12 hours) for 7 days: through ___.
Disp:*13 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. metronidazole 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 
8 hours) for 7 days.
Disp:*19 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. oxycodone 5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO every six (6) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*15 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Perforated diverticulitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
admission.

You were admitted with stomach pain and nausea/vomiting. You 
were found to have an infection in your colon, called 
diverticulitis.  You were given antibiotics, and since you were 
able to take an oral diet, these antibiotics were given orally.

Please take the following antibiotics for seven days, through 
___:
- Metronidazole (flagyl) three times a day
- Ciprofloxacin (cipro) two times a day
- for pain control, you can take oxycodone as needed every 6 
hours. Please do not drive a care or operate heavy machinery 
while taking this medication
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Pubic Symphysis Pain
Induction of Labor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cesarean birth
Blood transfusion
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo G3P1011 at 38w4d presented to L+D with complaint of 
increasing pubic bone pain preventing her from ambulating. She 
was recently evaluated for lower extremity  swelling with 
negative PIH eval. 

PNC: ___ ___ by LMP
- A+/Ab neg/RPR NR/RI/HBsAg neg/GBS positive
- normal fetal survey- declined quad screen
- ___ EFW 15%tile, ___ 25%tile with BPP ___ with
reactive NST
- MRSA+ culture
- Prior admission for hyperemesis gravidarum ___
- s/p fall ___ with separated pubic symphasis requiring
admission, seen by ___
- Recurrent Proteus UTI; on cephalexin; culture pan-sensitive
- Anemia, HCT ___
- a few elevated BP, w/u negative ___
- Rubeola non-immune
- asthma - rare use of albuterol

 
Past Medical History:
OBHx: G2P1
- SVD x 1 at term after PTL at 31 wks s/p BMZ and tocolysis

MedHx: asthma, anemia

SurgHx: denies

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission:
VSS - 116/72; afebrile.
Gen: NAD, uncomfortable with movement; arrived in wheelchair
Abd: soft, gravid. Severe pain with palpation of pubic bone. EFW
7# by ___
Ext: tr ___ bilaterally.
SVE: ___ 
FHT: 130's, +accels, no decels, moderate variability
Toco: irregular

 
Pertinent Results:
Notable for Hct of 24.0 upon admission. This went to 21.9 on ___ 
at 1440. 
Post-operatively on ___, Hct was 15.9, repeat x 2 were 16.2 and 
15.3.

Coags on ___: ___ PTT-27.7 ___

Utox was negative.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ y/o who was admitted on ___ for IOL for 
increasing pubic symphysis pain. She was noted to be group-B 
strep positive and started on penicillin. Cytotec was given to 
start her induction. She was eventually started on pitocin, and 
this was increased to 20 without cervical change. On ___, the 
she was noted to have concerning vaginal bleeding and a 
non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing. The decision was made 
to proceed with cesarean delivery for concern of abruption. 

Intraoperatively, a large adherent clot was found on the 
placenta. A male baby was delivered, with APGARs of 8 and 8. 
NICU was present for the delivery, and suctioned old blood out 
of the baby's stomach. The patient was taken to the recovery 
room in stable condition.

Pre-operatively, her Hct was noted to be 24.8. This dropped to 
21.9, then on POD #1 was found to be 15.7. She was without signs 
of symptoms of anemia, and HR remained in the ___, orthostatic 
vital signs were negative, urine output was good. On POD #2, 
transfusion was strongly recommended. Patient declined. Vital 
signs remained stable and she continued to have no sx. 
Transfusion was re-addressed with the patient, and she agreed on 
POD #3. She was transfused 2 U PRBCs without complications. 
Post-transfusion Hct was 22.4, still without symptoms. She was 
discharged home on POD# 4 in stable condition.  

 
Medications on Admission:
PNV, iron, cephalexin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for Constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*3*
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every six (6) hours as needed for Pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Iron (Ferrous Sulfate) 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One 
(1) Tablet PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cesarean birth
anemia

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Pelvic rest
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Antibiotics)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
fall
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
closed reduction of left radius fracture
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo woman with PMH notable only for HCV with right ankle 
fracture ___ now s/p fall on crutches today with left radius 
fracture, admitted for rehab placement. Patient reports that at 
initial fall she lost her grip on a handrail and fell down 20 
stairs, fracturing her ankle. She was dc-ed from ED with 
crutches and oxycodone. ___ night she attempted to go to 
the bathroom after recently taking oxycodone, lost control of 
her crutches, and fell backwards onto left wrist. She denies 
LOC, dizziness/lightheadedness, CP/palpitations/SOB, subjective 
weakness.

In the ED, initial vitals were: 99.8 102 126/60 14 95% RA 
She was found to have left scaphoid fx and intra-articular 
distal radius fracture and underwent reduction and casting by 
orthopedics.
Patient was given: morphine 5 mg x5, zofran 4 mg x3
Consults: Seen by ortho who recommended NWB L wrist immobilized 
in splint, WBAT on LEs in short-leg walking boot. Follow up with 
Dr. ___ in 1 week.

On the floor, patient is feeling well. Pain and nausea 
adequately controlled.
 
Past Medical History:
HCV with plan for future treatment
H/o Lyme disease s/p 1 month doxycycline and 4 months 
tetracycline
Laparoscopy for h/o PID in ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother with parkinsons, CAD s/p CABG, valve replacement. Father 
with CAD s/p CABG, prostate CA. Paternal ___ with gastric CA.

 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vitals: 99.5 136-71 85 18 98% RA
General: Pleasant woman lying comfortbaly in bed, alert, 
oriented, no acute distress
HEENT: Sclerae anicteric, MMM, EOMI,pupils small but reactive 
bilaterally
Neck: Supple, no LAD
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
rhonchi
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no organomegaly, no rebound or guarding
GU: No foley
Ext: L arm in cast, fingers warm with normal sensation. Right 
ankle edematous, warm, with petechial rash over medial aspect of 
foot, normal sensation. Left ankle with trace edema.
Neuro: CNII-XII intact, moving all extremities purposefully.

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:

 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS:
___ 06:00AM BLOOD WBC-7.1 RBC-4.21 Hgb-12.1 Hct-37.6 MCV-89 
MCH-28.7 MCHC-32.2 RDW-13.4 RDWSD-43.6 Plt ___
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Glucose-84 UreaN-11 Creat-0.6 Na-137 
K-3.9 Cl-101 HCO3-25 AnGap-15
___ 06:00AM BLOOD ALT-49* AST-44* AlkPhos-72 TotBili-0.8
___ 06:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-3.4 Mg-

DISCHARGE LABS:
No labs drawn day of discharge.

IMAGING:
___ CT left upper extremity: 1. Comminuted, intra-articular, 
mildly impacted fracture of the distal radius contains a 
fracture gap measuring 4 mm in the AP dimension.
2. There are comminuted, minimally displaced fractures of the 
waist of the scaphoid and the ulnar styloid.

___ XR left hand/wrist: Interval casting of left wrist with 
improved alignment at the distal radius comminuted 
intra-articular fracture. Ulna styloid process and scaphoid 
waist fractures are stable.

___ XR right ankle: Small avulsion fragment distal to the 
tip of the lateral malleolus, compatible with avulsion injury of 
indeterminate age.  There is soft tissue swelling about the 
ankle.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo woman with PMH notable only for HCV with right ankle 
fracture ___ now s/p fall on crutches ___ with left 
radius fracture, admitted for rehab placement.

#Fall: Patient initially fell on some stairs resulting in the 
fracture of her right ankle. Patient reported she then fell in 
her house shortly after being discharged from the ED for her 
ankle fracture, very late at night, having recently taken 
oxycodone. She denied any LOC, dizziness/lightheadedness, 
CP/SOB/palpitations. Given history consistent with mechanical 
fall, no further workup was done. She was seen by ___ in the ED 
who recommended rehab placement. She was admitted to the 
medicine service and kept on fall precautions.

#L wrist and R ankle fractures: Patient initially had fracture 
of right tibial malleolus. Second, presenting fall caused 
fractures of left ulna styloid, scaphoid, and distal radius. 
Radius fracture reduced by orthopedics in the ED. Pain was 
controlled with ibuprofen and oxycodone, and nausea controlled 
with zofran. Per ortho recs patient was kept NWB to L wrist, and 
weight bearing as tolerated to ___ with boot. She will need to

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / azithromycin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
nasal septal deviation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
functional septoplasty and cosmetic open rhinoplasty

 
History of Present Illness:
she is a ___ female with
history of having nasal obstructive symptoms.  She states that
the left side may be greater than the right side with respect to
nasal obstructive symptoms.  She states that she has sinus
infections approximately two to three times a month during the
___ months.  She states that she uses Flonase with respect to
nasal spray and she has not had a nasal fracture.  She has an
interest regarding functional nasal procedures for improvement 
of
breathing.
 
Past Medical History:
Past Medical History:
Includes high blood pressure.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family History:  
Significant for high blood pressure and stroke.

 
Physical Exam:
On exam, she is alert, oriented, in no apparent distress, fully
ambulatory, fully conversant.  She has a weight of 120 pounds. 
She has a height of 5 feet 4 inches.  Examination of the nasal
area reveals septal deflection to the left side seen with 
respect
to nasal septal region.  She has turbinates that are moderate in
size on both sides.  She has mild skin thickness as well as
rosacea of her nasal tip area.  She has been negative ___
sign.  She has well-defined lower lateral cartilages and her
cranial nerve examination is otherwise intact.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had a nasal septoplasty and open rhinoplasty.  The 
patient tolerated the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received Morphine PCA with 
good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She had some nausea which was treated 
with Zofran. Intake and output were closely monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV clindamycin, 
then switched to PO clindamycin for discharge home. The 
patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: She was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early 
as possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.
 
Medications on Admission:
Alprazolam 0.25 mg tab ___ tab prn sleep 
Cyclosporine 0.05% eye drops both eyes bid 
Fluticasone 50 mc nasal 2 whiffs nasally daily 
lisinopril 10 mg tab daily 
calcium 
vitamin D3 000 U po daily 
omega-3 fish oil 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. ALPRAZolam 0.25 mg PO TID:PRN sleep  
2. Clindamycin 300 mg PO Q6H 
3. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 
4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
nasal septal deviation, nasal occlusion

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
* Please contact your doctor for any serious change in your 
symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds as ordered.
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
.
*You may take a bath or shower, but do not get your face/nose 
wet until instructed by your doctor.
* Keep your dressings in place until your follow up appointment 
with your doctor.  You may change your 'mustache' dressing as 
needed.
* No strenuous activity until instructed by your doctor.
* Finish all of your antibiotics
* Sleep with head elevated to help with swelling
* You may use soft, cool compresses around your eyes for comfort 
but do not use them on your nose.
* Do NOT blow your nose
* Sneeze with your mouth open
* do NOT take any medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or 
Ibuprofen etc.
.
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
cantalope
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hyperparathyroidism.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Removal of right upper parathyroid adenoma.

 
History of Present Illness:
Primary hyperparathyroidism.  Sestamibi ultrasound positive on 
right side.  Ultrasound showed a large lesion.

 
Past Medical History:
DM
Asthma
Anxiety

 
Physical Exam:
VS:98.0 85 109/66 18 100% RA
Gen: well appearing, NAD, clear phonation
HEENT:neck soft, no hematoma,steris c/d/i
Cardiac:regular rate rhythm,S1 S2 normal
Pulmonary: clear, no stridor
Abdomen:soft,nontender, nondistended
Ext: WWP, no CCE

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:20AM BLOOD Calcium-9.6
___ 10:15AM BLOOD PTH-LESS THAN 
___ 07:10AM BLOOD PTH-168*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old woman with history of hyperparathyroidism, 
now status post right superior parathyroidectomy.The patient 
tolerated the procedure well and after an uneventful stay in the 
PACU,she was admitted overnight to the floor for observation. 
Her postoperative course was stable. Postoperatively her voice 
was slight hoarse however she had good phonation. She denied any 
perioral/lower extremity paresthesia. Her diet was advanced as 
tolerated and she voided spontaneously. Her pain was well 
controlled with oral pain medication. Her surgical neck incision 
remained dry and intact without any signs of wound infection or 
hematoma. Postoperatively her PTH and calcium levels were 
normal. POD 1, she was discharged home in good condition and 
will follow-up with Dr. ___ in clinic.
 
Medications on Admission:
albuterol nebulizers, albuterol inhaler, fluticasone 2 puffs 
intranasal BID, fluticasone inhaler 2 puffs BID, ibuprofen prn, 
singulair 10', vitamin D3 1000'

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q4H:PRN wheeze 
3. Cepastat (Phenol) Lozenge ___ LOZ PO Q4H:PRN sore throat 
4. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 
5. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU BID 
6. Montelukast 10 mg PO DAILY 
7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY 
9. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hyperparathyroidism.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your admission to 
___ after your surgery. Please refer to the following 
discharge instructions.
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication and take any new 
medications as prescribed. You will be given a prescription for 
narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed. It is recommended 
that you take a stool softner such as Colace while taking oral 
narcotic pain medication to prevent constipation. You may also 
take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 
mg in one day. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk 
several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.

Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site. You may shower and wash incisions with a mild 
soap and warm water. Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by 
your surgeon. Gently pat the area dry.You have a neck incision 
with steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own.

All the Best,
 The ___ Surgery Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___
